headline: cincinnati police raise ‘blue lives matter’ flag outside justice center
standfirst: Hamilton county sheriff said US flag was stolen and ‘thin blue line’ flag was raised to honor officer who was shotl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: police officers in cincinnati, ohio, stoked tensions with groups  protesting against police brutality by raising a provocative flag that represents police officers outside a law enforcement building in place of the stars and stripes.

headline: workplace inclusion drives have almost trebled since blm protests, survey shows
standfirst: About half of minority-ethnic workers said their employer had taken action to tackle racism in past 12 months
lead_paragraph: the number of employers implementing new diversity and inclusion drives has almost trebled since the end of the black lives matter protests, new research shows.

headline: dining across the divide: ‘she thinks people come to britain for a free house’
standfirst: They disagreed on newspapers, immigration and Black Lives Matter. Can two strangers see eye to eye over dinner?l>i> Click here if you’d like to dine across the dividei>l>
lead_paragraph: trong>amanda, 52, west yorkshiretrong>

headline: can black lives matter la dismantle the powerful police unions?
standfirst: Union members who lost relatives to officer killings are fighting to eject ‘harmful and violent’ police groups from labor associationsr>
lead_paragraph: on 22 april 2020, a los angeles police officer showed up to the scene of a car accident and fatally shot one of the drivers.

headline: a pirate captain cook and his own head in a jar: the subversive satire of daniel boyd
standfirst: Ahead of a career-spanning exhibition, the Indigenous Australian artist talks about his family story, Black Lives Matter and why he is inspired by an Aboriginal warrior who took on the invading Britonsl>i> Get our weekend culture and lifestyle email and  listen to our podcasti>l>
lead_paragraph: the stories of aboriginal warriors who fought british colonisation, among them  windradyne,  yagan and  jandamarra, provide cultural affirmation for many indigenous australians. for the artist daniel boyd, it was  pemulwuy, the bidjigal clan man who led a long guerrilla war that began shortly after the arrival of the first fleet, who became a personal source of strength.

headline: ‘excited delirium’ emerges as key issue in trial of officers accused over george floyd death
standfirst: Civil rights trial of Tou Thao, J Alexander Kueng and Thomas Lane, accused of failing to intervene in Floyd’s murder, takes place
lead_paragraph: use of the controversial label “excited delirium” by first responders when subduing people exhibiting signs of severe agitation has emerged as a key issue in the  federal trial of three former minneapolis police officers involved in the death of  george floyd.

headline: shorta review – a racist cop’s redemption
standfirst: Police brutality triggers unrest on a Danish housing estate in this visually striking but misconceived morality tale
lead_paragraph: in the aftermath of an inflammatory incident of police brutality, level-headed danish cop jens (simon sears) is partnered with boorish racist mike (jacob lohmann) in the hope that he can keep the older officer’s worst impulses in check. but the two men find themselves trapped in the svalegarden housing estate, just as tensions boil over. there’s a clear kinship with films such as yann demange’s m> ’71m> and the french oscar nominee m> les misérablesm>. but while m>shortam> is certainly a propulsive piece of action cinema, which makes effective use of its acid yellow, cement grey and burnt umber palette and warren-of-concrete location, there’s a crudely schematic quality to the writing. mike’s gradual redemption comes at the expense of seemingly expendable young arab characters, and as the film staggers to its overwrought conclusion, we’re left with the question of whether the story of the bigoted cop is really the one that needed to be told.

headline: andrea sahouri on her blm protest arrest: 'i was the only journalist of color and the only journalist arrested'
standfirst: The Des Moines Register reporter speaks about her arrest while covering a protest against police brutality: ‘I did my job and I did it correctly’
lead_paragraph: six days after the murder of george floyd, the des moines register journalist  andrea sahouri went to work.

headline: golden globes crisis deepens as former president expelled and advisers resign
standfirst: Hollywood Foreign Press Association expels Philip Berk after he shared article calling Black Lives Matter a ‘racist hate group’
lead_paragraph: the crisis-plagued hollywood foreign press association (hfpa), the body that organises the golden globes, has expelled philip berk, its former president  who sparked widespread outrage by sharing an anti-black lives matter article that described the movement as a “racist hate group”.

headline: why are palestinians protesting? because we want to live | mariam barghouti
standfirst: Just as the Black Lives Matter protests were not only about one killing, we are facing a whole regime of oppression
lead_paragraph: i started going to demonstrations when i was 17. at first, i went to protests against israel’s military occupation. then we also began to protest against the authoritarianism of the palestinian authority and hamas, and the  sickening rivalry between palestinian political factions. for palestinians, protest has become a way of life – a way to  be steadfast, to persevere.

headline: israeli spyware firm linked to fake black lives matter and amnesty websites – report
standfirst: Researchers say web domains masquerading as activist, health and media groups are used by governments to hack targets
lead_paragraph: an israeli company that sells spyware to governments is linked to fake black lives matter andtrong> trong>amnesty international websites that are used to hack targets, according to a new report.

headline: first thing: breonna taylor decision sparks protests across the us
standfirst: Two police officers were shot in Louisville after a grand jury declined to bring charges in Taylor’s killing. Plus, a Black Lives Matter founder on the movement’s past and futurel>i>trong> Don’t already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up heretrong>i>l>
lead_paragraph: good morning,

headline: no 10's race report widely condemned as 'divisive'
standfirst: Review set up after Black Lives Matter protests says family and socioeconomic background bigger factors than racism
lead_paragraph: a landmark report on racial disparity has been widely condemned by mps, unions, and equality campaigners as “divisive” and a missed opportunity for systematic change.

headline: ahmaud arbery: trial of accused murderers is test for racial justice ‘in the heart of white supremacy’
standfirst: Six months after Derek Chauvin was convicted of murdering George Floyd, the case of a Black man killed while jogging in Georgia is a sterner litmus test
lead_paragraph: beneath the spanish moss that swayed from an oak tree, diane arbery jackson took a seat in the morning shade as the three white men accused of murdering her nephew sat in the courtroom a few feet away.

headline: black lives matter group offers rural people 'insight into prejudice'
standfirst: BLM in the Stix promotes online toolkit to encourage UK communities to take a standr>
lead_paragraph: black lives matter activists have launched a toolkit designed to help rural communities across the uk to fight racism in their local area.

headline: thousands gather in london for george floyd protest
standfirst: Star Wars actor John Boyega among those taking part in Hyde Park Black Lives Matter protest
lead_paragraph: thousands of mostly young protesters have marched through central london in an overwhelmingly peaceful black lives matter demonstration that culminated in passionate crowds gathering at the heart of westminster.

headline: wnba players to wear names of women such as breonna taylor on jerseys
standfirst: l>i>Shirts will honour women who have died at hands of policei>i>Warm-up jerseys will carry Black Lives Matter slogani>l>
lead_paragraph: the wnba,  long the most progressive league in us sports, says its players will wear the names of women  who have been killed by police or in racial violence when the season resumes later this month.

headline: derek chauvin pleads guilty to civil rights charges in killing of george floyd
standfirst: Ex-Minneapolis police officer has already been convicted of state murder and manslaughter charges and sentenced to 22 1/2 years
lead_paragraph: former minneapolis police officer derek chauvin has pleaded guilty to violating george floyd’s civil rights during the arrest that killed floyd in may 2020, sparking mass racial justice protests across the us and beyond.

headline: protests about police brutality are met with wave of police brutality across us
standfirst: Use of teargas, batons, pepper spray, fists, feet and vehicles against protesters sparks lawsuits and international condemnation l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the nationwide anti-police brutality protests sparked by the killing of george floyd in the us have been marked by widespread incidents of police violence, including punching, kicking, gassing, pepper-spraying and driving vehicles at often peaceful protesters in states across the country.

headline: the verdict on the sewell report into racial disparity | halima begum and others
standfirst: Did the government’s response to the Black Lives Matter protests measure up? A panel of writers responds
lead_paragraph: for tony sewell to argue that there is no  evidence of institutional racism in the uk is delusional. it is deeply disturbing to see this government-commissioned report riddled with so many distortions. neither the existence nor the extent of institutionalised racism can be denied.

headline: troy deeney urges social media firms and government to tackle racism
standfirst: l>i>Watford captain says George Floyd killing has been a catalysti>i>#PlayersTogether initiative raffling Black Lives Matter shirtsi>l>
lead_paragraph: troy deeney has called on social media companies and the government to do more to eradicate racism after the #playerstogether initiative launched a raffle of black lives matter shirts worn by premier league footballers.

headline: far-right thugs exploit black lives matter movement, warns uk anti-extremism chief
standfirst: Home Office commissioner Sara Khan reveals surge in online hate material since death of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: the black lives matter movement has been aggressively exploited by the uk’s far right, which has recruited and radicalised people on the back of its success, the government’s chief adviser on extremism has warned.

headline: sweeping george floyd police reform bill stalls as talks collapse
standfirst: Floyd’s cousin urges Biden to do all he can to push through reform as negotiators clash on key issues
lead_paragraph: bipartisan negotiations in the us congress over a police reform bill that was prompted by the killing of george floyd have collapsed.

headline: george floyd’s family urges biden to pass a policing reform bill – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> President has private meeting with members of Floyd’s familyi>i> One year on, how George Floyd’s murder has changed the worldi>i> Biden confirms he’ll meet Vladimir Putin in Switzerland next monthr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2021-05-26t00:09:36.901z">1.09am pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: systemic racism and police brutality are british problems too | kojo koram
standfirst: Those who argue that Black Lives Matter protesters are jumping on an American bandwagon wilfully miss the point
lead_paragraph: it’s october 2019, and bestselling authors douglas murray and lionel shriver take to the stage for an event at central hall westminsterm>.m> part of the way through their talk, murray begins to rail against the 2016 british black lives matter protests and what he sees as “the globalisation of a specific american racial issue”.

headline: a racist, belligerent press doesn’t just hurt its targets, it’s bad for all of us | nesrine malik
standfirst: Whether it’s EU migrants or Black Lives Matter campaigners, enemies are singled out to keep Britain’s hierarchies intact
lead_paragraph: there is a myth that many in the press in britain cling on to for dear life: they are members of a crusading profession which, in the mould of  woodward and bernstein, unfailingly holds the powerful to account. if there are any isolated examples of journalism that afflicts the powerless by indulging in racism or encouraging prejudice, they are outweighed by all the good work of those crusaders. the myth remains impervious to all the evidence that continues to mount, but every once in a while the sheer weight of reality comes through.

headline: derek chauvin trial: george floyd was ‘a person everybody loved’, says his brother – as it happened
standfirst: l>i>Murder trial over George Floyd’s death enters 11th day i>i>Philonise Floyd delivers emotional testimony for prosecutioni>i> Doctor says George Floyd’s death ‘absolutely preventable’i>i> Protests near Minneapolis after fatal police shooting at traffic stopi>i> Republicans push ‘tsunami’ of harsh anti-protest laws after BLM ralliesi>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2021-04-12t22:12:33.992z">11.12pm pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: 'i hear you': boris johnson to black lives matter protesters
standfirst: Prime minister acknowledges ‘feeling of injustice’ but warns of enforcement and virus riskl>i> What Floyd protests have achieved in just two weeksr>i>i> London mayor seeks to defuse tensionsi>l>
lead_paragraph: boris johnson has responded to the black lives matter protests with an article acknowledging the “incontrovertible, undeniable feeling of injustice” motivating the rallies, while condemning those who have flouted social distancing to attend them during a “time of national trial”.

headline: outcry as kyle rittenhouse sits down for tucker carlson fox news interview
standfirst: Eighteen-year-old, who was photographed before the trial with apparent Proud Boys, says: ‘I support the BLM movement’
lead_paragraph: kyle rittenhouse sat down for his first interview since being cleared of homicide on monday night, speaking with fox news’s tucker carlson in a segment that sparked a fresh round of controversy after the teen said he was “not a racist person” and supported the black lives matter movement.

headline: jofra archer fires back at holding and insists england cricket supports blm
standfirst: l>i>Sky pundit criticised England for stopping ‘taking a knee’i>i>Bowler says: ‘No one here has forgotten Black Lives Matter’i>l>
lead_paragraph: jofra archer insists england have not forgotten the spirit of the black lives matter movement and that michael holding had not done his research when criticising the team’s decision to stop taking a knee.

headline: derek chauvin jury begins deliberations as america braces for verdict
standfirst: l>i>Former officer charged with murder of George Floydi>l>
lead_paragraph: the derek chauvin murder trial heard closing arguments on monday before the jury began considering a verdict over the death of george floyd that is anxiously awaited by millions of americans.

headline: black lives matter isn't about statues or tv shows. it's about real lives being ruined | nosheen iqbal
standfirst: Ignore the trivialising punditry. This movement exists because of police brutality and systemic unfairness
lead_paragraph: in the past six weeks, i’ve lost count of the number of times i’ve been contacted about police brutality in britain. as a reporter, i’ve been sent photos of a black child picked up and thrown to the ground by an officer on hampstead heath. i’ve witnessed a dozen officers chase and aggressively pin an unarmed black 14-year-old boy on to his belly in a tottenham park. i’ve been emailed a video of black teenagers cuffed, harassed and searched by officers while their white friend can only watch. another of young black men physically shaking after being manhandled by police for walking a dog. i can promise you there’s so much more. it’s not even hard to find – social media is flooded with proof. you simply have to open your eyes and look.

headline: shorta review – danish urban thriller gets the heart pumping
standfirst: Two cops are stranded in hostile territory when an act of police brutality triggers a riot in this slick action film
lead_paragraph: denmark’s reputation as the land of tolerance, equality and cosy contentment takes a battering in this superslick urban thriller directed with adrenaline and savvy by first timers frederik louis hviid and anders ølholm. “shorta” is arabic for “police”, and the movie opens with black teenager talib ben hassi lying face down, a white police officer on his back. “i can’t breathe,” he pleads. we don’t see talib again but his name is repeated over and over: on the streets in svalegårdena, the fictional estate where he grew up; by tv journalists reporting on his condition in intensive care; at the police station where damage limitation is in overdrive.

headline: kentucky partially bans no-knock warrants after breonna taylor killing
standfirst: l>i>Governor Andy Beshear: ‘I know more needs to be done’i>i>Law received bipartisan support in Republican-led legislaturei>l>
lead_paragraph: the governor of kentucky has signed into law a partial ban on no-knock warrants, a year after the police shooting of breonna taylor fueled anti-racism demonstrations in the us and around the world.

headline: mass anti-racism protests take place in cities across uk
standfirst: Many thousands join rallies in response to George Floyd killing despite warningsl>i> George Floyd killing: latest updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: tens of thousands of people attended protests across the uk on sunday – including one where a statue of a slave trader was pulled down – after a week in which growing numbers defied calls from politicians and police to avoid mass gatherings to rally against racial injustice.

headline: an arrest at the george floyd protests: mel d cole’s best photograph
standfirst: ‘As soon as I took this shot, I knew it was special – something pretty much all Black people could relate to. This man was arrested for daring to question authority. I’ve been arrested for the same thing’
lead_paragraph: i took this on the first day of the protests in foley square, new york, following the murder of  george floyd. i’ve witnessed protests before but nothing like this. it was intense, volatile and angry. people were sick and tired – and ready to fight for their rights.

headline: un calls for end of ‘impunity’ for police violence against black people
standfirst: Report launched in aftermath of George Floyd murder cites example of 2018 death of Kevin Clarke in UK
lead_paragraph: a un report that analysed racial justice in the aftermath of the murder of george floyd has called on member states including the uk to end the “impunity” enjoyed by police officers who violate the human rights of black people.

headline: blm protesters cleared over toppling of edward colston statue
standfirst: Rhian Graham, Milo Ponsford, Sage Willoughby and Jake Skuse found not guilty over act of public dissent during Bristol protest
lead_paragraph: anti-racism campaigners have hailed a jury’s decision to clear protesters responsible for toppling a statue of the slave trader edward colston as a huge step in getting the uk to face up to its colonial past.

headline: 'it keeps her alive': remembering breonna taylor through art
standfirst: A new exhibition, involving Breonna Taylor’s mother Tamika Palmer, aims to honor her legacy one year after her killing at the hands of police
lead_paragraph: last year, the baltimore artist  amy sherald painted  breonna taylor, a 26-year-old medical worker who was killed by police, as a commission for the cover of vanity fair, depicting taylor in hues of turquoise and blues, standing elegantly, like a goddess, in a long, flowy dress. “producing this image keeps breonna alive forever,”  said sherald.

headline: be reassured: the world is not as divided as we might think | stephan shakespeare and joel rogers de waal
standfirst: Beneath the public discord about BLM, the climate and feminism, there is surprising consensus about how the world should be
lead_paragraph: today’s widely accepted narrative is that we live in historically divided times. voters are routinely described as “polarised”, while analysts compete to identify the essential schism of the age, whether this is  metropolitan versus traditionalist,  people versus democracy or  anywheres versus somewheres.

headline: stella dadzie, feminist pioneer: ‘the black british women’s movement was about life-and-death issues’
standfirst: She co-wrote a classic, The Heart of the Race, and helped draw attention to overlooked atrocities – including racism in schools, police brutality and deaths in custody
lead_paragraph: one night in 1998 stella dadzie went to two celebrations. the writer, 69, best known for co-authoring the 1985 feminist classic,  href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/the_heart_of_the_race:_black_women%27s_lives_in_britain" title="">the heart of the race, first stopped at the dorchester hotel for maya angelou’s 70th birthday. it was a wonderful party. “i tied my hair up and wore a very afrocentric dress, unlike many people who’d been at the hairdresser all day and bought a special outfit, i was never that kind of person.” later, after a quick change of shoes, and “without batting an eyelid” dadzie was off again, this time to a “rave on the stonebridge estate in harlesden”.

headline: 'he is a destroyer': how the george floyd protests left donald trump exposed
standfirst: As cities reel under protest and violence, Black Lives Matter leaders say the president has failed his countryl>i> George Floyd protests: live coverager>i>i> Robert Reich: the Trump presidency is overi>l>
lead_paragraph: “americans watching this address tonight have seen the recent images of violence in our streets and the chaos in our communities. many have witnessed this violence personally, some have even been its victims. i have a message for all of you: the crime and violence that today afflicts our nation will soon – and i mean very soon – come to an end.”

headline: us policing is far less about fighting crime than controlling the poor | kenan malik
standfirst: Creeping militarisation has made it ever easier to oppress – and kill – those like George Floyd
lead_paragraph: ‘lower-class culture is pathological.” so claimed american political scientist edward banfield in his 1970 book m>the unheavenly citym>. for banfield, unlike the middle class, “the lower-class person lives from moment to moment… unable or unwilling to take account of the future or control his impulses”. poverty was the product of people “not troubled by dirt and dilapidation” or by “the inadequacy of public facilities such as schools, parks, hospitals and libraries”.

headline: sky aims for one in five staff from minority backgrounds by 2025
standfirst: UK broadcaster aims to reshape its workforce, partly in response to Black Lives Matter movement
lead_paragraph: sky has pledged that one in five of its staff will be from a minority ethnic background by 2025, under a new recruitment target that could lead to 1,500 more black, asian and minority ethnic workers being hired.

headline: priti patel describes black lives matter protests as 'dreadful'
standfirst: UK home secretary says she disagreed with last year’s protests as well as taking the knee
lead_paragraph: the home secretary, priti patel, has described the black lives matter protests that swept the uk last year as “dreadful” and said she did not agree with the gesture of taking the knee.

headline: on my radar: claudia rankine’s cultural highlights
standfirst: The poet and playwright on her love of The White Lotus, the example of Naomi Osaka, and what stayed with her from the George Floyd murder trial
lead_paragraph: claudia rankine is a poet, essayist, playwright and a professor of poetry at yale. born in jamaica in 1963, she moved to america as a child and later received an mfa from columbia university. she is the author of six books of poetry, including m> citizen: an american lyricm>  (2014), which won numerous prizes including a national book critics circle award. rankine lives in new haven, connecticut with her husband, the film-maker john lucas, and their daughter. her latest book, m>just us: an american conversationm>, which interrogates race in the us through a series of conversations, is out in paperback on 2 september.

headline: whole foods managers told to talk up donations while enforcing blm ban
standfirst: The grocery chain’s dress code bans political slogans, including for Black Lives Matter, but it wants to stress parent Amazon’s support for social justice groups
lead_paragraph: whole foods is advising managers to “talk about donations” the supermarket chain and its parent amazon have given to various social justice groups while enforcing dress code policies that ban black lives matter slogans on uniforms or face masks, according to internal documents obtained by the guardian.

headline: parents back call by uk teacher to help end 'white supremacy'
standfirst: A headteacher has won wide support for anti-racist drive in wake of George Floyd killingl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: a primary school headteacher says he has been “overwhelmed by support” after calling on parents to help tackle structural racism.

headline: netherlands museum exhibition to tell story of dutch slave trade
standfirst: ‘Black Lives Matter shows urgency that subject is addressed,’ says Rijksmuseum director
lead_paragraph: the netherlands’ national art institution, the rijksmuseum, is to open its first major exhibition telling the stories of slaves and the dutch people who enslaved them, as its director backs a government initiative to return thousands of looted treasures to former colonial lands.

headline: yg, che lingo, kendrick lamar: the protest songs of black lives matter 2020
standfirst: The demonstrations against the killing of George Floyd have brought a wave of powerful protest music, with new tracks and revisited classics
lead_paragraph: the slow and inhumane killing of george floyd, coupled with the frustration of lockdown and mass unemployment, have created the conditions necessary for mass protest and – hopefully, finally – change.

headline: george floyd should be alive today | nicholas russell
standfirst: Floyd is no martyr. To speak of him as such is a hollow kind of myth-making. No, if justice were true, he would simply be
lead_paragraph: tuesday’s pageantry surrounding the verdict of derek chauvin’s trial felt like a looming hand coming down to put placating pressure on the masses like a weighted blanket. there’s little to say that can be considered truly revelatory, other than to be explicit about how perverse and orchestrated these events feel. the hours before the verdict consisted of filler dispatches from every news outlet. here’s what we know so far. what you need to know. minutes to go. the likelihood of a conviction. what makes this trial different. how ubiquitous surveillance, not fervent, sustained protest, made it possible. testimony from black journalists. the understanding that even more psychic weight would be placed on to them in the coming days, no matter the outcome. all of this solemnly, respectfully delivered, with similar sentiments echoed on social media, yet still the anticipation generated was closer to that of a major sports event. writer and comedian natasha rothwell touched on a bleak, crushing irony when she tweeted: “can’t wait to find out if my life matters! 🙏🏾🤞🏾🙏🏾 .”

headline: budapest black lives matter artwork sparks rightwing backlash
standfirst: Officials from Viktor Orbán’s rightwing party stoke outrage over two-week installation
lead_paragraph: it will be only one metre high, and will be on display for just two weeks. nevertheless, a planned art installation dedicated to the theme of black lives matter is causing uproar in budapest, where the rightwing, nationalist government of viktor orbán has taken aim at the movement and all it represents.

headline: derek chauvin trial: jury begins deliberations over killing of george floyd – as it happened
standfirst: l>i>Prosecution says George Floyd is dead ‘because Chauvin’s heart is too small’i>i>Prosecution and defense make closing argumentsi>i>Former police officer charged with murder over death of George Floydr>i>i> Protests flare as America awaits verdict in Derek Chauvin triali>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2021-04-19t23:55:30.475z">12.55am pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: ‘enough of the senseless killings’: biden calls chauvin verdict ‘a start’ as democrats demand action
standfirst: Lawmakers echo Kamala Harris’s call for passage of George Floyd Justice in Policing Act
lead_paragraph: addressing the nation on tuesday evening, joe biden said the  guilty verdict for the former minneapolis police office derek chauvin was “a start”. but, he said, “in order to deliver real change and reform, we can and we must do more”.

headline: black lives matter, grandma and me: how our world changed during lockdown
standfirst: After months apart, Jade Bentil was reunited with her grandmother, in time to see the BLM protests unfold. She reflects on a history of repression
lead_paragraph: it is saturday 13 june 2020 and the world is on fire. i’m sitting with my grandma, esther, in her living room in south london for the first time in three months. she’s reclining in her favourite chair, occasionally sitting up to gesticulate at the tv and pepper the air with comments as we watch the 24-hour newsreel. the scene is achingly familiar; we have sat together in this way, usually with my mum, every year since my grandma was the first person to hold me in her arms in the wake of my arrival into this world, in november 1992. yet, even while this moment is comforting in its familiarity, there is also something wholly unprecedented about the afternoon, as we watch the images flicker before our eyes.

headline: ‘now is the time’: london’s black lives matter rally looks like a turning point
standfirst: Many of those protesting about George Floyd’s death believe demands for racial justice now have a new and unstoppable urgencyl>i> George Floyd killing: latest updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: it was always likely that the months of lockdown would demand some kind of emotional catharsis. you imagined it would involve the usual british excesses of lager and sunshine. in fact, in the past week its primary expression has been a coming together of mostly young people in our cities under the banner of  black lives matter.

headline: ‘they wanted to kill me’: the lawyer taking on police brutality in kenya
standfirst: Almost 20 years ago, a police shooting left David Makara without an arm and facing jail. Inspired by the blind lawyer who saved him, he now defends others facing injustice
lead_paragraph: when the police started shooting at david makara in his home town of nyahururu, in kenya, he ran before quickly collapsing. two bullets had hit him – one in his right arm, one in his hip – but he only realised when he looked down and saw his hand dangling from his wrist and blood pouring out.

headline: black lives matter meets animal crossing: how protesters take their activism into video games
standfirst: In the Covid-19 age, protestors are finding novel ways to express themselves, from BLM rallies in The Sims to Hong Kong protests in Animal Crossing
lead_paragraph: as street protests against anti-black racism erupted across the globe, animal crossing: new horizons players were taking their own stand.  adelle, a software engineer from new york, decided to create a memorial on her in-game island, decorated with flowers and pixel art portraits of  george floyd, breonna taylor and other black victims of police brutality.

headline: on these grounds: a shocking film about police brutality within us schools
standfirst: In a new documentary, the story of a 16-year-old Black student who was assaulted by a white police officer exposes a broken system
lead_paragraph: in on these grounds, an expansive, insightful and infuriating documentary about police brutality in the public education system, former school resource officer ben fields makes his case. fields, a hulking and defensive white cop, meekly looks at the camera, clinically explaining away his actions when confronting a 16-year-old black student identified as shakara at spring valley high in south carolina. the violent incident caught on multiple videos  immediately went viral and led to his dismissal.

headline: maga v blm: how police handled the capitol mob and george floyd activists – in pictures
standfirst: Wednesday saw a thin deployment of officers as rioters stormed the Capitol. In June, a very different scene unfolded in the same city
lead_paragraph: the contrast between the law enforcement reaction to the storming of the capitol on wednesday and the suppression of peaceful protests in the summer is not just stark – it is black and white.

headline: 'blue lives matter': ex-yankee damon cites support for trump during dui arrest
standfirst: l>i>Former MLB star suggests he is targeted for political viewsi>i>47-year-old arrested near home in Windermere, Floridai>l>
lead_paragraph: two-time world series champion johnny damon suggested he has been targeted for his political views during video of his arrest for dui.

headline: amnesty condemns colombia police brutality after scores of protesters killed
standfirst: ‘He died as he lived, resisting’, says mother of young artist killed in Cali, as report claims authorities used systematic ‘pattern of violence’ in city
lead_paragraph: nicolás guerrero, a 26-year-old artist from the colombian city of cali, took to the streets on 2 may to protest against the lack of opportunities he saw in his country. he had a family in spain that he had hoped one day to bring to south america. but later that night, after riot police launched a brutal crackdown, he was found lying on the pavement, seriously wounded. he died hours later in hospital.

headline: trump to hold first rally in months in tulsa, a city with history of deadly racial violence – as it happened
standfirst: l>i>Trump to hold rally in Tulsa, Oklahoma, next week on Juneteenth, day commemorating end of slaveryi>i> Philonise Floyd participates in hearing on police brutalityi>i> Minneapolis police chief withdrawing from contract negotiationsi>i> White House press secretary defends Trump’s conspiracy theory tweeti>i> After 15 days of protests … what happens next?i>i>Sign up to our  First Thing newsletterr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2020-06-11t01:43:41.602z">2.43am pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: education department to review english schools guidance on anti-capitalist groups
standfirst: Campaigners threaten legal action over attempt to ban material from groups including Black Lives Matter
lead_paragraph: guidance warning schools against using resources from organisations that have expressed a desire to end capitalism will be reviewed by the department for education (dfe) following the threat of legal action.

headline: tearful testimony and defense’s own goal: key moments in the chauvin trial
standfirst: Derek Chauvin’s trial for the killing of George Floyd has cast a spotlight on racist policing
lead_paragraph: the trial of the white former police officer derek chauvin for the killing of george floyd has been one of the most high-profile cases in america’s recent history and cast a spotlight on racist policing in the united states.

headline: ‘my brother got justice’: george floyd’s family praises guilty verdict
standfirst: Members of Floyd’s family have become leaders in the movement sparked by his deathl>i> Derek Chauvin guilty verdict – follow live updatesi>i> Life of George Floyd: ‘He knew how to make people feel better’i>l>
lead_paragraph: latonya floyd watched in anxious silence, her hands pressed together in front of her face, as the judge prepared to read the verdict in the trial of the former minneapolis police officer who had killed her brother last year.

headline: 'it gives me hope': guardian readers on why they joined us racism protests
standfirst: Across the country people have taken to the streets en masse in response to the police killing of George Floydl>i> Latest on Black Lives Matter protestsi>l>
lead_paragraph: as protests continue throughout the us in reaction to the death of george floyd, the african american man who died under the knee of a white police officer in minneapolis, the guardian has spoken to readers about why they have taken part in demonstrations – and what needs to change.

headline: australia's acting pm says capitol attack 'unfortunate' and condemns twitter 'censorship' of trump
standfirst: Michael McCormack attempts to draw comparisons between deadly storming of building and last year’s Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: australia’s acting prime minister, michael mccormack, has described donald trump’s refusal to concede defeat in the presidential election, his inflammatory tweets and the deadly storming of the us capitol building by rioters as “unfortunate”.

headline: trump's hollywood walk of fame star defaced in support of black lives matter
standfirst: The reality TV host turned US president’s star has been spray painted black and tagged with BLM
lead_paragraph: donald trump’s star on the hollywood walk of fame has been defaced yet again, this time in support of the black lives matter movement.

headline: george floyd killing sparks protests across us: at a glance guide
standfirst: A summary of the widespread demonstrations against police brutality, from Detroit to Washington
lead_paragraph: protests against police brutality have spread across the us overnight and into saturday morning. here are the key developments:

headline: simon & schuster refuses to distribute book by officer who shot breonna taylor
standfirst: US publishing giant was due to distribute Jonathan Mattingly’s The Fight for Truth for rightwing outlet Post Hill Pressr>
lead_paragraph: simon & schuster has said that it will not be distributing a book by one of the police officers who shot breonna taylor, after a small publisher whose books are distributed through s&s announced the book to widespread criticism.

headline: back to black: how the music industry reckoned with race this year
standfirst: Black Lives Matter sparked overdue changes – but if deeper prejudices go unaddressed, they could be all too fleeting
lead_paragraph: “in the wake of george floyd” is a sentence i have both read and written too many times this year. his brutal and racist killing forced an elevated conscience across every industry: suddenly, organisations cared about black lives and everyone wanted to amplify black voices.

headline: opal tometi, co-founder of black lives matter: 'i do this because we deserve to live'
standfirst: Seven years ago Tometi helped to create what is possibly the biggest protest movement in US history. She explains what the critics of BLM get wrong, how her family’s story made her an activist and why she is certain the movement will succeed
lead_paragraph: maybe opal tometi is not the image of a great us civil rights leader that lives in your head. for a start, she is not an austere man in a dark suit, but a 36-year-old woman in pilates gear, who laughs often and generously. she doesn’t need the sonorous tones of a southern baptist preacher to make her point – she has social media – and with nigerian-born parents her ancestors were not among those enslaved and transported across the atlantic several centuries ago. yet, as one of the three founders of black lives matter, opal tometi has helped to reignite the civil rights movement.

headline: ‘guilty, guilty, guilty’: world’s media react to chauvin trial verdict
standfirst: Analysis: relief and reflection sweep newsrooms as George Floyd case points to ‘turning point’ in US race relations
lead_paragraph: with intense international interest in the  us trial of former police officer derek chauvin for the murder of george floyd, news organisations around the world had been live blogging the proceedings and were quick to reflect the ruling by the jury.

headline: talawa theatre company: 'it's time to double down on black lives matter pledges'
standfirst: The minds behind Britain’s oldest black theatre group discuss pulling out of Birmingham Rep when it became a Nightingale court – and their plans to conquer the West End
lead_paragraph: britain’s oldest black theatre company,  talawa, is plotting its 35th-anniversary celebrations and hopes to go big. it might have gone bigger, had its plans to stage an ambitious season of works not been aborted late last year. michael buffong, its artistic director, had programmed black joy at birmingham rep for this autumn,trong> trong>which “was supposed to present a step change” in its scale and ambition.

headline: kyle rittenhouse verdict declares open hunting season on progressive protesters | cas mudde
standfirst: Demonstrators in the US must fear not only police brutality but also rightwing vigilantesl>i> Kyle Rittenhouse acquittal: follow the latesti>l>
lead_paragraph: kyle rittenhouse – the armed white teenager who traveled from illinois to wisconsin to allegedly “protect” local businesses from anti-racism protesters in kenosha, whereupon he shot and killed two people and injured another – has been  acquitted of all charges. i don’t think anyone who has followed the trial even casually will be surprised by this verdict. after the various antics by the elected  judge, which seemed to indicate where his sympathies lay, and the fact that  the prosecution asked the jurors to consider charges lesser than murder, the writing was on the wall.

headline: chauvin trial: prosecution quizzes defense witness over carbon monoxide claim – as it happened
standfirst: l>i>Forensic pathologist David Fowler testifies for Chauvin defensei>i> Criminal complaint set to be filed Wednesday against Kim Potteri>i> George Floyd and Daunte Wright families join together in griefr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2021-04-14t21:33:05.764z">10.33pm pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: george floyd memorials vandalised in new york and new jersey
standfirst: • Statues daubed with reference to far-right hate group• Attacks come on eve of sentencing of Derek Chauvin for murder
lead_paragraph: supporters of a white nationalist hate group defaced brand-new memorials to george floyd in new york and new jersey this week, even as the nation  awaits a sentence for floyd’s murderer.

headline: rayshard brooks family call for murder charges after police killing
standfirst: l>i>Widow Tomika Miller: ‘I can never get my best friend back’i>i>Brooks, an African American, was shot by white Atlanta officeri>i> Black Lives Matter protests continue – US politics livei>l>
lead_paragraph: the family of rayshard brooks, an unarmed black man who was shot twice in the back by a white atlanta police officer on friday after he fell asleep in his car, have called for murder charges and a radical overhaul of the city’s police department.

headline: woman charged after allegedly driving car into crowd of new york protesters
standfirst: Police say six people were injured when a car plowed into Black Lives Matter demonstrators in Manhattan
lead_paragraph: one woman was arrested after allegedly  driving her car into a crowd of black lives matter protesters in manhattan friday afternoon, injuring six, the new york police department (nypd) said.

headline: derek chauvin trial: defence opens its case with ex-police officer
standfirst: Defence attempts to show George Floyd had history of failing to cooperate but he comes across as frightened in videol>i> Chauvin trial – live coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the defence in the derek chauvin murder trial  opened its case on tuesday by attempting to show george floyd had a history of failing to cooperate with the police while under the influence of drugs.

headline: today’s verdict isn’t ‘justice’. but accountability is a first step to justice | keith ellison
standfirst: In a short speech following the George Floyd verdict, Minnesota attorney general Keith Ellison distinguished between the conceptsr>
lead_paragraph: m>in a press conference following the news that a jury had  found the former police officer derek chauvin guilty on multiple counts of the murder of george floyd, minnesota’s attorney general, keith ellison, delivered a short but powerful statement.m>

headline: marie stopes charity changes name in break with campaigner's view on eugenics
standfirst: Organisation says Black Lives Matter movement reaffirmed commitment to changing name to MSI Reproductive Choices
lead_paragraph: marie stopes international (msi) is to change its name in an attempt to break its association with the family planning pioneer.

headline: derek chauvin found guilty of murder of george floyd
standfirst: l>i>Jury finds ex-Minneapolis police officer guilty on all countsi>i>Chauvin knelt on Floyd’s neck for more than nine minutesi>i> Derek Chauvin guilty verdict – follow live updatesi>i> Life of George Floyd: ‘He knew how to make people feel better’i>l>
lead_paragraph: derek chauvin has been  convicted of murder for killing george floyd by kneeling on his neck for more than nine minutes, a crime that prompted waves of protests in support of racial justice in the us and across the world.

headline: derek chauvin trial: what we've learned after the first week
standfirst: Chauvin kept his knee on George Floyd longer than originally thought and witnesses described feelings of guilt
lead_paragraph: the trial against derek chauvin, the white former police officer charged with murdering  george floyd in minneapolis last may,  began in earnest on monday and lasted all week.

headline: ‘imperially nostalgic racists’ target empireland author with hate mail
standfirst: Sathnam Sanghera speaks out against ‘vicious’ abuse he is receiving over his bestselling book: ‘Empire has been weaponised by the right wing, ever since Black Lives Matter’r>
lead_paragraph: sathnam sanghera’s empireland, a journey through britain’s imperial past, has been a bestseller since it was pubished last month, acclaimed by critics as “unflinching … moving and stimulating”  (the guardian), and “excellent” and “balanced” (the sunday times). and yet, from the british public the author has received handwritten hate mail, and thousands of abusive tweets from  “imperially nostalgic racists”, as he succinctly replied, some of them verging, he says, on death threats.

headline: hundreds join minneapolis high school walkouts: ‘police don’t care about us’
standfirst: Teens gather in Twin Cities to condemn the killings of Daunte Wright and George Floyd as Chauvin trial continues
lead_paragraph: “national guard, go home!” hundreds of teenagers chanted in a heavily fortified  minneapolis on monday, as part of statewide high school walkouts over the police killings of daunte wright and george floyd.

headline: wednesday briefing: day of justice for george floyd
standfirst: Former police officer Derek Chauvin convicted of murder … ESL relegated to history … and will we ever wash properly again?
lead_paragraph: hello, warren murray with news of justice served.

headline: black lives matter uk to give £600,000 in funding to campaign groups
standfirst: Recipients include groups that organised last summer’s anti-racism protests
lead_paragraph: black lives matter uk has announced it is giving £600,000 in funding to grassroots groups across the country, including those that organised last summer’s anti-racism protests.

headline: nelson, blm and new voices: why barbados is ditching the queen
standfirst: Michael Safi reports from the ground as island nation prepares to declare itself a republic
lead_paragraph: the first time, he stumbled on it by accident, after following a dirt track through fields of sugar cane that came to a clearing. there was a sign, hakeem ward remembers, beneath which someone had left an offering.

headline: biden to meet with george floyd family but miss police reform deadline
standfirst: President wanted George Floyd Justice in Policing Act passed by 25 May, on anniversary of police killing but bill is stalled in the Senate
lead_paragraph: joe biden will on tuesday meet the family of george floyd on the first anniversary of his murder by police in minneapolis – but miss his own deadline for police reform to address racial injustice.

headline: la protester accuses uncle, an lapd officer, of ordering projectiles fired on him
standfirst: Asim Jamal Shakir Jr is suing the Los Angeles police department after he was injured during a George Floyd demonstration last May
lead_paragraph: a 23-year-old los angeles film-maker has sued the los angeles police department, alleging that his uncle, a los angeles police department officer, ordered him to be shot by projectiles during the george floyd protests last summer.

headline: ‘i had a big gasp’: george floyd jurors speak on the trial, the video and the verdict
standfirst: In a CNN interview, seven jurors reflect on the trauma of seeing the cellphone recording and how they arrived at their decision
lead_paragraph: jurors in the landmark george floyd murder trial spoke about the life-altering case and how the experience still affects them, in an interview  with cnn on thursday.

headline: fauci says white house's 'bizarre' attacks on him damage trump – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> Trump chastises Peter Navarro’s op-ed criticizing Faucir>i>i> Oklahoma governor Kevin Stitt tests positive for Covid-19i>i> US again sees record-high number of new coronavirus casesr>i>i> Media banned from publishing new bodycam video of two officers involved in George Floyd deathr>i>i> Trump’s niece says president is dangerous and calls on him to resigni>i>Sign up to our  First Thing newsletteri>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2020-07-16t00:37:26.785z">1.37am pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: tell us: are you attending a uk vigil to mark the anniversary of george floyd’s death?
standfirst: We would like to hear from people who plan to attend a vigil to commemorate the first anniversary of the murder of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: vigils are to be held across the uk to mark the one-year anniversary of the murder of george floyd, who died in minneapolis, minnesota on 25 may last year after a white police officer derek chauvin knelt on his neck for more than nine minutes.

headline: hundreds march in sydney to protest against indigenous deaths and george floyd killing
standfirst: Protesters call on Australian media to cover police brutality in Australia as well as overseas
lead_paragraph: hundreds of people marched through sydney on tuesday, chanting “black lives matter” and protesting against indigenous deaths in custody in australia and the killing of george floyd in the united states.

headline: blm gives cautious welcome to queen’s reported backing
standfirst: Anti-racism movement says ‘actions speak louder than words’ after comments attributing royal assent
lead_paragraph: black lives matter uk has expressed surprise after  the queen and the royal family were said to support its cause, but the anti-racism movement stressed that “actions speak louder than words”.

headline: minneapolis removes barricades to reopen george floyd square to traffic
standfirst: Community members had turned the intersection where Floyd was murdered into a public mourning space
lead_paragraph: parts of the memorial space constructed at the south minneapolis intersection where george floyd was murdered by a white police officer were removed by work crews on thursday morning.

headline: enrique tarrio, leader of rightwing proud boys, arrested ahead of rallies
standfirst: He was charged with destruction of property – related to his role in burning a Black Lives Matter banner – and a firearms offense
lead_paragraph: the leader of the proud boys, the violent far-right group, was arrested in washington dc and charged with destruction of property and a firearms offense, according to local police.

headline: billie eilish, jay-z and more voice solidarity with george floyd protesters
standfirst: Rappers Travis Scott and Gunna join pop singers including Halsey and Ariana Grande in condemning police brutality
lead_paragraph: stars from across the pop music spectrum, including billie eilish, adele, jay-z, ariana grande and more have used their sizeable platforms to support protesters and condemn police brutality, in the wake of the  killing of george floyd and other black americans.

headline: chauvin's use of force on george floyd was 'in no way' policy, says police chief
standfirst: Medaria Arradondo says on sixth day of trial that ex-officer’s treatment of George Floyd breached regulationsl>i> Derek Chauvin trial – live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: the minneapolis police chief, medaria arradondo, told the derek chauvin murder trial on monday that he “vehemently disagrees” that there was any justification for the former police officer to keep his knee on george floyd’s neck for more than nine minutes.

headline: the george floyd protests are a rebellion against an unjust system | philip v mcharris
standfirst: Police brutality, white vigilantism and poverty – not property damage - are the true violence l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: rebellion is etched  into american, and human, history. when people are systematically beaten, killed and not given the resources to thrive, rebellion becomes inevitable. it serves as a human response to conditions that become so untenable that rising up becomes instinctual, despite the consequences. social transformation has long been forged in the ashes of rebellion, though today rebellion is only acknowledged as a potent tool in retrospect.

headline: tech platforms vowed to address racial equity: how have they fared?
standfirst: Facebook, Twitter, YouTube, Google and Amazon issued statements in response to Black Lives Matter this year but did they follow through?
lead_paragraph: following the death of george floyd and nationwide protests against police brutality and racial inequality,  some of the largest technology corporations waded into the anti-racism movement with slickly worded corporate declarations that “black lives matter”.

headline: boris johnson 'stoking fear and division' ahead of blm protests
standfirst: Critics say PM’s claim that George Floyd protests ‘hijacked by extremists’ is dangerousr>
lead_paragraph: boris johnson was accused of “stoking fear and division” ahead of a weekend of black lives matter demonstrations after he unequivocally condemned the removal of historic statues and claimed the protests had been “hijacked by extremists intent on violence”.

headline: to win justice for george floyd, we need the rage that abolished slavery | jericho brown
standfirst: The protesters on America’s streets know the truth about police brutality, and they’re marching for radical change
lead_paragraph: if you live in the united states, everything you have is the result of, or in spite of, violence. as a matter of fact, any history we learn in our schools about our nation is a catalogue of murderous events told in such rapid succession that by the time we graduate from high school we are numb enough to believe that state-sanctioned brutality is not just normal but, worse, moral.

headline: black lives matter uk to start funding groups from £1.2m donations
standfirst: More than £100,000 will be released in January to black-led organisations across country
lead_paragraph: black lives matter uk will be releasing more than £100,000 to black-led organisations across the country by the end of the month, as protesters pledge to build on last year’s anti-racism demonstrations.

headline: 'believe your eyes, it’s a homicide': key quotes from day one of the chauvin trial
standfirst: Prosecutor says ex-officer betrayed police principles in killing of George Floyd while defense argues Chauvin followed his training
lead_paragraph: opening arguments got under way on monday morning in the trial of the white former police officer derek chauvin, charged with the murder of george floyd, a black man, in minneapolis last may, after chauvin kneeled on his neck during an arrest.

headline: blackout tuesday: black squares dominate social media and spark debate
standfirst: Millions post black squares in solidarity with fight for racial justice after George Floyd death, while others say it’s reductivel>i> George Floyd protests: latest developmentsi>l>
lead_paragraph: the protest movement sparked by the death in police custody of george floyd in minneapolis spread from the music business to social media on tuesday as major institutions around the world posted black squares and stopped online activity in solidarity.

headline: colston statue ‘cast a shadow’ over bristol, court hears in blm protest trial
standfirst: Defence says memorial to slave trader toppled last June was ‘indecent and threatening’ to city’s black community
lead_paragraph: the statue of edward colston in bristol was “a monument to racism”, a court has heard, as a defendant described the moment he gave the signal to topple the memorial to the slave trader.

headline: recording reveals police efforts to recruit blm activist as informant
standfirst: Swansea activist Lowri Davies recorded call from officer in ‘frightening and distressing’ attempted recruitment
lead_paragraph: a secret recording has revealed how a covert police unit in wales tried to recruit a black lives matter activist to be an informant.

headline: new york makes complaint records of 83,000 police officers available to public
standfirst: Files made public as part of a national push for greater police transparency following the death of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: the complaint records of 83,000 active and former new york city police officers have been added to a searchable public database justice advocates hope will help citizens and activists identify problem officers and trends in police abuse.

headline: pulitzer board honors darnella frazier for her ‘courageous’ george floyd video
standfirst: Her video documenting the murder of a Black man at the hands of a white police officer helped galvanize a global movement
lead_paragraph: the teenager whose video documenting the murder of george floyd helped galvanize a global movement over racial injustice was awarded a special citation by the pulitzer prizes board.

headline: stephen colbert on derek chauvin guilty verdict: ‘more work to be done’
standfirst: Late-night hosts react to Minneapolis jurors finding Chauvin guilty of murdering George Floyd and observe the holiday known as 4/20
lead_paragraph: “just before the taping of our show today the verdict was announced in the trial of derek chauvin,” said stephen colbert on tuesday evening.” around 5pm et that afternoon, a minneapolis jury found the officer who kneeled on george floyd’s neck for over nine minutes  guilty on all three counts against him: second- and third-degree murder, and manslaughter.

headline: families call for un to launch inquiry into police killings of black americans
standfirst: Relatives of 165 victims of police brutality backed by ACLU and 250 groups worldwide write to UN commissioner for human rights
lead_paragraph: the families of 165 victims of police brutality in the us are calling on the united nations to set up an independent inquiry into the ongoing scourge of police killings of black men and women.

headline: virginia police officer fired after donating to kyle rittenhouse fundraiser
standfirst: The Guardian reported lieutenant donated $25 to teenager accused of killing two people during police brutality protest last August
lead_paragraph: the virginia city of norfolk has fired a police lieutenant after the guardian  reported that he donated to and expressed support for kyle rittenhouse, the teenager accused of killing two people during a police brutality protest in wisconsin last summer.

headline: george floyd and the need for uk police reform | letters
standfirst: trong>Stephen Black trong>on why the police complaints system needs to change fundamentally and trong>Ruth Baker trong>on how a video by a 17-year-old was crucial to the case
lead_paragraph: while the guilty verdict in the george floyd case is to be welcomed, we are very far from the culture change required if policing with consent is to become a reality ( href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/apr/20/derek-chauvin-verdict-guilty-murder-george-floyd" title="">derek chauvin found guilty of murder of george floyd, 21 april). in numerous incidents in the us and the uk, overzealous actions of the police have been captured for all to see, but have you ever seen or heard a fellow officer intervening or condemning them? in the george floyd incident, two other officers did not regard the restraint as unlawful and made little attempt to prevent or advise their fellow officer.

headline: crimes linked to race and religion rise in england and wales
standfirst: Black Lives Matter and far-right counter-protests contribute to increase, says Home Office
lead_paragraph: the number of racially or religiously aggravated offences in england and wales rose in june and july, most likely linked to black lives matters rallies and far-right counter-protests, the home office has said.

headline: ultraviolence review – still no justice in follow-up doc on deaths in uk police custody
standfirst: Ken Fero’s grim update to his fearless 2001 documentary Injustice, about police brutality against black men, is a shocking case of more of the same
lead_paragraph: twenty years in the making, ken fero’s ultraviolence is the follow-up to  injustice from 2001, a documentary that is the most important british nonfiction film of my professional lifetime: a radical, passionate work about the ongoing scandal and tragedy of deaths in uk police custody, largely of black men. that film challenged the consensus and earned fero and his co-director tariq mehmood nothing but obstruction from the authorities. the police federation threatened him with writs and the terrestrial broadcasters nervously shied away.

headline: most charges against george floyd protesters dropped, analysis shows
standfirst: Some prosecutors and law enforcement observers say departments carried out mass arrests as crowd control tactic
lead_paragraph: the vast majority of citations and charges against george floyd protesters were ultimately dropped, dismissed or otherwise not filed, according to a guardian analysis of law enforcement records and media reports in a dozen jurisdictions around the nation.

headline: sasha johnson shooting: second teenager charged
standfirst: Devonte Brown, 18, of Southwark, charged with conspiracy to murder over shooting of BLM activist
lead_paragraph: a second teenager has been charged with conspiracy to murder over the shooting of the black lives matter activist sasha johnson, the metropolitan police said.

headline: thousands gather in britain to support us george floyd protests
standfirst: Anti-racism demonstrators defy lockdown in London, Cardiff and Manchesterl>i> George Floyd protests - live newsi>l>
lead_paragraph: protesters in london, cardiff and manchester gathered on sunday in solidarity with demonstrations in the united states that were sparked by the death of  george floyd.

headline: breonna taylor died more than a year ago. but us policing has barely changed | akin olla
standfirst: Thousands of protesters were arrested last year. Some face harsher punishments than the officers who killed Taylor
lead_paragraph: it has been over a year since breonna taylor, a 26-year-old er technician, was killed by police officers in her home. it has been nearly a year since george floyd, a former rapper and father of five, was killed by officer derek chauvin in broad daylight. and it has been some 300 days since the subsequent uprisings in their names. thousands of protesters were arrested, and while the vast majority have had their flimsy charges dropped, there are many still facing harsher punishments than the officers who killed taylor face. there is legislation being passed in the name of the slain and a handful of cities have made modest cuts to police budgets due to the  hard work of local organizations. at the same time, many local governments have doubled down on their support for violent policing, and the system that necessitated a movement to defund the police remains pretty much entirely intact and murderous.

headline: 'everything is riding on the outcome': minneapolis braces for chauvin trial
standfirst: Prosecutors due to set out their case in heavily fortified building for trial of ex-officer charged with murdering George Floyd
lead_paragraph: the city of minneapolis and millions across the us and around the world are bracing for monday’s opening arguments in the trial of derek chauvin, the white former police officer charged with murdering george floyd, who was black, in the city last may.

headline: white people, black authors are not your medicine | yaa gyasi
standfirst: When Yaa Gyasi’s book rocketed up the charts after last year’s Black Lives Matter protests, she grieved. Treating authors of colour as tools for self-improvement is an impoverished response to centuries of harm
lead_paragraph: in 2018, two other novelists and i were being driven back from a reception in grosse pointe, michigan, to our hotel in downtown detroit, when we saw a black man getting arrested on the side of the road. the driver of our car, a white woman who had spent the earlier part of the drive ranting about how  coleman young, detroit’s first black mayor, had ruined the city, looked at the lone black man surrounded by police officers with their guns drawn and said: “it’s good they’ve got so many on him. you never know what they’ll do.”

headline: the chauvin verdict is a step in the right direction. but there is much work to do | rev al sharpton
standfirst: Eleven months ago, I delivered the eulogy for George Floyd. It grieves me that I am returning to do the same for Daunte Wright
lead_paragraph: the entire world was on edge, patiently waiting for the verdict in the trial of former police officer derek chauvin. on tuesday, the jury returned a guilty verdict on all three counts after deliberating for about 10 hours over two days. chauvin was convicted of second- and third-degree murder, as well as second-degree manslaughter in the death of george floyd.

headline: lizzo and lil nas x criticise blackout tuesday for obscuring protests
standfirst: Musicians lead call for constructive response to share helpful information among those moved by George Floyd death, rather than posting millions of black squaresl>i> George Floyd protests: latest developmentsi>l>
lead_paragraph: lizzo and  lil nas x have condemned a music industry-sponsored social media movement to suspend business activities in support of global protests sparked by the death in police custody of  george floyd in minneapolis.

headline: george floyd killing: defense rests case after derek chauvin declines to testify
standfirst: Both sides will make closing arguments on Monday and the case over the death of George Floyd will then go to the jury
lead_paragraph: derek chauvin declined to testify in his murder trial over the killing of george floyd as the defence wrapped up its case after just two days of testimony.

headline: sons of kemet: black to the future review – an eloquent dance between anger and joy
standfirst: (Impulse!)r>Shabaka Hutchings and co’s urgent fourth album, much of it recorded after the murder of George Floyd, nevertheless lifts the spirits and feeds the soul
lead_paragraph: jazz is most often a collegial endeavour, but it has a star system too. it’s hard to overstate the significance of sons of kemet’s  shabaka hutchings, a saxophonist whose relentless energy and pioneering spirit have been key to the development of the british jazz scene over the past decade.

headline: ‘they kill the person twice’: police spread falsehoods after using deadly force, analysis finds
standfirst: trong>A review of California cases shows that law enforcement frequently publish highly misleading information about people they’ve killed – just like the first George Floyd press releasetrong>
lead_paragraph: on the day of george floyd’s killing, minneapolis police published a short  press release titled “man dies after medical incident during police interaction”.

headline: seth meyers: chauvin conviction ‘does not mean justice was done’
standfirst: Late-night hosts continue to process the conviction of Derek Chauvin for the murder of George Floyd and talk marijuana legalization and Matt Gaetz
lead_paragraph: on wednesday night, seth meyers offer chastened relief at the  conviction of minneapolis police officer derek chauvin for the murder of  george floyd. “in many ways, the most powerful evidence in this case has been right there in front of us since the video first emerged,” the late night host said. “it’s what we saw with our own eyes.”

standfirst: People gather at one of several events planned nationwide to mark year since Floyd’s death. Plus, US joins global outcry over Belarus ‘hijacking’ of plane
lead_paragraph: good morning,

standfirst: l>i> Medical examiner Dr Andrew Baker says he found no damage to Floyd’s hearti>i> Dr Lindsey Thomas says ‘primary mechanism of death is asphyxia or low oxygen’r>i>i>Murder trial enters 10th day of witness testimony in Minneapolisi>i> Lung expert: George Floyd died from lack of oxygen caused by restrainti>l>

headline: 'we weren't intimidated': a diary of cori bush's first two weeks in the house
standfirst: The freshman congresswoman talks about what it was like to be in the Capitol during the attack, getting booed for denouncing white supremacy, and the Republicans who mistook her for Breonna Taylor
lead_paragraph: the first two weeks of cori bush’s freshman week in congress couldn’t have been more turbulent. three days after the missouri representative was sworn in, the capitol was stormed by white supremacists looking to overturn the election. she gave  her first criticisms of the biden administration, saw her twitter following grow by 185,000 and, last but not least, voted to impeach the president. and she did all of it without a paycheck, as one of the very few representatives that was  neither a millionaire nor a  career politician before joining the house of representatives.

headline: chauvin trial: vivid testimony and focus on deadly force in dramatic first week
standfirst: The ex-officer’s trial has seen witnesses offering personal and raw accounts of their experiences from the day George Floyd was killed
lead_paragraph: the murder trial of derek chauvin, which concluded its first week of testimony on friday, saw a wave of witnesses come before the jury, with many offering deeply personal and vivid accounts of their experiences on 25 may last year.

headline: naga munchetty: 'my most memorable interviewee of the year? a nurse'
standfirst: The broadcaster on her small-screen loves and hates of 2020, and her experience covering the pandemic and the Black Lives Matter movement on the BBC
lead_paragraph: trong>have you been watching much tv away from news this year, and do you in general? r/>trong>well, i don’t usually watch too much tv. my thing was always going out, playing golf and running, and the tv was on in the background. i work in television, and sometimes you need a break. but that has all changed. i’ve watched a lot in lockdown.

headline: mi5 boss says russian and chinese threats to uk 'growing in severity'
standfirst: Ken McCallum also pledges to boost diversity in the service as response to Black Lives Matter movement
lead_paragraph: mi5’s new boss has said the spy threats posed by china and russia to the uk are “growing in severity and complexity” while the terrorist threat from isis and the far right “persists at scale”.

headline: breonna taylor died one year ago. the fight for justice is far from over | shanita hubbard
standfirst: The best way to honor her is to put an unflinching spotlight on the way society minimizes violence against Black womenr>
lead_paragraph: in march last year, life as we knew it in america changed. on 11 march, donald trump declared the coronavirus pandemic a national emergency. two days later, police officers entered the home of breonna taylor and shot her to death. news of the former instantly shook the world. the latter took several months to command mainstream attention. perhaps stories about her killing were lost in the noise of a world seemingly collapsing. or perhaps we are conditioned to de-prioritize the brutality faced by black women in america. one year later this is what i know for certain: we  did not and won’t receive the justice that so many of us  fought for last year, but we can choose to honor breonna taylor by continuing our fight for black women impacted by police violence – and for all vulnerable black women in our community.

headline: ‘it’s time to bring out the wiz!’ the wild return of the super soul musical
standfirst: This spin on The Wizard of Oz was a Broadway hit in the 70s and became a film with Diana Ross. Now, the tale of Black joy takes Dorothy from a Manchester tower block and BLM protests to the Emerald City
lead_paragraph: the wizard of oz is a movie masterpiece that still glitters like a ruby slipper. its stage prequel,  wicked, has been running non-stop since 2003. but there is another, lesser-known spin-off from l frank baum’s original novel. the wiz, which filters the same story through the prism of african american culture, won seven tonys during its initial broadway run in 1975. it’s surprising, then, that this musical by charlie smalls (music and lyrics) and william f brown (book) has been revived so infrequently over the years, or that reviews have sometimes been the critical equivalent of the bucket of water with which dorothy vanquishes the wicked witch of the west.

headline: george floyd memorials held in houston and los angeles as democrats unveil reforms – as it happened
standfirst: l>i>Thousands of people come to pay their respects to Floydi>i> Derek Chauvin appeared virtually in court Mondayi>i> Lawmakers propose Justice in Policing Act to prevent deaths in custodyi>i> Biden states opposition to defunding policei>i> New York to start reopeningr>i>i> Minneapolis lawmakers vow to disband police departmentr>i>i>Sign up to our  First Thing newsletterr>i>l>
