headline: fires light up washington dc on third night of george floyd protests
standfirst: Sunday evening’s demonstrations began peacefully but deteriorated into firecrackers, teargas and multiple firesl>i> George Floyd protests: live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: multiple fires broke out near the white house late on sunday evening, as angry protesters gathered in washington dc for the third night in a row following the death of george floyd.

headline: uk officer cleared of breaking law over george floyd meme
standfirst: Sgt Geraint Jones sent ‘grossly offensive’ meme to Devon police colleagues as joke, rules judge
lead_paragraph: a devon police sergeant who sent colleagues a “disgusting and grossly offensive” doctored image of george floyd’s arrest has been cleared by a judge of breaking the law after she accepted it was meant as a joke.

headline: derek chauvin sentenced to 22.5 years in prison for murder of george floyd
standfirst: Four members of the Floyd family, including his seven-year-old daughter Gianna, gave statements before the sentencing
lead_paragraph: derek chauvin, the former minneapolis police officer who murdered george floyd, has been sentenced to 22 years and six months for second-degree murder, closing one chapter of a case that thrust the issue of race and american policing back into the global spotlight.

headline: ‘liverpool is built on transatlantic slavery’: how city’s museums are tackling race issues
standfirst: Laura Pye, director of National Museums Liverpool, describes impact of BLM movement on staff
lead_paragraph: a year ago, laura pye would have said that she had been a champion of diversity throughout her career. and then george floyd’s murder sparked a movement that took hold in the uk on an  unprecedented scale.

headline: curtis sittenfeld: ‘people misunderstood the sex scenes in rodham’
standfirst: The bestselling author on reimagining Hillary Clinton’s life, what novelists have learned from Covid and the mood in her home town, Minneapolis, since the murder of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: curtis sittenfeld, 45, is the author of two short story collections and six novels, including m> prepm>, her 2005 debut about a teenage girl at boarding school, and m> american wifem>, narrated by a white house first lady, based on laura bush. both books were bestsellers longlisted for the orange prize (now the women’s prize for fiction). her latest novel, m> rodhamm>, out in paperback next month, imagines how hillary clinton’s political career might have looked had she not married bill. sittenfeld, who was born in ohio and studied at the iowa writers’ workshop, spoke to me on zoom from minneapolis, where she has lived since 2018.

headline: louisville's failure to address racial disparities prompts fears 'there will be another breonna taylor'
standfirst: A year after the killing of a 26-year-old in a deeply segregated Kentucky city, calls for justice – a task bigger than reforms, memorials and platitudes – have gone unanswered
lead_paragraph: three hundred and sixty-five days. four police chiefs. two fatal shootings tied to protests. hundreds of protesters arrested. zero charges for the three police officers who fired 32 bullets in the early morning raid that killed breonna taylor, hitting her six times.

headline: stormzy gives £500,000 to fund scholarships for disadvantaged students
standfirst: Rapper makes donation in the wake of the Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: stormzy has donated £500,000 to fund educational scholarships for students from disadvantaged backgrounds as part of his commitment to becoming a major philanthropist supporting black british causes.

headline: 'abuse of power': global outrage grows after death of george floyd
standfirst: Protests spread to Sydney and Paris, as diplomats question use of force in US l>i> George Floyd protests: latest developmentsi>l>
lead_paragraph: the eu’s top diplomat has described the death of george floyd as an “abuse of power”, adding his voice to growing international unease over the us killing as well as washington’s subsequent violent crackdown against protesters.

headline: n ireland police chief apologises over handling of black lives matter protests
standfirst: Chief constable admits BAME community ‘frustrated, angry and upset by our policing response’r>
lead_paragraph: northern ireland’s most senior police officer has apologised over the handling of black lives matter protests in belfast and derry during the pandemic lockdown earlier this year.

headline: ‘the work continues’: black americans stress that police reform is still needed
standfirst: The Obamas and Bernice King were among those to encourage justice for other victims of police brutality after the Derek Chauvin guilty verdict
lead_paragraph: prominent black americans expressed relief after the white former minneapolis officer derek chauvin was  convicted of murdering george floyd, but warned that police reform, and justice for other victims of police brutality, are still necessary.

headline: us protests live: hundreds of thousands march against racial injustice – as it happened
standfirst: Large crowds from coast to coast demonstrate against police killing of George Floydl>i> States announce police reforms after controversial tacticsi>i> Protests about police brutality met with wave of police brutalityi>i> In their own words: the protesters at the heart of America’s uprising i>i> What freedom of the press looks like in the US right now r>i>l>

headline: the stifling of protest around the world paves the road for authoritarian rule | janai nelson
standfirst: One year after the murder of George Floyd, we should be honoring the actions that made his name a global call to action instead of targeting those who speak outr>
lead_paragraph: as the first anniversary of  george floyd’s murder by a former minneapolis police officer passes this week, we continue to contend with relentless violence by law enforcement against people of color and other marginalized communities. since that tragic loss, law enforcement in the united states have killed  181 black people – a disproportionate rate compared with other groups. and, globally, law enforcement officers also continue to engage in rampant violence against civilians, which is  frequently directed at members of societal groups that have endured historic discrimination. however, another deeply disturbing reality that has emerged is the brutal crackdown on police accountability protests and protesters worldwide, who, following floyd’s killing, united their voices against racial injustice to a level not seen since the anti-apartheid movement of the 1980s. as dangerous as police violence has been for black communities and other marginalized groups across the world, the stifling of protest and betrayal of protesters poses a particularly nefarious global threat, with devastating civil and human rights consequences if left unchecked.

headline: the most notable us athletes of 2020: no 4 – breanna stewart, the unstoppable ally
standfirst: A gruesome injury couldn’t stop basketball’s most dominant force from adding to her trophy cabinet, but it was her allyship in the memory of Breonna Taylor that made a bigger impact
lead_paragraph: there’s a special joy in watching breanna stewart go about her work. the 26-year-old archetype-busting star forward of the seattle storm stands 6ft 4in with a 7ft 1in wingspan that’s longer than lebron’s, blending the size and strength of a top-drawer post player with the agility and coordination of an elite wing. when she’s not using her length and physicality to pick her teeth with muscle-bound defenders in the paint, you can find her on the perimeter, calmly sinking three-pointers or roasting opponents off the dribble to create chances for herself and her teammates.

headline: ‘my mum met my dad, they had sex. it’s amazing!’: the best quotes of the 2021 oscars
standfirst: Daniel Kaluuya shouted out to his parents’ productivity, Frances McDormand urged Americans to return to cinemas soon, and winners decried police brutality in America
lead_paragraph: “it has been quite a year. and we are still smack dab in the middle of it,” said king as she  kicked off the 93rd oscars with a strut through union station to the socially distant stage. “we are mourning the loss of so many, and if things had gone differently this past week in minneapolis? i might have traded in my heels for marching boots.

headline: miss juneteenth star nicole beharie: ‘black people are not monolithic’
standfirst: The actor on Black Lives Matter, discussing representation with Steve McQueen and remembering co-star Chadwick Boseman
lead_paragraph: speaking to nicole beharie, it becomes apparent that she is m>reallym> passionate about science. during our interview, the actor erupts into a flurry of asides, from the discovery of  two new black holes to her ardour for neuroscience. “i’m fascinated by pavlov’s theory of domesticating animals,” she says at one point. “seeing how culture affects things and why people are the way they are.”r/>r/>beharie’s interest in the human condition might explain the range and depth of the roles she has played to date, starting with her critically acclaimed lead performance in 2008’s  american violet as a wrongly convicted single mother who refuses to take a plea bargain. since then, she has starred as the intended parent of a surrogate child in hulu’s  little fires everywhere; the wife of a conflicted cop battling between his badge and his identity in the 2018 drama monsters and men, partly inspired by the death of eric garner; and as a resilient-yet-flawed former beauty queen in the upcoming film miss juneteenth. a 45-second clip of her performance in an episode of black mirror, a masterclass in understated emotion, recently  went viral on twitter.

headline: bishop 'outraged' over trump's church photo op during george floyd protests
standfirst: The Rev Mariann Budde says the institution aligns itself with those seeking justice for Floyd’s deathl>i> George Floyd killing: follow latest updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: the episcopal bishop of washington dc has said she is “outraged” after officers used teargas to clear a crowd of peaceful protesters from near the white house to make way for  donald trump.

headline: how mma fighter donald williams helped achieve justice for george floyd
standfirst: The 33-year-old was an eye witness to a murder than shook America. His testimony – and knowledge of wrestling – proved important at trial
lead_paragraph: when donald williams ii saw the police car, he debated continuing on his way. he’d snuck out of his place on 25 may 2020 for a few minutes’ break from his family – just a quick hop to cup foods for an energy drink, something williams had done countless times before. it had been a productive day of fishing on valentine lake with his 13-year-old son. they planned to fillet and cook the three bass they had caught for dinner; williams didn’t want to keep his son waiting. he’d haphazardly thrown on his navy blue northside boxing hoodie and two mismatched socks that peaked conspicuously out of his flip-flops. he wasn’t dressed for a serious interaction.

headline: george floyd: protests take place in cities around the world
standfirst: Public figures condemn police killing of unarmed black man as people march in solidarity with US protestersl>i> George Floyd protests: live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: people in cities around the world have marched in solidarity with demonstrators in the us, as politicians and public figures unite to condemn the killing of  george floyd.

headline: minneapolis shooting: man dies in 'exchange of fire' with police
standfirst: Spontaneous protests at scene less than a mile from where George Floyd died in May
lead_paragraph: police in minneapolis shot and killed a man in an exchange of gunfire during a traffic stop on the city’s south side on wednesday night, authorities have said.

headline: texas officials seek posthumous pardon for george floyd over drug conviction
standfirst: l>i>Floyd spent 10 months in jail after 2004 conviction in Houstoni>i>Application for pardon reveals repeated police harassment i>i> Police killings amount to crimes against humanity, report findsi>l>
lead_paragraph: nearly a year after his death, and a week after the police officer who killed him in minneapolis was  found guilty of murder, the search for justice for george floyd continues.

headline: 'being black in america requires emotional aerobics': regina king on 'powder keg' movie one night in miami
standfirst: The Oscar-winning Beale Street actor on success and her sharply topical feature debut, a civil rights-era film that coincided with the explosive rise of Black Lives Matter
lead_paragraph: to say regina king is “having a moment” feels a little inappropriate, considering that she is 35 years into her career. but it also feels like an understatement. in the past five years she has won  an oscar, four emmys and numerous other awards for her performances in a string of acclaimed titles, including barry jenkins’s  if beale street could talk, the prescient comic-book miniseries  watchmen and the netflix race-crime drama  seven seconds. as well as marching her down several miles of red carpet, the flurry of attention has catapulted her into a new echelon of star power.

headline: protesters rally in oxford for removal of cecil rhodes statue
standfirst: University campaigners and Black Lives Matter protesters block road outside Oriel Collegel>i> UK Black Lives Matter protests - live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: more than a thousand protesters have gathered outside oxford university to demand the removal of a statue of the victorian imperialist cecil rhodes.

headline: with world watching derek chauvin's trial, focus will be on officer who 'betrayed' his badge
standfirst: Analysis: the trial over the killing of George Floyd may be a bellwether for racial justice, but the prosecution will focus on one man’s actions
lead_paragraph: for all the many thousands of protests around the world, the global reckoning on racism and policing prompted by the killing of george floyd last may, prosecutors were clear that their case in the murder trial of former minneapolis police officer derek chauvin would be centered around a period of time lasting less than 10 minutes.

headline: fears grow of us coronavirus surge from george floyd protests
standfirst: l>i>Demonstrators in close proximity, many without masksi>i> Trump under fire as violence flares across Americai>i> George Floyd protests: live coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: even as all us states continue further phased reopening of businesses and social movement amid the  coronavirus pandemic, governors, mayors and public health officials across the us are raising fears of a surge in cases of  covid-19 arising from escalating protests over the death of  george floyd.

headline: girl, 10, who witnessed george floyd murder ‘proud’ after guilty verdict
standfirst: l>i>Judeah Reynolds testified at Chauvin murder triali>i>‘My mom said we brought change. My dad said we won’i>l>
lead_paragraph: a young girl who witnessed derek chauvin murder george floyd has said she felt “proud” after the jury’s verdict on tuesday.

headline: people ask me how they can support black lives matter. at the moment all i can feel is sadness and grief
standfirst: Questions of race have made me tired since I was old enough to understand what police brutality was – I can shine a light on the issues, but I’m no teacher or strategist
lead_paragraph: i am not a teacher. i have never trained as a teacher, nor do i think i’d be a very good one. so it always comes as a surprise that i’m expected to teach non-black people about race. one of the questions i was asked most, on my year-long m>queeniem> press tour, was: “how do we solve the problem of diversity in publishing?” i’m an author. it’s not my responsibility to redress a system that is institutionally racist. i can shine a light on it, but i already have a job. and diversity corrections strategist is not it. m>neitherm> is teacher.

headline: bbc considers dropping rule britannia from last night of the proms
standfirst: Covid restrictions seen as opportunity for change in wake of Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: the traditional flag-waving anthems rule britannia and land of hope of glory could be dropped from the last night of the proms because of their perceived links with colonialism and slavery.

headline: black lives matter changed my life, and my interracial marriage, for the better | tineka smith
standfirst: In a defining year as an African American woman, I realised my white British husband will always be learning about race
lead_paragraph: like some sort of subversive enlightenment, 2020 has revealed a number of unpalatable truths about our world. but perhaps the most uncomfortable moments of the year came when we looked inwardly at ourselves and the relationships we have with others.

headline: george floyd death: four ex-police officers indicted on civil rights charges
standfirst: l>i>Derek Chauvin, Thomas Lane, J Kueng and Tou Thao chargedi>i>Quartet accused of violating Floyd’s constitutional rightsi>l>
lead_paragraph: a federal grand jury has indicted the four former minneapolis police officers involved in george floyd’s arrest and murder, accusing them of violating the black man’s constitutional rights as he was restrained face-down on the pavement and gasping for air, according to indictments unsealed on friday.

headline: daunte wright and george floyd: another chapter in america’s recurring tragedy
standfirst: The latest instance of a black man killed by a police officer added fuel to the fire already burning in Minneapolis
lead_paragraph: it was shortly after midday on thursday at the new salem missionary baptist church in minneapolis. in front of a towering stone facade, katie wright stood at the pulpit, almost dwarfed by the plexiglass lectern and mass of microphones in front of her. she shuddered with grief, held by members of her family.

headline: trump fled to bunker as protests over george floyd raged outside white house
standfirst: The president has been widely criticised for his response to the demonstrations, preferring tweets to a national addressl>i> George Floyd protests: live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: donald trump was taken to the secure white house bunker, usually reserved for times of war or terrorist attacks, in the midst of noisy protests on friday about the killing of george floyd by police, and sporadic clashes close to the presidential complex’s perimeter.

headline: obama didn’t deliver for africa – can biden prove that black lives matter everywhere? | vava tampa
standfirst: There is reason to hope the president-elect will pivot from long-standing US policy of backing continent’s strongman leaders
lead_paragraph: how different is the biden-harris administration’s africa policy going to be from donald trump’s, or even barack obama’s? many african people, as well as the continent’s strongman leaders, are now gingerly asking – is biden going to be obama 2.0, or trump-lite?

headline: george floyd killing: what sparked the protests – and what has been the response?
standfirst: Protests have flared up across the US as people demand justice and systemic change to end police brutalityl>i> George Floyd killing – follow live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: the us is undergoing a reckoning on race and police brutality after footage went viral of a white police officer killing a black man by kneeling on his neck for more than eight minutes.

headline: us house passes most ambitious police reform effort in decades
standfirst: George Floyd Justice in Policing Act would ban chokeholds and qualified immunity for law enforcement, but faces tough road in the Senater>
lead_paragraph: the us house of representatives passed the george floyd justice in policing act, the most ambitious police reform effort in decades, for the second time on wednesday.

headline: derek chauvin trial: police expert witness says ‘excessive force’ used on george floyd – as it happened
standfirst: l>i>Day seven of murder trial over George Floyd’s death underwayi>i> Medical trainer: ‘Just because they’re speaking doesn’t mean they’re breathing’i>i> Police lieutenant: restraint permitted if suspect is actively aggressiver>i>i> Police chief: use of force on George Floyd was ‘in no way’ policyr>i>i> Doctor says asphyxia was likely cause of deathi>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2021-04-06t20:50:48.458z">9.50pm pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: 'oh cool, i don’t have to put on pants!' stars on music's year of chaos
standfirst: Phoebe Bridgers, Danielle Haim, Lianne La Havas, Declan McKenna, Rina Sawayama and Moses Sumney discuss Black Lives Matter, WAP, TikTok, the collapse of live music and more
lead_paragraph: each year we convene pop stars to mull over the year’s big musical moments, and for 2020 this was – like almost every social or professional interaction – convened over a video call. it was a strangely appropriate format for an industry that learned how to livestream as it weathered a total collapse in gigs and festivals, but despite the horrors, there was still plenty of brilliant and indeed cathartic music released. pondering it all are danielle haim, singer with haim, who are nominated for album of the year at the grammys; phoebe bridgers, also heading to the grammys with four nominations; british soul-jazz singer lianne la havas; emotive songwriter moses sumney; glam-pop star declan mckenna; and british-japanese pop sensation rina sawayama.

headline: tottenham protest marks anniversary of mark duggan's death
standfirst: Action supported by Black Lives Matter calls for end to ‘institutionally racist policing’
lead_paragraph: chants of “no justice no peace” echoed around tottenham police station on saturday afternoon as hundreds of peaceful demonstrators gathered outside to call for an end to what they say is institutionally racist policing in this part of north london.

headline: tate faces protests over impact of job cuts on bame staff
standfirst: Institution’s Black Lives Matter response also criticised as galleries prepare to reopen
lead_paragraph: the tate is facing protests against job cuts that trade unions and others say will disproportionately affect black and minority ethnic staff as it reopens its doors for the first time in four months.

headline: the guardian view on wisconsin and the republicans: america's divisions | editorial
standfirst: Killings during Black Lives Matter protests in Kenosha highlight what is at stake in November’s election
lead_paragraph: on tuesday, america heard two calls for peace and unity. the first came from the mother of jacob blake, a black man shot in the back by police multiple times in front of his children, and reportedly left paralysed. after episodes of arson and looting followed peaceful protests in kenosha, wisconsin, julia jackson  href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/aug/25/jacob-blake-family-justice-peaceful-protest" title="">urged: “we need healing.”

headline: breonna taylor protests: what we know so far
standfirst: The decision not to lay any direct charges over the killing of Breonna Taylor in Louisville have sparked protests across the nationl>i> Breonna Taylor decision: two officers shot in Louisville as protests erupt across US – live i>l>
lead_paragraph: trong>protests have erupted across the us after a grand jury decided not to directly charge police officers for the killing of breonna taylor,trong> who was fatally shot by louisville police as officers carried out a no-knock warrant in march.

headline: george floyd protests: the us cities that became hotspots of unrest
standfirst: l>i>Major cities from New York to Los Angeles and Miami to Seattle saw a mix of peaceful demonstrations and violent outbreaksi>i> George Floyd protests: live reporti>l>
lead_paragraph: protests have erupted across the us, from coast to coast and north to south, in reaction to the death of  george floyd, an african american man who was killed under the knee of a white police officer in minneapolis last monday.

headline: youtube star jake paul denies looting arizona mall during george floyd protests
standfirst: l>i>Footage emerges of 23-year-old in looted Scottsdale malli>i> George Floyd protests: live coveragei>i> Dispatch from Minneapolis: the night the city cracked downi>l>
lead_paragraph: the youtube star jake paul has denied taking part in looting at an arizona mall on saturday night.

headline: chauvin trial told ‘a healthy person would have died’ under same circumstances as george floyd – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> ‘A healthy person subjected to that … would have died’i>i> Pulmonology expert says low oxygen levels caused damage to braini>i>Murder trial enters ninth day of testimony in Minneapolisr>i>i> The protesters who gather every day to demand justicei>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2021-04-08t22:20:51.970z">11.20pm pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: 'mr president, don't go hide': china goads us over george floyd protests
standfirst: Officials and state media appear to revel in scenes of US unrest, comparing protests there to Hong Kong’s pro-democracy movementl>i> George Floyd protests: live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: chinese officials and state media have seized on news of the protests sweeping the us, comparing the widespread unrest to the pro-democracy movement in hong kong and accusing washington of hypocrisy.

headline: 'racism is in the bones of our nation': will joe biden answer 'cry' for racial justice?
standfirst: Activists are hopeful but cautious as president acknowledges ground shifted in the US after the police killing of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: in his first few minutes as america’s new president, joe biden made a promise so sweeping that it almost seemed to deny history. “we can deliver racial justice,” biden pledged to his factious nation. it wasn’t a commitment presented in any detail as he moved on to asserting that america would again be the leading force for good in the world, a claim that draws its own scrutiny.

headline: the black lives matter effect: how cinema is tackling an epidemic of police shootings
standfirst: Queen & Slim is the latest in a series of films exploring police brutality against African Americans, with mixed results
lead_paragraph: how many times have we seen a white police officer pull over an african-american driver in a movie? enough to know exactly what to do, even if we have never been in the situation ourselves. be polite and cooperative. hands where they can see them. no sudden movements. even then, an innocent black driver might not make it out alive. in queen & slim, the black couple of the title (played by daniel kaluuya and jodie turner-smith) do survive, but the white cop doesn’t. like us, they know these incidents rarely end in justice. so they hit the road and hope for the best.

headline: prosecutors accuse derek chauvin of killing george floyd as trial starts
standfirst: Jerry Blackwell told jury that ex-officer used excessive and unreasonable force ‘without regard for Floyd’s life’l>i> Derek Chauvin trial begins – live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: prosecutors accused former police officer derek chauvin of killing a defenceless george floyd by “grinding and crushing him until the very breath, the very life, was squeezed out of him”, at the opening on monday of a murder trial regarded by millions as a litmus test of us police accountability.

headline: marilynne robinson: 'america still has a democratic soul'
standfirst: The author of Gilead on the Black Lives Matter protests, the dangers of social media, and her latest novel, Jack
lead_paragraph: marilynne robinson is an american novelist and essayist. one of barack obama’s favourite authors, she won the pulitzer prize for fiction in 2005 for  her novel m> gileadm>. this was the first in a trilogy of books that chronicle the spiritual journeys of two families in a fictional mid-western town. her new book, m>jackm>, returns to the most enigmatic character in the series, as he embarks on an interracial relationship in segregated st louis.  robinson lives in iowa, where she set her gilead novels.

headline: cricket's dressing rooms have questions to answer over black players' isolation | andy bull
standfirst: The Black Lives Matter movement has highlighted problems faced by players who have felt alienated by teammates
lead_paragraph: back in july the south african fast bowler lungi ngidi answered a question about the black lives matter movement: “it’s something we will be addressing as a team,” he said, “and if we are not, it’s something i will bring up.” it was a tiny spark, but it started a fire that has burned through the south african winter, as more and more black players have started to open up about their unhappy experiences playing for the national team. in the end, cricket south africa launched a social justice and nation building project, to investigate whether it ought to  pay reparations to players who were discriminated against.

headline: george floyd killing: protests flare as americans await verdict in chauvin trial
standfirst: Outcome is expected to resonate nationwide, particularly in cities that have seen continuing demonstrations over police violence
lead_paragraph: protests against police killings flared across the us this weekend, from minneapolis to chicago to portland, as americans wait for a verdict in the trial of the white police officer charged with murdering george floyd last year.

headline: chris jordan: 'the black lives matter message is definitely being heard'
standfirst: England’s death-bowling specialist on taking a knee, why Eoin Morgan is one of a kind, and inspiring the next generation
lead_paragraph: the number of cricket teams taking a knee before matches may have dwindled during the recent summer but for chris jordan, england’s death‑bowling specialist in twenty20 cricket, the momentum behind its message of racial equality continues.

headline: george floyd case reignites calls to tackle racial injustice in uk policing
standfirst: Campaigners say conviction of white officer Derek Chauvin should be catalyst for changer>
lead_paragraph: the conviction of a us police officer for  murdering george floyd has reignited calls to tackle racial injustice in british law enforcement, with campaigners calling for an end to a “culture of impunity”.

headline: george floyd: curfews fail to deter a new wave of protests across us
standfirst: l>i>Governors set curfews and national guard troops were deployedi>i> Fires light up Washington DC on third night of George Floyd protestsi>i> Robert Reich: the Trump presidency is overr>i>i> George Floyd protests: live coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: cities across the us saw further unrest on sunday as protests against police brutality and the killing of george floyd in minneapolis raged on. fires burned in the nation’s capital, including near the white house, on the sixth day of nationwide demonstrations.

headline: minneapolis hopes for new beginning after verdict: ‘george floyd is a movement’
standfirst: After weeks of anxiety, the city celebrated with a victory march. ‘Tomorrow we get back to work,’ one organizer said
lead_paragraph: as george floyd’s girlfriend waited for a verdict in the trial of derek chauvin, the police officer charged with murdering floyd, one of the journalists crowded around her asked what being present outside the minneapolis courthouse meant to her.

headline: jason holder urges cricket not to abandon black lives matter message
standfirst: l>i>West Indies captain feted at Cricket Writers’ Club awardsi>i>He says: ‘I haven’t had one conversation in the IPL around it’i>l>
lead_paragraph: jason holder has urged cricket not to abandon the black lives matter message after the west indies captain and his team were recognised among the annual cricket writers’ club awards.

headline: death of romany man knelt on by czech police compared to that of george floyd
standfirst: Video footage challenges official claims that the cause of death was unrelated to man’s arrest
lead_paragraph: video footage of a police officer kneeling on the neck of a romany man who later died in an ambulance is being shared among czechs on social media, leading many to compare his treatment to that of george floyd.

headline: seth meyers: beware the 'craven husks laying groundwork' for trump's election chaos
standfirst: Late-night hosts blast Trump’s suggestinon to delay the 2020 election and the memeification of Breonna Taylor
lead_paragraph: on thursday trump used twitter to decry mail-in voting – a standard practice for state elections – and to “delay the election until people can properly, securely and safely vote???”

headline: george floyd: donald trump under fire as violence flares across america
standfirst: l>i>President tweets from White House as cities strugglei>i>Democrat Val Demings: ‘We need leadership’i>i> George Floyd protests: live coveragei>i> Dispatch from Minneapolis: the night the city cracked downi>l>
lead_paragraph: the chaos and crisis engulfing america came to the president’s doorstep on saturday night, as protesters chanting “i can’t breathe” and “fuck donald trump!” clashed with the secret service and police outside the white house.

headline: 'things are getting worse': tunisia protests rage on as latest victim named
standfirst: Police brutality and unemployment worsened by the pandemic continues to drive young protesters onto streets to demand reform
lead_paragraph: the latest victim of tunisia’s current unrest has been named as haykel rachdi, from sbeitla in kasserine, near the algerian border. he died of his injuries on monday night after reportedly being struck on the head by a police teargas canister.

headline: aid spending in africa must be african-led – it needs a black lives matter reckoning | dedo baranshamaje and katie bunten-wamaru
standfirst: If we use this pivotal moment to shift funding to grassroots groups we could unlock transformational change
lead_paragraph: while the us continues to reckon with its long-simmering struggle against racial injustice, it is important to remember that racism is not just a homegrown problem – we are also exporting it.

headline: george floyd protests: can trump deploy federal troops on to the streets in the us?
standfirst: Outcome seems to hang on the interpretation of the 1807 Insurrection Act, which allows the use of active-duty troops for law enforcementl>i> Live coverage of the George Floyd protestsi>l>
lead_paragraph: us president donald trump has  threatened to deploy the united states military to american cities to quell civil unrest in the wake of george floyd’s death.

headline: tucker carlson defends actions of teen charged in killings of kenosha protesters
standfirst: Kyle Rittenhouse, 17, has been charged with murder after two people were killed at Black Lives Matter protest
lead_paragraph: the rightwing fox news host tucker carlson has defended the actions of a 17-year-old who was arrested and charged with murder after two people were killed in kenosha,  wisconsin, as white vigilante agitators shot at black lives matter protesters.

headline: olivette otele: 'discussions of cancel culture are very middle class. activists just survive and support each other'
standfirst: The UK’s first black female history professor talks about slavery, Black Lives Matter and the long thread of resistance among Africans in Europe
lead_paragraph: olivette otele is the quintessential african european. she was born in cameroon, grew up in france where she received her education, and now lives in wales. in 2018, she became the uk’s first black female history professor, and this she year was included in the  “100 great black britons” list. when  edward colston’s statue was torn down and dragged into bristol’s harbour, otele, who teaches the history of slavery at the university of bristol, could not have been better placed to witness and process the moment.

headline: derek chauvin trial: george floyd was ‘a person everybody loved’, brother says
standfirst: Philonise Floyd tells jury how his brother was ‘a leader’ while cardiologist says George Floyd’s death was ‘absolutely preventable’ r>
lead_paragraph: george floyd’s younger brother, philonise floyd, took the stand on monday in the trial of the former police officer accused of murdering him and told the jury how george floyd was “a person that everybody loved around the community”.

headline: uk police officer denies sending offensive george floyd meme
standfirst: Sgt Geraint Jones of Devon and Cornwall force will go on trial in March accused of sharing image
lead_paragraph: a police sergeant has denied a charge of sending a grossly offensive meme of george floyd to colleagues in a whatsapp group.

headline: derek chauvin murder trial delayed for decision on extra charge
standfirst: l>i>Judge in George Floyd case delays jury selection for at least dayi>i>State supreme court to be asked to rule on additional chargei>l>
lead_paragraph: the judge overseeing the trial of a former minneapolis police officer accused of murdering george floyd delayed the start of jury selection on monday for at least a day while an appeal proceeds over the possible reinstatement of an additional charge.

headline: sasha johnson: blm activist in critical condition after gunshot to the head
standfirst: Shooting in Southwark, London came after numerous death threats, says her Taking the Initiative partyl>i> Latest: BLM activist Sasha Johnson may have been shot by mistakei>l>
lead_paragraph: the black lives matter activist sasha johnson is in a critical condition after sustaining a gunshot wound to her head in an incident in south london, her affiliated group, taking the initiative party, has announced on social media.

headline: i grew up not knowing my african heritage. but now i feel a calling | florence boafo
standfirst: From Black Panther to Black Lives Matter, I’ve felt a new sense of identity and pride, that I will pass on to my children
lead_paragraph: growing up, i envied those who understood their mother’s native language. speaking it was admirable, but the very act of comprehension was a beautiful thing to witness. from afar it seemed like a love language, something intimate and secretive spoken between families – it suggested a bond, a closeness that seemed impenetrable.

headline: the spin awards: a biosecure summer of unsung heroes like no other | tim de lisle
standfirst: Prizes go to Michael Holding for showing why Black Lives Matter and the BBC for bringing cricket back to the masses
lead_paragraph: at first, after the unbeatable thrills of 2019, the men’s international cricket season of 2020 looked like being an anticlimax. then, as one nation after another locked down, it looked like not happening at all. next, it looked like happening after a fashion but being too weird to cast a spell. and finally, it happened, without a hitch, and with many a magic moment. now was our easter of discontent made glorious summer.

headline: sydney black lives matter protest organisers say rally will proceed despite pm and premier's condemnation
standfirst: Scott Morrison says BLM protest ‘appalling’ while Gladys Berejiklian says rally cannot be allowed to go aheadl>i> Follow our Australian coronavirus live blogi>i> Sign up for Guardian Australia’s coronavirus emaili>l>
lead_paragraph: organisers of a black lives matter protest planned for sydney next week say the demonstration will go ahead despite both the prime minister and  new south wales premier demanding it be cancelled.

headline: trump orders creation of 'garden of american heroes' amid backlash over monuments
standfirst: President proposed garden amid protests against police brutality that fueled the removal of statues tied to historic injustice
lead_paragraph: heading out of office in a blur of insurrection, mass deaths due to a pandemic, scandal and lies, donald trump on monday issued  an executive order directing the building of a national garden of american heroes, “to reflect the awesome splendour of our country’s timeless exceptionalism”.

headline: a restaurateur, a radical chef and a cook-turned-campaigner: ‘what 2020 has taught us’
standfirst: From Covid-19 to Black Lives Matter and the storm around food inequality, it’s been a tumultuous year. Three people in the hospitality industry reveal how it’s changed their lives
lead_paragraph: m>owner, lunya restaurant and deli, liverpoolm>

headline: the protesters who gather every day to demand justice for george floyd
standfirst: A small but determined group rise early to take their spot outside the Minneapolis courthouse – and they stay all day
lead_paragraph: behind the hennepin county courthouse in downtown minneapolis, which is heavily fortified for the  murder trial of derek chauvin, a small but determined core of seven protesters gathers every day.

headline: la haine review – effervescent classic radiates with rage and comedy
standfirst: Mathieu Kassovitz’s celebrated story of inequality in a Paris banlieue is a timely rerelease in the Black Lives Matter era
lead_paragraph: m athieu kassovitz’s classic of banlieue rage has been rereleased after 25 years with a new urgency and relevance in the black lives matter era. what comes across now isn’t the “hate” of the title, more the aimless, directionless comedy of three guys hanging around, bantering and squabbling about things such as which cartoon character is the most badass. it is touches like this which make you realise how very 90s it all is, similar to tarantino and trainspotting (with a nod to taxi driver’s “ you talkin’ to me?” scene) but it also has a little something of the french new wave, the world of jacques rivette’s paris belongs to us, all of which influenced the later americans. it’s a film about which i’ve had fluctuating views. perhaps as a result of having watched it so much, i greeted the 10th-anniversary rerelease with some grumpy contrarianism. now i think it simply looks superb.

headline: injured boy 'stopped and searched' by met officer he asked for help
standfirst: Teenager attacked in London by rightwing opponents of Black Lives Matter movement
lead_paragraph: rights groups have criticised police after a boy of 16, attacked by far-right opponents of a black lives matter demonstration in london, said he was stopped and searched by the policeman he had asked for help.

headline: labour criticises pm's silence on promised equalities review
standfirst: Boris Johnson announced inquiry a month ago in response to Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: labour has questioned why the government has not yet revealed who will chair an equalities review, a month after it was announced by boris johnson as a response to the black lives matter movement.

headline: greek pm appeals for peace after police brutality ignites riots
standfirst: Protests sparked by video clips of police officer beating man with iron baton for breaking Covid restrictionsl>i> Coronavirus – latest updatesi>i> See all our coronavirus coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the greek government, put on the defensive by mounting allegations of police brutality, has appealed for calm following clashes on the streets of athens, mass protests and growing anger over the country’s prolonged lockdown.

headline: louisville declares state of emergency ahead of breonna taylor decision
standfirst: Grand jury decision imminent on fatal shooting by police of 26-year-old inside her apartment in March
lead_paragraph: a state of emergency was declared in louisville, kentucky, in anticipation of protests following an imminent grand jury decision on the police killing of breonna taylor.

headline: a father and a 26-year-old skateboarder: the protesters killed in kenosha
standfirst: Anthony Huber, 26, and Joseph Rosenbaum, 36, were shot dead when armed extremists disrupted a Black Lives Matter protest
lead_paragraph: the two men shot dead when white armed extremists disrupted a black lives matter protest and at least one agitator opened fire on a group of protesters in kenosha have been identified.

headline: truck drives through crowd of protesters on minneapolis bridge
standfirst: Officials say driver hospitalized after being dragged from his truck and beaten, but no others were hurtl>i> George Floyd protests: live updatesi>i> Dispatch from Minneapolis: the night the city cracked downi>l>
lead_paragraph: a fuel semi-truck drove into a george floyd demonstration of thousands of people on a bridge in minneapolis apparently without seriously injuring anyone.

headline: uk police officer charged over offensive george floyd meme
standfirst: Sgt Geraint Jones of Devon and Cornwall force accused of sharing image with colleagues on WhatsApp
lead_paragraph: a police officer has been charged with a criminal offence for allegedly sending a grossly offensive meme of george floyd to colleagues in a whatsapp group.

headline: these days, having hope as a black woman can be hard. but history shows progress is possible | shanita hubbard
standfirst: The Breonna Taylor verdict is demoralizing and painful. Yet history is a reminder that in the long run, activists will make a more just worldr>
lead_paragraph: on 24 september, a kentucky grand jury delivered an unsurprising verdict: breonna taylor’s killers would walk free. the frequency of black killings at the hands of police does not lessen the severity of the pain, it deepens the wound.

headline: thursday briefing: 10,000 excess deaths at home since june
standfirst: People choosing not to visit hospitals during Covid … US protests after Breonna Taylor officers not charged ... and BLM’s co-founder on why critics get it wrong
lead_paragraph: good morning and welcome to this thursday briefing with me, alison rourke.

headline: independent review criticizes la police for handling of george floyd protests
standfirst: Review commissioned by the city council found that poor planning led to chaos and mass arrests
lead_paragraph: the los angeles police department has been criticised over its handling of the widespread protests that broke out over the summer after the death of george floyd, with an independent review finding that poor planning led to chaos and mass arrests.

headline: the guardian view on the murder of george floyd: a racial reckoning begins | editorial
standfirst: The conviction of a police officer was a landmark moment. Can an exceptional case bring the broader changes needed?r>
lead_paragraph: the relief that swept through the crowd outside the minneapolis court, and rippled around the world, was in its own way shocking. the conviction of derek chauvin  href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2021/apr/20/derek-chauvin-verdict-guilty-murder-george-floyd" title="">for george floyd’s murder should have been inevitable. the sight of the policeman kneeling upon the 46-year-old’s neck for nine minutes and 29 seconds, as the dying man  href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/jul/08/george-floyd-police-killing-transcript-i-cant-breathe" title="">pleaded repeatedly that he couldn’t breathe and called out to his late mother, was caught on camera, described by traumatised witnesses, and condemned by fellow officers during the trial.

headline: wave of extremist republicans run for office, many with trump's blessing
standfirst: Rightwing Republicans who promote QAnon and conspiracy theories about Covid-19 and Black Lives Matter are increasingly entering politics
lead_paragraph: when donald trump congratulated laura loomer, an islamophobe and conspiracy theorist, on her  republican congressional primary victory this week, it seemed to bring the president’s version of the republican party full-circle to the start of his rise.

headline: chauvin’s supervisor says his force against george floyd was unnecessary | first thing
standfirst: Sgt David Pleoger said officer accused of Floyd’s murder could have stopped restraining him much earlier. Plus, at least 36 dead after train derailed in Taiwan
lead_paragraph: good morning.

headline: marcus smith puts gloss on rugby's ragged return as harlequins beat sale
standfirst: l>i>Harlequins 16-10 Salei>i>Quins take a knee for Black Lives Matter in unisoni>l>
lead_paragraph: english rugby is back, albeit with more of a clunk than a bang, but after five long months we must gratefully accept what we are given. harlequins will not care that the rust from both sides was all too evident, nor that the penalty count kept good pace with the number of errors, and even eddie jones might have gone home happy with the mature performance of the home fly-half marcus smith.

headline: bbc newsnight accused over failure to interview any bame guests for a week
standfirst: ‘Shocking’ lack of racial diversity and women across UK journalism reported by survey in wake of Black Lives Matter protestsr>
lead_paragraph: bbc newsnight went an entire week without featuring a single live interview with a guest from a minority ethnic background, according to an analysis of national media output.

headline: the best children's books of 2020 for all ages
standfirst: From Covid-19 to Black Lives Matter, children’s books tackled the world-changing events of 2020. Here, Fiona Noble looks back on the year and, below, our picks in each age group
lead_paragraph: as  covid-19 tightened its grip in march, forcing schools, bookshops and libraries to close, so the children’s book world responded in characteristically generous style, producing an explosion of free online content to educate, entertain and support children and families.  julia donaldson and axel scheffler created a series of covid-related cartoons featuring beloved characters (“the gruffalos stayed in the gruffalo cave’”) and children’s laureate cressida cowell read daily chapters of m> how to train your dragonm>. picture book creator rob biddulph became a viral phenomenon thanks to his m> draw with robm> videos, culminating in no less than a guinness world record for the largest online art class when 45,611 people joined him in drawing a whale. a whole new covid category of children’s books was born, both instructional and inspirational. there was m> coronavirus: a book for children about covid-19m> (nosy crow), m> while we can’t hugm> by eoin mclaughlin and polly dunbar (faber), and a slew of rainbow-hued picture books. health workers were celebrated in m> the hospital dogm> by julia donaldson and sara ogilvie (macmillan) while  captain tom moore’s record-breaking fundraiser for the nhs became the m> one hundred stepsm> picture book (puffin), illustrated by adam larkum. and although not written in response to the pandemic, maggie o’farrell weaves resilience and bravery into her elegant debut picture book, m> where snow angels gom> (walker), an unforgettable winter adventure with illustratrions by daniela jaglenka terrazzini.

headline: 'the system is rigged': seun kuti on reviving fela's political party
standfirst: The musician and youngest son of the Afrobeat legend has been galvanised to act after police brutality in Nigeria
lead_paragraph: “for 60 years nothing has really been solved in this country,” seun kuti says. “healthcare, education, electricity, transportation, welfare – nothing has been accomplished.”

headline: police did not let bystanders help george floyd, court hears | first thing
standfirst: Derek Chauvin also resisted calls to remove his knee from Floyd’s neck, witnesses said on the second day of the murder trial. Plus, the US orders non-essential diplomats to leave Myanmarl>i>trong> Don’t already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up heretrong>i>l>
lead_paragraph: good morning.

headline: ‘racism doesn’t dissolve once it’s out of the headlines’: is the fashion industry doing enough to address diversity?
standfirst: Since the killing of George Floyd, the industry has attempted to tackle racism, but has it gone far enough?
lead_paragraph: this month, fashion’s unofficial watchdog,  diet prada, posted a  “how it started versus how it’s going” meme on instagram. contrasting a past moment of hope with a current moment of reckoning, diet prada turned its attention to the us clothing and homeware store anthropologie.

headline: mps demand review of national curriculum, led by black leaders
standfirst: Politicians want history syllabus re-examined after Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: mps are demanding the government holds a review of the national curriculum led by black and ethnic minority leaders and historians to better reflect black history.

headline: the life of george floyd: ‘he knew how to make people feel better’
standfirst: How someone beloved by family and many in the community became a man who would ‘change the world’l>i> Derek Chauvin verdict – follow live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: george floyd’s loved ones said  at his funeral on 9 june last year that his tragic killing at the hands of police was “going to change the world”.

headline: ‘america is on trial’: george floyd family and activists gather outside courthouse
standfirst: Family with civil rights attorney Ben Crump and campaigner Al Sharpton knelt outside as murder trial of Derek Chauvin began
lead_paragraph: members of george floyd’s family along with the civil rights attorney ben crump and the campaigner al sharpton gathered and knelt in front of the courthouse in minneapolis on monday morning as the murder trial began of former police officer derek chauvin.

headline: how laws allow the world's largest police departments to use lethal force
standfirst: As police forces face scrutiny a year after the killing of George Floyd, new research finds professional codes allow use of force even when lives are not under threat
lead_paragraph: police departments in major cities across the world give their officers legal impunity to use lethal force even when their lives are not in danger, according to new research commissioned by the guardian.

headline: george floyd family urges biden to pass police reform bill as it stalls in senate
standfirst: Floyd’s brother describes Biden as a ‘genuine guy’ but urged him to pass a law ‘to protect people of color’ at White House meetingl>i> Special report: The fight to whitewash US historyi>l>
lead_paragraph: “say his name,” said seven-year-old gianna floyd. in bright sunshine outside the west wing of the white house, family members and lawyers raised their fists and said her father’s name in chorus: “george floyd!”

headline: derek chauvin trial: defense claims bad heart and drug use killed george floyd
standfirst: Dr David Fowler, testifying for the defense, also said vehicle exhaust may have played a part in Floyd’s death
lead_paragraph: a leading forensic pathologist has told the derek chauvin trial that george floyd was killed by his heart condition and drug use.

headline: the family whose black lives matter sign shook their conservative town
standfirst: In the small community of White Sulphur Springs, everyone knows each others’ political stance. But does it promote any fruitful debate?
lead_paragraph: the hamlet of white sulphur springs, two hours north-west of new york city, tumbles toward the rolling foothills of the catskill mountains off new york state route 52 in rural, verdant sullivan county. the first white settlers, drawn by the dense hemlock forest, set up sawmills; later, dairy farms and tanneries were the area’s main economic drivers. but now and for the past hundred or so years, this bucolic wedge of new york countryside relies on tourism.

headline: breonna taylor: louisville officials agree to pay family $12m
standfirst: City reached settlement in civil suit stemming from fatal shooting by police of Taylor, 26, inside her apartment in March
lead_paragraph: the city of louisville, kentucky, has reached a $12m settlement with the family of breonna taylor in a civil suit stemming from  the fatal shooting by police of the 26-year-old inside her apartment in march, the city’s mayor, greg fischer, announced on tuesday.

headline: tv tonight: dramas from the black lives matter frontlines
standfirst: A series of shorts looks at the lives of those involved in the protests, plus there’s a visit to a Jobcentre in Yorkshire. Here’s what to watch this evening
lead_paragraph: stripped across the week, these four short dramas explore various aspects of the  black lives matter movement. we begin with jerome bucchan-nelson’s generational in which oliver (nicholas pinnock) catches his daughter justina (yasmin monet prince) sneaking out of the house. the usual fatherly concerns evaporate when he discovers she is attending a protest march. but they are replaced by another set of anxieties: will justina be safe? and does she understand the battles fought on similar ground by previous generations? trong>phil harrisontrong>

headline: keir starmer to sign up for unconscious bias training amid criticism
standfirst: Labour leader challenged by radio caller over his response to Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: keir starmer has said he will sign up for unconscious bias training amid criticism of his response to black lives matter protests and calls from a new co-chair of momentum to “get labour’s house in order” over racism.

headline: ‘we showed it was possible to create a movement from almost nothing’: occupy wall street 10 years on
standfirst: Some say it inspired BLM and the growth of the US left. Others see it as an abject failure. A decade after the occupation of New York’s Zuccotti Park, the people who were there look back
lead_paragraph: “we are the 99%.” ten years ago that unifying slogan travelled around the world. some attribute its origin to the economist joseph stiglitz, who first popularised the distinction between the 1% of people with great wealth and power and the rest of us. others say that it was the late anthropologist and anarchist david graeber who coined the phrase. but everyone agrees that it went global when it was voiced by demonstrators who gathered in lower manhattan’s financial district on 17 september 2011.

headline: it's not banter, it's racism: uk students accuse universities of brushing complaints aside
standfirst: Statements supporting Black Lives Matter are meaningless without action over racist incidents, students say
lead_paragraph: as one of six black medical students in a cohort of 150 at aberdeen university, jessica eze, a londoner, says it is hard to speak out about prejudice because your voice feels “too tiny”. so when a white patient in the hospital in which she was training publicly congratulated her on being able to speak english, she couldn’t tell her tutors how demoralised she felt.

headline: ten black history events that should be taught to every pupil
standfirst: Black History Month is a chance to introduce forgotten historical episodes into the curriculum, from the British black panthers to the Bristol bus boycottl>i> ‘It isn’t a tick-box’: young BLM activists on Black History Month in UK schoolsi>l>
lead_paragraph: black history month presents an opportunity to highlight historical episodes and figures not given due (or any) prominence in uk schools.

headline: stephen lawrence's parents' fight for justice to be made into tv drama
standfirst: Parents back project saying it has added resonance in light of Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: doreen and neville lawrence’s long, difficult struggle to get justice for their  murdered son, stephen, is to be made in to a three-part television drama.

headline: how black lives matter reshaped the race for los angeles’ top prosecutor
standfirst: The contest has highlighted the role of district attorneys in what is arguably the most important criminal justice race this election cycle
lead_paragraph: the race for top prosecutor in los angeles has become one of the most important criminal justice elections in the us this year, with black lives matter activists pushing the contest to the forefront of national debates on racist policing and incarceration.

headline: ‘let this send a clear message’: world leaders react to derek chauvin verdict
standfirst: Justin Trudeau welcomes jurors’ decision but warns that systemic racism still exists in the USl>i> ‘I cried so hard’: the teen who filmed Floyd’s killing, and changed Americai>i> Tearful testimony and defense’s own goal: key moments in the Chauvin triali>l>
lead_paragraph: news that derek chauvin has been  convicted of murder for killing george floyd by kneeling on his neck for more than nine minutes has prompted reaction from leaders around the world, with many hailing the verdict as a step toward accountability and justice in the us, while cautioning that much work remains as america re-examines racism and policing.r/>r/>canada’s prime minister, justin trudeau, wrote on twitter that the verdict meant americans had seen “accountability for the murder of george floyd. but make no mistake, systemic racism and anti-black racism still exist. and they exist in canada, too.”

headline: andrea jenkins: the first black openly transgender woman to hold us public office
standfirst: As the George Floyd murder trial opens in Minneapolis, the city councillor talks about coming out as trans, the prejudices she has had to overcome – and how policing must change
lead_paragraph: andrea jenkins lives just a few blocks away from  38th and chicago, the crossroads in minneapolis where george floyd was killed on 25 may last year. she spent two decades of her life working to revitalise the community there, and kicked off her 2017 campaign for the city council’s eighth ward in an arts centre a few yards away.

headline: devon officer tells court he shared george floyd meme for 'cheap laugh'
standfirst: Geraint Jones is on trial accused of sending a grossly offensive image to police colleagues
lead_paragraph: a british police sergeant sent a “grossly offensive” doctored image of  george floyd’s arrest to fellow officers for a “cheap laugh”, a court has been told.

headline: george floyd died from lack of oxygen caused by restraint, lung expert testifies
standfirst: l>i>Dr Martin Tobin: ‘Mr Floyd died from a low level of oxygen’i>i>Knee on neck and handcuffs in prone position starved him of airi>l>
lead_paragraph: a leading pulmonary expert has told the derek chauvin murder trial that george floyd was killed by a lack of oxygen because a knee was pressed into his neck while he was held facedown in handcuffs.

headline: equity reports an 'enormous' rise in complaints of racism
standfirst: New general secretary Paul Fleming says that amid this summer’s Black Lives Matter protests, the union received spike in reported cases of racist behaviour
lead_paragraph: equity, the uk trade union for creative practitioners, has seen a massive upsurge in cases of racism reported across the stage and screen industries. paul fleming, the union’s incoming general secretary, said the complaints raised by members include “dignity issues” and racist language used in dressing rooms and auditions.

headline: chauvin used deliberate and excessive pain technique on george floyd, police expert says
standfirst: Jody Stiger, a police specialist on the use of force, tells trial ‘pain compliance’ technique was used for much longer than necessary
lead_paragraph: an expert police witness has told the derek chauvin murder trial in minneapolis that the accused former officer used a technique designed to deliberately inflict pain and subjected george floyd to it for an extended period.

headline: derek chauvin sentenced to 22 and a half years for murder of george floyd – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> Judge hands down sentence to former Minneapolis police officeri>i>US officials weighing criminal charges against Trump Organizationi>i>Justice department sues Georgia over sweeping voting restrictionsi>i> First Thing: sign up to the Guardian’s daily US newsletteri>l>

headline: us police used british anti-riot gear at black lives matter protests
standfirst: Revelation contradicts official assurance that no UK-made equipment was used to repress peaceful demonstrations
lead_paragraph: us law enforcement officers used british anti-riot gear to strike protesters during their controversial policing of black lives matter demonstrations, despite assurances from the conservative government that no uk-made equipment was used to repress peaceful protest.

headline: breonna taylor: grand juror speaks out, saying homicide charges weren't offered
standfirst: Anonymous juror challenges statements made by the Kentucky attorney general after clearing way to speak publicly
lead_paragraph: a grand juror in  the breonna taylor case has spoken out, challenging statements made by the kentucky attorney general and saying that the jury was not offered homicide charges to consider against officers involved in taylor’s killing.

headline: black lives matter activists call for met commissioner to step down
standfirst: Demonstrators outside New Scotland Yard say Cressida Dick has failed to acknowledge racism in forcer>
lead_paragraph: the metropolitan police commissioner dame cressida dick is facing calls to step down from black lives matter activists who say she has “failed to acknowledge” racism within the force.

headline: fury as marjorie taylor greene likens covid rules to nazi treatment of jews
standfirst: l>i>Republican and Democratic leaders condemn commentsi>i>Congresswoman persists in railing against ‘vaccine passports’i>i> US politics – live coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: republicans and democrats condemned marjorie taylor greene on tuesday as the far-right georgia congresswoman continued to compare measures to combat the coronavirus pandemic to the treatment of jewish people during the holocaust.

headline: derek chauvin trial: senior police testify over george floyd death – as it happened
standfirst: Minneapolis police chief Medaria Arradondo did not take stand before adjournment and is expected to testify on Monday
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2021-04-02t16:57:11.956z">5.57pm pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: biden pledges vaccines for most adults soon as cdc chief fears 'impending doom' – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> Biden says 90% of adults will be eligible for vaccine by 19 Aprili>i> CDC finds Pfizer and Moderna vaccines highly effective at preventing infectioni>i> Chauvin trial livestreamed with courtroom access restrictedi>i> ‘Please, I can’t breathe’: prosecutors play disturbing videor>i>i> CDC head warns of ‘impending doom’ as coronavirus cases risei>i> Sign up to receive First Thing – our daily briefing by emaili>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2021-03-30t00:19:51.827z">1.19am pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: minneapolis promised change after george floyd. instead it's geared up for war | akin olla
standfirst: The trial of Derek Chauvin, the officer who killed Floyd, has begun – and Minneapolis looks like a police stater>
lead_paragraph: the george floyd uprising that began in minneapolis introduced the demand of defunding the police to the general public, empowered black-led anti-police violence movements across the planet, generated policy changes in cities across the us, and most importantly built new organizations which have the capacity to fight for systemic change for the long haul. the uprising brought a lot of reforms and positive developments to its birth city, too, including a move to actually defund the minneapolis police department and redistribute funds to services with a larger potential for eradicating both crime and poverty. now, however, the minneapolis and minnesota governments are in the process of undoing that progress and moving in the opposite direction. the trial of derek chauvin, the officer who publicly killed 46-year-old george floyd – and inadvertently triggered what may have been the  largest protest movement in us history – began this week. instead of becoming more transparent and committed to undoing the anti-black image it has cultivated, the city of minneapolis has quickly transformed itself into a 21st-century police state, pushing even beyond the hyper-militarization and violence that already plague police departments across the us.

headline: uk anti-racism protesters defy calls to avoid mass gatherings
standfirst: Thousands join Black Lives Matter protests, with 10 police officers injured in clashes
lead_paragraph: thousands of anti-racism protesters have gathered across the uk, defying calls from ministers and police chiefs to avoid mass gatherings.

headline: chauvin verdict a blow to ex-police trio awaiting trial over george floyd death
standfirst: Tou Thao, J Alexander Kueng and Thomas Lane to go on trial in August, charged with aiding and abetting Floyd’s murder
lead_paragraph: as millions of americans welcomed derek chauvin’s murder conviction, three of his former colleagues who still face trial for their part in george floyd’s death will have greeted it with dismay.

headline: morning mail: bankruptcy overhaul, breonna taylor indictment, tiktok hits back
standfirst: trong>Thursdaytrong>: a new debt restructuring process to be unveiled by the Morrison government. Plus, will Covid create greener, livelier Australian cities?
lead_paragraph: good morning, this is richard parkin bringing you the main stories and must-reads on thursday 24 september.

headline: teen who filmed killing tells court george floyd was 'begging for his life'
standfirst: Darnella Frazier said Derek Chauvin did not ease up as he pinned Floyd down and that she still loses sleep over the killing
lead_paragraph: the woman who recorded the shocking video of george floyd’s death that prompted mass protests for racial justice around the world has told the derek chauvin murder trial of her feelings of guilt at being unable to intervene to save his life.

headline: nigeria: protests continue despite curfew and president's plea
standfirst: Demonstrators against police brutality killed in Lagos after security forces opened fire
lead_paragraph: protests against police brutality have continued in many nigerian cities despite a call for calm from the president and curfews enforced by armed security forces.

headline: nigeria protests: security forces open fire on protesters in lagos
standfirst: Crackdown as rallies against police brutality continue in defiance of government curfew
lead_paragraph: nigerian security forces have opened fire on hundreds of protesters in lagos, as rallies against police brutality continued in defiance of a 24-hour curfew imposed by the government earlier in the day.

headline: police force blm protesters to move on from sydney's town hall – as it happened
standfirst: Organisers of Black Lives Matter protest had begun shouting, ‘It’s over. Go home’. This blog is closedl>i> NSW police out in force for Sydney’s Black Lives Matter protesti>i> Sign up for Guardian Australia’s daily coronavirus emailr>i>i> Download the free Guardian app to get the most important news notificationsi>l>
