lead_paragraph: good morning, this is richard parkin bringing you the main stories and must-reads on thursday 27 august.

headline: katy bourne: 'police officers want to show solidarity with those protesting against racism'
standfirst: The Sussex police and crime commissioner on the Black Lives Matter protests and how the force is tackling domestic abuse during lockdown
lead_paragraph: “the mood of the officers i have spoken to is one of disgust, disbelief and disappointment that the actions of a handful of police officers on the other side of the world could potentially undo decades of progress in re-establishing public trust in policing,” says katy bourne, the police and crime commissioner for sussex.

headline: essential poll: 64% of australians fear businesses will suffer if jobkeeper is withdrawn early
standfirst: Large majority also believe Black Lives Matter protests put community at risk of Covid-19 but 62% say local protesters’ demands were justified
lead_paragraph: australians are worried that businesses will be put at risk if the morrison government withdraws the wage subsidy jobkeeper prematurely and there is a substantial second wave of covid-19 infections, according to the latest guardian essential poll.

headline: lapd and district attorney investigate george floyd photo with ‘you take my breath away’ caption
standfirst: ‘People will find my wrath,’ police chief says if inquiry confirms report that Valentine-like format was circulated among officers
lead_paragraph: the los angeles district attorney and the police department are investigating after a police officer reported that an image of george floyd had been made into a mock-valentine meme featuring the words “you take my breath away” and circulated among officers.

headline: colbert: america has 'a tremendous opportunity, but to do what?'
standfirst: Late-night hosts discuss the popularity of the protests for Black Lives Matter, the unpopularity of Trump and calls to ‘defund the police’
lead_paragraph: on the late show, stephen colbert examined the resilience of the protest movement in the wake of george floyd’s killing by police officer derek chauvin in minneapolis. polls show the majority of americans support the movement; one poll found that support for the black lives matter movement among americans has jumped to 53% from 42% a month ago. “so, just over half of american voters believe black people have the right to live,” said colbert. “good news…? it’s a start.”

headline: in lockdown we have built our resilience and confronted racism. we must keep going | dawn butler
standfirst: I was already facing an overload of personal grief. Then the killing of George Floyd opened up generational wounds
lead_paragraph: at the  beginning of lockdown i had this fantasy, like a lot of other people, that i would have time to tidy my house, give it a spring clean, pick up my violin and learn to play it again, and rest my soul. but it is hard to fathom how much sad news we would all face. as for so many other people, every morning – with its former routine of getting ready, having an hour’s trip into work – was disrupted. i could just have a quick shower and put on a top half for the meetings. i would roll out of bed and on to the computer, and there i would stay until i was called by the grumblings of my belly to get something to eat. and i would not leave the computer until 9pm or 10pm. i had to keep going: i could feel the desperation in the voices of the people i spoke to.

headline: minnesota charges three more officers over george floyd killing and elevates chauvin murder charge
standfirst: Attorney general increases Chauvin’s charge to second-degree murder and charges officers J Alexander Kueng, Tou Thao and Thomas Lane for aiding and abetting murderl>i> George Floyd protests – live coveragei>i> George Floyd coverage in fulli>l>
lead_paragraph: the minnesota attorney general, keith ellison, has announced charges against three former police officers in the death of  george floyd, and increased the charge against the officer who kneeled on the man’s neck.

headline: the only republican to vote in favor of george floyd bill said it was an accident
standfirst: l>i>Lance Gooden said he pushed wrong voting button on police billi>i>Conservative from Texas has now amended the official recordi>l>
lead_paragraph: when the us house of representatives tallied up lawmakers’ votes on wednesday for the george floyd justice in policing act, all but a single republican had opposed the bill.

headline: john lewis knew civil rights did not end with voting rights or barack obama | peniel e joseph
standfirst: The Georgia congressman’s life was more complex than tributes might make out. His embrace of Black Lives Matter shows he knew racist oppression never came close to ending
lead_paragraph: the  death of john lewis, the alabama-born civil rights activist, freedom rider and student leader turned georgia congressman, represents a generational transition in america’s long struggle for black freedom, dignity and citizenship. a disciple of dr martin luther king jr who experienced brutal and repeated acts of violence by racist white law enforcement and vigilantes that left him with permanent physical scars, including a cracked skull, lewis remained stubbornly resolute in his insistence that black life mattered.

headline: the black lives matter backlash is generating its own fake culture war | chaminda jayanetti
standfirst: A panicked right spurs controversy where there is none in order to discredit a perfectly reasonable set of demands
lead_paragraph: pity the poor culture warrior, their mental gymnastics burning far more calories than pre-corona gym sessions ever could.r/>r/>a statue was torn down, and they demanded people follow the proper channels. statues were taken down via the “proper channels”, and they decried the panicked response. reviews were announced to avoid a panicked response, and they raged against the reviews. when all else fails, they just conjure controversy out of thin air. r/>r/>take the telegraph. last week it  claimed that the future of a 22-year-old statue of the roman emperor constantine outside york minster was being “looked at”, after church officials “received complaints that the roman emperor supported slavery”. the story was then picked up by the daily mail. r/>r/>there was one problem. york minster swiftly clarified it had not received a single complaint about the statue, and ruled out removing it.r/>r/>this is part of a pattern. shortly after edward colston’s statue was torn down in bristol, boris johnson played up the threat to the westminster statue of winston churchill. hardly anyone was calling for its removal, but johnson made it the centre of his response to the black lives matter protests, and the telegraph duly  plastered it across the front page. r/>r/>write-ups of the churchill statue also  focused on the role of london mayor sadiq khan, a go-to hate figure on the nationalist right. this tactic was repeated recently, when newspapers roped meghan markle into their  coverage of prince harry’s “support for a ban” (actually a review that almost certainly won’t lead to a ban) of the song swing low, sweet chariot by the rugby football union. r/>r/>the drivers of this dynamic are not hard to identify. black lives matter is a movement, larger and broader than the organisations that bear its name. it challenges the privileges of the majority who do not experience racism, and the image that majority has of britain and its history. and some of that majority take at least some of the movement’s arguments on board - while others lash out against it.r/>r/>those who lash out are less numerous than you might imagine. polling conducted days after colston’s statue was removed found  most respondents agreed with the stated aims of the black lives matter movement. only 15% disagreed – around one in seven. respondents were more evenly divided on the removal of slavery-related statues, and displayed outright hostility to removing westminster’s churchill statue.r/>r/>but the one in seven who oppose even black lives matter’s broad aims are overrepresented in the rightwing press, on talk radio and the broader network of rage merchants on social media. the organisations they work for claim to represent the unheard british majority, but they do not. they are aghast at the concept of structural racism, which implicates people and institutions far beyond their comfort zone of condemning neo-nazis and football thugs. r/>r/>their interests are not served by tackling racialised economic inequality. the notion that unequal outcomes have structural causes affronts their smug certainty that it’s all about “personal responsibility”. and, of course, their bottom lines are not harmed by whipping up rage. r/>r/>the problem is that they cannot win fighting against the basic principles of this movement because the public are broadly in favour of them. so their answer is to focus on what people are against, find examples of that, no matter how tenuous, and use them to discredit an entire political project.r/>r/>the irony is that these critics of black lives matter call it divisive. given that the campaign challenges britain’s self-image, its understanding of its history, and structural discrimination against a minority, what is notable is how little division it has provoked – contrast the support for blm in both the us and the uk to the widespread antipathy towards martin luther king in the united states of the 1960s. it makes angry people very angry, but they are in the minority.r/>r/>instead, it is supporters of the populist right who are desperate to stoke division by reducing issues of fundamental importance to ephemeral noise and fake news. their careers, and their ideology, depend on it.

headline: hank willis thomas: 'the work will not be complete in our lifetime'
standfirst: The artist talks about the Black Lives Matter movement, his latest timely sculpture and why it’s more important than ever for artists to use their voices to challenge power
lead_paragraph: in atlanta, the beltline eastside trail recently saw a new addition to its landscape: a new public artwork by the historic fourth ward park, close to the birthplace of dr martin luther king jr.

headline: northampton manager keith curle not in favour of rooney rule
standfirst: l>i>Curle is one of only five BAME managers in the EFLi>i>Premier League reiterates backing for Black Lives Matteri>l>
lead_paragraph: keith curle, the northampton manager, has said high-profile black, asian and minority ethnic players interested in coaching should not expect to walk into a job and warned they must prove their credentials by gaining experience.

headline: the uk government responded to black lives matter – by protecting statues | the secret barrister
standfirst: Our justice system is in tatters, yet what may be the first piece of bipartisan legislation to pass is one protecting the feelings of concrete
lead_paragraph: the government’s response to the protests of the past week followed a predictable pattern. step 1: a flurry of headlines  promising: “violent protesters face jail within 24 hours”, optimism unencumbered by any understanding of the law, procedural fairness or how covid-19-struck criminal courts are operating in practice. step 2: announce longer prison sentences for something.

headline: sydney's black lives matter protest to go ahead despite organisers losing court appeal
standfirst: Organisers say they have a Covid-19 safety plan for the rally and will ensure attendees adhere to public health rules l>i> Sign up for Guardian Australia’s coronavirus emailr>i>i> Download the free Guardian app to get the most important news notificationsi>l>
lead_paragraph: organisers have vowed tuesday’s black lives matter rally will go ahead in sydney despite the new south wales court of appeal effectively upholding an earlier decision that the protest was a prohibited public assembly under the current public health regulations.

headline: supreme court rules in favour of police, banning sydney's black lives matter protest
standfirst: Family of David Dungay Jr says rally to call for justice will proceed on Tuesday
lead_paragraph: the new south wales supreme court has ruled in favour of police, effectively banning a black lives matter protest planned for tuesday in sydney – but activists say the rally will go ahead.

headline: england cricket team to wear black lives matter badge against west indies
standfirst: l>i>Root: ‘Important to show solidarity with the black community’i>i>Use of symbol in sport now being distanced from political groupi>l>
lead_paragraph: england’s cricketers are to wear black lives matter badges on the collar of their shirts during the upcoming test series against west indies, calling it an “act of solidarity” with their caribbean opponents.

headline: 100 playwrights and actors join forces in new theatre project challenging australian identity
standfirst: Nakkiah Lui, Suzie Miller and more in series exploring issues faced by the country in a world transformed by Covid-19 and Black Lives Matter
lead_paragraph: richard frankland, nakkiah lui and suzie miller are among 50 australian playwrights joining forces with 50 actors including miranda tapsell, jack thompson and tasma walton to challenge australia’s sense of identity post-coronavirus in a new series of plays.

headline: vivica a fox: 'black lives matter is going to be trump's demise'
standfirst: The actor has pushed the envelope for portrayals of black women and been up close with the president and Harvey Weinstein. “You come at me crazy, it’s gonna be on like popcorn,” she warns
lead_paragraph: it is 8am and vivica a fox, the star of two independence day films, two seasons of curb your enthusiasm, both parts of kill bill and, latterly, two sharknado movies, has been awake for hours. she sprang out of bed at 4am, pottered around and “did a little social media post” about her podcast,  hustling with vivica a fox. it’s a spin-off from  every day i’m hustling, her memoir-cum-self-help manual which contains health tips (“hydrate, girl!”), social media advice (“use hashtags to join big conversations”) and underwear secrets (“i’m a g-string type of gal”). once the podcast was online this morning, she explains, “i said to myself: ‘let’s get some coffee on. it’s m>showtimem>!’”

headline: lewis hamilton: 'watching george floyd brought up so much suppressed emotion'
standfirst: Hamilton has just equalled the record of seven F1 world championships – many believe he is the greatest driver of all time. And this year, more than ever, he has been leading the fight against racism
lead_paragraph: at the end of 2019, lewis hamilton had a realisation about formula one. “i was looking at pictures of all the teams – they do these team photos in front of the garage or on the track – and they’ve posted all these pictures and i’m like, there are no people of colour in any of these teams.”

lead_paragraph: the top editor of the philadelphia inquirer has resigned following an uproar over a headline bemoaning property damage incurred during the protests against police brutality and racial injustice.

headline: 20 must-see documentaries to explain the world in 2020

lead_paragraph: director: lisa bryant m> netflixm>

headline: donations to black lives matter uk and other groups top £1m
standfirst: Funding floods in to groups including Black Minds Matter and Black Protest Legal Support
lead_paragraph: black lives matter uk has said it is touched by people’s generosity after donations towards combating the causes and consequences of racism reached more than £1m.

headline: how the electric slide became the black lives matter protest dance
standfirst: This is a moment of movement: as people gather to push for change, collective dancing has become activism in motion
lead_paragraph: the protests sparked by the killing of george floyd have spread across the world and as many have said: this is not a moment, it’s a movement. but it is also a moment m>of m>movement, as the protests have been accompanied by outbreaks of dancing. a common sight on social media and light news spots are the  electric slide and the  cupid shuffle, but you can also see the  cha-cha slide,  macarena,  krumping and the  haka dance.

headline: obama shares advice on how to make george floyd protests 'a turning point'
standfirst: Former president applauded peaceful protesters and suggested demonstrations could translate to ‘effective action’l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: barack obamatrong> trong>has once again weighed in on the  george floydtrong> trong>protests gripping much of america and attracting global attention, suggesting the demonstrations could translate to “peaceful, sustained and effective action” to address structural racism.

headline: the guardian view on black lives matter worldwide: a common cause | editorial
standfirst: An American death has sparked global protest and confronted other countries with uncomfortable truths
lead_paragraph: george floyd’s name is now known around the globe; his death has sparked protests from berlin to mexico city. the extraordinary cruelty of  href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/george-floyd" title="">his killing has shocked the world. but his death has resonated so widely not because it was exceptional, but because it was not. not exceptional in the us, where the toll of african americans who have died at police hands is long and shameful. and not, unfortunately, exceptional elsewhere.

headline: defunding the police and abolishing prisons in australia are not radical ideas |  robyn oxley for indigenousx
standfirst: Ongoing Aboriginal deaths in custody, high rates of incarceration, and police brutality require us to dismantle these systems
lead_paragraph: the past few months have sparked conversations about defunding the police, specifically through the black lives matter protests held around the world. i want to explain, from a criminological point of view, why this is imperative.

headline: teargassed, beaten up, arrested: what freedom of the press looks like in the us right now
standfirst: As protests spread across the US, journalists are being attacked by police forces and even sustaining serious injuriesl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: caught in the middle of a scrum covering protests in minneapolis on saturday, photojournalist ed ou could feel his hands and face were wet. for a long time, he didn’t know if it was teargas, pepper spray, or blood – in the end, it turned out to be a combination of all three.

headline: klan leader charged over driving car into black lives matter protesters
standfirst: l>i>Harry Rogers charged after incident in Richmond, Virginiai>i>Officials investigating possibility of hate crimes chargesi>l>
lead_paragraph: a self-described ku klux klan leader has been charged with assault after driving his car into a group of black lives matter protesters in virginia.

headline: aunt jemima brand to change name and logo due to racial stereotyping
standfirst: Quaker Foods, which has long been criticized for the logo and name, makes announcement about pancake mix and syrup brand amid Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: one of america’s most recognizable but unreconstructed household brands, aunt jemima pancake products, will change its name and image in an effort by the brand to distance itself from racial stereotypes.

headline: morning mail: chauvin found guilty of george floyd murder, rudd and turnbull on climate, chelsea out of super league

lead_paragraph: good morning. a verdict has just been announced in the trial over the police killing of trong>george floydtrong>. trong>murdoch mediatrong> is under fire from the former us director of national intelligence, and trong>australia’s flawed vaccinationtrong> program is having devastating ramifications for those stuck abroad.

headline: john boyega's rousing black lives matter speech wins praise and support
standfirst: Boyega’s Star Wars co-stars were among those congratulating the actor on a passionate address at anti-racism demonstration in London
lead_paragraph: john boyega, the actor who followed up last week’s blistering attack on social media racism with a powerful speech at a black lives matter rally in london, has won widespread praise for his actions.

headline: kimberlé crenshaw: the woman who revolutionised feminism – and landed at the heart of the culture wars
standfirst: From police brutality to sexual harassment, the lawyer fights to ensure black women’s experiences are not ignored. So why are her ideas being denounced?r>
lead_paragraph: it was october 1991 and  anita hill was testifying against clarence thomas. at the judge’s us supreme court confirmation hearing, hill, his former aide, claimed he had sexually harassed her. kimberlé crenshaw was assisting hill’s legal team and felt dejected and exhausted. as she left the capitol building in washington dc that day, she saw a group of african americans, mostly women, gathered at the bottom of the steps in a prayer circle. she let out a sigh of relief and walked towards them.

headline: donald trump threatens to deploy army as teargas fired so he can pose at church
standfirst: Authorities suddenly target demonstrators outside White House, clearing way for a presidential photo opportunityl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: donald trump has threatened to deploy the us military to quell civil unrest – even as teargas was fired against nearby peaceful protesters to grant him a photo opportunity.

headline: britain needs leadership on race inequality. not just another review | david lammy
standfirst: If Boris Johnson is serious about Black Lives Matter he should act now – not make an announcement buried in an article about Winston Churchill
lead_paragraph: it feels like groundhog day each time i am asked whether racial discrimination still exists in britain. we already know that  9% of black people are unemployed, compared with  4% across all ethnic groups. there is still a  13% attainment gap between black and white students at university. you are  nine times more likely to be stopped and searched if you are black than if you are white. out of every 100 professors,  only two are ethnic minority women. it is still the case that  51% of children locked up in prison are from ethnic minorities, even though black, asian and minority-ethnic people make up 14% of the uk’s total population.

headline: a boot is crushing the neck of american democracy | cornel west
standfirst: The fundamental question at this moment is: can the United States be reformed?l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: here we go again. another black person killed by the us police. another wave of multiracial resistance. another cycle of race talk on the corporate media. another display of diversity with neoliberal leaders, and another white backlash soon to come. yet this time might be a turning point.

headline: i was kidnapped by police for nine hours for being a black lives matter protester
standfirst: Violence against largely peaceful protesters is escalating, no matter how much officials downplay the terms they use
lead_paragraph: there’s no fitting comparison for the sensation of teargas.

headline: it took a death overseas to take the blinkers off here. australia, the time has come | joe williams
standfirst: I pulled together a Black Lives Matter march in the regional city where I grew up. And Wagga showed up, in big numbersr>
lead_paragraph: “all lives matter – when black lives matter.” that was the chant as it echoed down baylis street, the main street of the community i grew up in the heart of wiradjuri country, wagga wagga.

headline: nsw police chief vows to block black lives matter protest planned for sydney
standfirst: Mick Fuller says Victoria’s protests put lives at risk but state health authorities have said ‘no known episodes of transmission occurred’
lead_paragraph: nsw police commissioner mick fuller has vowed he will go to court to block a black lives matter protest planned for sydney next week, citing the event’s potential to spread coronavirus.

headline: removing the statue of black lives matter activist jen reid was a mistake | letters
standfirst: trong>Jon Bloomfield trong>on claims that the statue is an appropriation, because the artist is white, trong>Lyn Howardtrong> on what the empty plinth now says, while trong>Clive Sykes trong>has a suggestion
lead_paragraph: your report ( href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jul/15/the-day-bristol-woke-up-to-a-new-statue" title="">the day bristol woke up to a new statue, 15 july) and feature ( href="https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2020/jul/15/marc-quinn-statue-colston-jen-reid-black-lives-matter-bristol" title="">g2, 15 july) on the bristol statue of jen reid created by the artist marc quinn were marred by the comments of thomas j price in a different article ( href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2020/jul/15/allyship-or-stunt-marc-quinns-blm-statue-divides-art-world" title="">allyship or stunt? marc quinn’s blm statue divides art world, 15 july). he claims that quinn has “created the votive statue to appropriation” and it should have been “a black artist’s output, not that of a white cis man”. this is reactionary politics disguised in obscure, trendy jargon.

headline: sydney black lives matter rally: nsw court rules protest is illegal
standfirst: Prime minister Scott Morrison urges Australians to stay away amid fears a series of planned weekend rallies risk spreading coronavirus
lead_paragraph: scores of protesters and police are set to converge on central sydney on saturday despite the new south wales supreme court ruling a rally drawing attention to police treatment of indigenous australians is illegal and should not go ahead.

headline: buffalo officers filmed shoving 75-year-old protester charged with assault

headline: the armed white men who terrorized philadelphia’s black lives matter supporters
standfirst: Protesters reported men ripping up signs, yelling homophobic slurs, and spitting on people. And the police greeted them as friends
lead_paragraph: as thousands in philadelphia marched to end police brutality against black americans on monday, a group of white men carrying bats, golf clubs, and other improvised weapons gathered in the city’s fishtown neighborhood.

headline: grindr dating app removes ethnicity filter to support black lives matter
standfirst: Feature will not be part of app’s next release following accusations of hypocrisy
lead_paragraph: grindr is removing an “ethnicity filter” from its dating app as part of its support for the black lives matter movement, the company announced on monday.

headline: leave means leave, nigel! now farage is out, will lbc stop hiring toxic blowhards?
standfirst: The Brexiter was shown the door after comparing Black Lives Matter protesters to the Taliban. But he’s far from the radio station’s only problem
lead_paragraph: it’s tina i feel sorry for. this week she rang  lbc’s breakfast show to tell host  nick ferrari what toppling statues of racist britons means to her as a british woman of african-caribbean ancestry. could she get her point across? not a chance. every time she tried to air her views, ferrari’s voice cut through hers. “tina, tina, tina,” ferrari said in his trademark oleaginously patronising simper as if speaking to a dim child. tina complained about him interrupting her, but ferrari wouldn’t be silenced. taking down statues is illegal. end of. “i can’t breathe” is a black lives matter slogan. “i can’t get airtime” might be tina’s.

headline: stephen colbert interviews john bolton: 'how could you be naive?'
standfirst: The Late Show host presses Trump’s former adviser on his tell-all book, and Trevor Noah asks corporate America to take Black Lives Matter beyond tweets
lead_paragraph: after  criticizing john bolton last week for holding his criticism of the trump administration for a lucrative book deal, stephen colbert hammered trump’s former national security adviser in an interview on tuesday’s late show.

headline: us urged to address racial injustice or risk further instability in new report
standfirst: International Crisis Group analysis implored Trump and officials to stop courting conflict with incendiary languagel>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: a failure to confront the “deep pain and injustice borne by the african american community” in response to the police killing of george floyd will result in further “division and instability” in the united states,  according to a new analysis by the international crisis group.

headline: labour's dawn butler: 'people threatened to kill me. i’ve been attacked on the tube'
standfirst: Her support for Black Lives Matter forced the MP to close her office. She says ending racism is the fight of her generation – and she has no qualms about upsetting Labour’s leader
lead_paragraph: at the start of april, dawn butler was a well-liked figure in parliament and looked like  a strong candidate for deputy leader of the labour party. an experienced parliamentarian, 50 years old and a party member for more than 30 of them, she had been a minister in gordon brown’s government and served in jeremy corbyn’s shadow cabinet. in december 2009, she had been the first black woman to speak from the dispatch box. she also had strong union links, having worked for the gmb and, before that, the public and commercial services union. she had a life before – and halfway through – westminster, working as a computer programmer and then an employment-service trainer.

headline: the brands rushing to defend black lives used to silence us. does it get more shameless? | candice frederick
standfirst: Vague platitudes about solidarity aren’t enough – not from organizations that discarded Kaepernick for taking a kneel>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: when i first noticed that there were non-black faces in the myriad protests demanding justice for the police murder of george floyd across the world over the last few days, i thought: it’s nice to see that oppressed black people aren’t the only ones speaking out about the oppression of black people. because generally that’s been the case. but that feeling of relief dissolved after big organizations such as  the nfl and  the cw, as well as stars like  lea michele, jumped on that bandwagon to align themselves with the fight for black humanity. because these are some of the same platforms that have silenced us.

headline: george floyd protests: more than 3,000 arrested in los angeles county

lead_paragraph: more than 3,000 protesters have been arrested in los angeles county during the demonstrations against the police killing of george floyd in minneapolis, police said, the overwhelming majority of them for non-violent offenses.

lead_paragraph: the statue of slave trader edward colston was replaced in bristol on wednesday morning – with a sculpture of one of the protesters whose anger brought him down.

headline: republicans push ‘tsunami’ of harsh anti-protest laws after blm rallies
standfirst: Critics say the bills introduced across the country would infringe free speech rights and disproportionately target people of color
lead_paragraph: after a year where  black lives matter demonstrations saw americans begin to re-address and rethink racial inequality in the nation, a pushback from predominantly republican lawmakers is on the horizon, with 29 states in the us moving to introduce draconian anti-protest laws.

headline: george floyd protests in california stretch from biggest cities to smaller towns

lead_paragraph: california erupted in protest alongside the rest of the country over the weekend, with hundreds of thousands taking to the streets over the police killing of george floyd in minneapolis.

headline: police criticized over heavy-handed response to peaceful protests across us

lead_paragraph: after a night of vandalism and police aggression against protesters across the united states, the response of law enforcement officers to widespread public demonstrations came under heavy criticism as demands grew to ensure the right of protesters to peaceably assemble.

headline: george floyd killing: widespread curfews fail to stop fresh wave of protests across us
standfirst: Demonstrations continue after death ruled a homicide, as police use helicopters, teargas and pepper spray against protestersl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: cities witnessed another night of protests despite widespread curfews as sporadic unrest continued across the us one week after george floyd’s death, which autopsies on monday  ruled was a homicide.trong>r/>trong>r/>from new york to washington dc and from philadelphia to los angeles, many communities enacted curfews on monday, in some cases giving residents just hours’ or minutes’ notice.

headline: across america, police are responding to peaceful protests with violence | nathan robinson
standfirst: Police too often act like squads of armed thugs rather than compassionate and helpful community servantsl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the footage and photographs are disturbing. these lawless rioters are out of control. they have  driven an suv into a crowd,  tossed journalists to the ground and pepper-sprayed them,  beaten people with batons and even  blinded a woman in one eye. they have been launching  unprovoked attacks on peaceful, law-abiding citizens exercising their constitutional rights. the violent behavior of these mobs should be condemned by all. we need to restore order: someone must stop the police.

headline: 'make it stop': george floyd's brother calls on congress to act over police violence
standfirst: Philonise Floyd makes impassioned plea to ensure brother’s death ‘isn’t in vain’ and urges US lawmakers to ‘do the right thing’l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: hours after george floyd was laid to rest in houston, his younger brother made an impassioned plea to congress to prevent his death from becoming just “another name” on an ever-growing list of black americans killed by police.

headline: husband of la district attorney charged after pointing gun at black lives matter protesters
standfirst: David Lacey, whose wife Jackie Lacey is running for re-election, has been charged with multiple firearm assaults
lead_paragraph: the husband of the los angeles district attorney has been charged with multiple firearm assaults after he pointed a gun at black lives matter activists and said, “i will shoot you.”

headline: stormzy on black lives matter: 'if we weren't oppressed, we wouldn't be shouting'
standfirst: Rapper talks to the BBC about the ‘hundreds, thousands of years of real pain’ suffered by black people
lead_paragraph: the  black lives matter movement represents “hundreds, thousands of years” of “real pain”,  stormzy has told the bbc.

headline: 'i ain’t waiting': john boyega shows movie stars what political engagement looks like
standfirst: His Hyde Park speech is a teachable moment in the history of race, racism and celebrity. He’s part of a vigorous, distinguished traditionl>i> John Boyega’s rousing Black Lives Matter speech wins praise and supporti>l>
lead_paragraph: already, the  sneery backlash has begun – as so much trumpism is founded on that keynote of faux-underdog self-pity in the face of supposedly all-powerful  liberalism. when actor john boyega, from star wars and attack the block, addressed protesters at a  black lives matter rally in london’s hyde park, he said: “i’m speaking to you from my heart. look, i don’t know if i’m going to have a career after this, but fuck that.” social media exploded with knowing jeers and giggling gotchas about how, actually, boyega m>hadm> to protest, or else his career would suffer! people on twitter who had shown no very obvious knowledge of or interest in the issue of civil rights or hollywood politics before this, were suddenly intoxicated by their delicious paradox, and made boyega’s comments the pretext of once again righteously smashing the 5g mast of liberal power.

headline: hundreds of armed counter-protesters confront black lives matter rally in ohio
standfirst: Counter-protesters harassed group of peaceful demonstrators with rifles, bats and racial slurs in mostly white town of Bethel
lead_paragraph: a small and peaceful demonstration in an ohio town to support the black lives matter movement at the weekend was overwhelmed when hundreds of counter-protesters – some armed with rifles or baseball bats – harassed the group.

headline: man rescued by uk black lives matter protester is ex-police officer
standfirst: Bryn Male, who retired from British Transport Police in 2014, identified as man carried over shoulder of Patrick Hutchinson
lead_paragraph: the counter-protester carried to safety by a black lives matter protester last weekend is a former officer at british transport police, the force has confirmed.

headline: blm activists demonstrating against anti-protest bill 'targeted by police'
standfirst: Protesters report that officers at Monday’s demonstration approached black women and asked their names
lead_paragraph: activists behind many of last summer’s black lives matter protests have accused the police of targeting and harassing them in an effort to stop them from taking part in  demonstrations against a police bill.

headline: 'denigrated and discredited': how american journalists became targets during protests
standfirst: Members of the media have faced brutal crackdowns amid a national uprising. Many observers lay the blame with Trumpl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: a photographer who says she was blinded in one eye. a tv reporter surrounded and arrested by police live on air. a cameraman slammed in the chest with a riot shield while filming a peaceful protest outside the president’s home.

headline: mothers of black americans killed by police speak out: ‘nothing's changed’
standfirst: For years, these women marched demanding for justice – what’s different now, they say, is a generation hungry for changel>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: in his final moments of life, george floyd called for his mother as a white minneapolis police officer knelt on his neck in the street.

headline: george floyd killing: peaceful protests sweep america as calls for racial justice reach new heights
standfirst: Hundreds of thousands took to the streets on a day that saw grief and determination punctuated by moments of levityr>l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: hundreds of thousands of americans took to the streets, in big cities and small towns, from coast to coast, marking one of the the most expansive mobilizations yet in the nationwide protests against police violence and systemic racism sparked by the police killing of george floyd in minneapolis.

headline: this weekend has to be day one of rugby's fight against racism | ugo monye
standfirst: The Rugby Against Racism campaign was belatedly born this week, 25 years after the game turned professional and thanks in the main to the raised awareness brought by the Black Lives Matter movement
lead_paragraph: black lives matter. those three words – a statement distilled to its purest form – are the best explanation i can give as to why i will take a knee when rugby restarts on friday night. i am totally aware that the statement has been politicised and i strongly disagree with some of the things the organisation stands for, but there is one reason why pretty much every household has developed a greater understanding and awareness of anti-racism recently: the black lives matter movement.

headline: long-bailey's sacking sparks focus on reporting of us-israeli police links
standfirst: Claim that tactics used on George Floyd were learned during Israeli training emphatically denied
lead_paragraph: keir starmer’s decision  to sack rebecca long-bailey as shadow education secretary after she shared on twitter an interview with the actor maxine peake has focused attention on links between us police forces and their israeli counterparts – and how those connections have been reported by some media outlets in recent weeks.

headline: no masks, no water: new york protesters held in ‘abysmal’ conditions, experts say
standfirst: More than 2,000 people have been arrested in the city and the police treatment of those detained is emboldening peopler>l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: protesters in new york have been unnecessarily arrested and detained for as long as 48 hours in “abysmal” conditions without access to masks, food and water, according to legal experts.

headline: end scourge of white supremacy
standfirst: The London Recruits group, which has long fought against apartheid, calls on the British government to work with Black Lives Matter to tackle institutional racism
lead_paragraph: we the undersigned, members of a group known collectively as the london recruits, condemn the killing of george floyd at the hands of police. we condemn police and state brutality against black people in the us, uk and worldwide, and applaud the brave protesters who are risking their lives during a pandemic to say that black lives matter.

headline: 'she should be with us': louisville protesters remember breonna taylor
standfirst: People gathered to mourn the unarmed black woman shot dead by police in March – and vowed to never give up in the fight for justice
lead_paragraph: breonna taylor would have been 27 on friday, but most of the people who showed up in downtown louisville to mark that milestone did not know her. a lot probably wish they had never heard her name.

headline: the birth of a militia: how an armed group polices black lives matter protests
standfirst: In Utah, members of a militia claim their presence deters protesters from becoming violent and destroying the state
lead_paragraph: the utah citizens’ alarm is only a month old, and yet it already boasts 15,000-plus members.

headline: starbucks reverses stance and allows staff to wear black lives matter clothing
standfirst: Chain, which had banned attire that ‘advocated a political, religious or personal issue’, changes course after backlash
lead_paragraph: starbucks  said friday that employees will be allowed to wear clothing and accessories in support of black lives matter, responding to a backlash and boycott calls after the coffee chain banned staff from wearing their own t-shirts and pins supporting the movement.

headline: the day bristol toppled colston – and a nation began to search its soul
standfirst: When Edward Colston’s statue was toppled, colonialism and national memory became a part of the Black Lives Matter conversation. But what will change in the city?
lead_paragraph: after the statue of 17th-century slave trader edward colston was hauled to the ground last weekend, a series of black bristolians clambered on his empty plinth and spoke from the heart about racism and the struggle for equality in the city and beyond.

headline: black lives matter has exposed sport's underlying  failure to deal with racism | jonathan liew
standfirst: The discussion needs to go on every day and every week, once the protests have died down and live sport has started again
lead_paragraph: the premier league has decided that next week, black lives will matter. or at least, it has decreed – at the behest of several club captains – that for the opening round of fixtures when the season resumes next week,  the phrase “black lives matter” can be borne on players’ shirts, in place of their names. it hasn’t formally decided whether black lives will matter beyond next week or for the rest of the season. but rest assured it will be consulting key stakeholders and making an announcement in due course.

headline: the perils of being black in public: we are all christian cooper and george floyd | carolyn finney
standfirst: Too often, by default, black people are perceived as threats to white people’s physical safety. We need fundamental, consequential and absolute changel>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: in the summer of 1997, i lived in seattle. i worked at a temp job while preparing to start my master’s degree in the fall. i was walking to a bus stop after a day at the office, when i stepped into a pothole on the street and heard my ankle crack.

headline: families of trayvon martin and oscar grant on protests: 'white supremacy is on its way out'
standfirst: Relatives of Tamir Rice, Alton Sterling and other black Americans killed by police describe a brutal road ahead – but some voice hopel>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: “i am enraged. i am on fire.”

headline: ‘they set us up’: us police arrested over 10,000 protesters, many non-violent
standfirst: Over 10,000 people have been arrested around the US, as police regularly use pepper spray, rubber bullets, teargas and batonsl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: since george floyd’s death at the hands of police in minneapolis, minnesota, on 25 may,trong> trong> about 140 cities in  all 50 states throughout the us have seen protests and demonstrations in response to the killing.

headline: gushers? witches? and ... mitt romney? the surprise coalition backing black lives matter
standfirst: Support has come from some less expected, fringe groups and allies, sometimes in very inventive ways
lead_paragraph: the protests over george floyd’s death are unprecedented for a number of reasons – their size, their duration, their impact. but what’s also unprecedented is their diversity, and not just along the lines of race or geography.

headline: minneapolis lawmakers vow to disband police department in historic move
standfirst: City council members declare intent to ‘abolish’ embattled agency and replace with alternative model in wake of George Floyd’s killingl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the minneapolis city council has pledged to disband the city’s police department and replace it with a new system of public safety, a historic move that comes as calls to  defund law enforcement are sweeping the us.

headline: police marching with protesters: how some cities got it right and others didn't
standfirst: New Jersey produced some striking images as protests elsewhere descended into violence but relied on trust previously being builtl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: when larry hamm, a veteran activist with people’s organization for progress, kicked off last weekend’s protest in newark, new jersey, he asked the crowd what they wanted. the majority – though not all – said they wanted a peaceful protest.

headline: 'they turned holy ground into a battleground': clergy teargassed by washington police
standfirst: l>i>Christian leaders among peaceful protesters swept asidei>i>Police surged forward to clear space in front of St John’s churchi>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesr>i>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>

headline: nigerian president criticised over response to protests crackdown
standfirst: Muhammadu Buhari addresses nation but fails to mention shootings by security forces on Tuesday
lead_paragraph: nigeria’s president, muhammadu buhari, has called for an end to nationwide demonstrations against police brutality, but failed to directly mention the fatal shooting of peaceful protesters.

headline: what does 'defund the police' mean? the rallying cry sweeping the us – explained
standfirst: Activists have long advocated taking money from police and reinvesting it in services. The idea is now seeing a wave of supportl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the call to “defund the police” has  become a rallying cry at protests across america this week, and some lawmakers appear to be listening.

headline: manuel ellis killing: mayor calls for firing of officers involved in death of black man
standfirst: Victoria Woodards said she was ‘angered’ after footage surfaced of Ellis, who died in custody in March, being beaten l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the mayor of tacoma, washington, has called for the police officers involved in the  death of an african american man in march to be fired and prosecuted after cellphone footage surfaced of him being beaten while lying on the ground.

headline: angry donald trump calls on governors to 'dominate' george floyd protests
standfirst: l>i>President rants at governors, police and security officialsi>i>Law enforcement must ‘dominate’ or ‘look like a bunch of jerks’i>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: donald trump has urged us governors and law enforcement officials to take a more forceful approach in responding to protests sparked by the death of  george floyd, an african american man who pleaded for air as a white minneapolis police officer pressed his knee against his neck for several minutes.

headline: george floyd killing: hundreds of thousands turn out for huge protests across us
standfirst: l>i>Large demonstrations in Washington, Chicago, Philadelphia and elsewherei>i>Memorial held in North Carolina, where Floyd was borni>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: hundreds of thousands of demonstrators marched in cities across the united states on saturday in what were some of the largest protests yet seen in the unrest triggered by the killing of george floyd by a white minneapolis police officer.

headline: anger as local police union chief calls george floyd a 'violent criminal'
standfirst: l>i>Lt Bob Kroll says protests organised by ‘terrorist movement’i>i>Ex-Minneapolis police chief calls Kroll ‘a disgrace to the badge’i>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the president of the minneapolis police union has written to its members calling george floyd a “violent criminal”, describing those protesting over his death as terrorists and criticizing the city’s political leadership for not authorizing greater use of force to stop the rioting.

headline: minneapolis police chief: all four officers ‘complicit’ in george floyd's death
standfirst: l>i>Only one officer, Derek Chauvin, has been charged with murderi>i>Philonise Floyd: ‘They’re at home sleeping in their bed, relaxing’i>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the chief of minneapolis police spoke directly to the brother of george floyd on sunday night,  dramatically cutting into a tv interview to say “all four officers” involved in floyd’s death were “complicit”, though only one has been charged with murder.

headline: premier league issues restart rules with no spitting or crowding officials
standfirst: l>i>Players will wear Black Lives Matter and NHS badgesr>i>i>Minute’s silence for those affected by Covid-19 will be heldr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: premier league players have been told not to spit, clear their nose or surround match officials when the season restarts, and will be directed towards a “celebration camera” after scoring in closed-doors matches.

headline: 'slide to illiberalism': ex-general joins chorus of condemnation of trump
standfirst: John Allen warns that politicisation of the military could be the beginning of the end of ‘the American experiment’l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the retired marine general who led the global coalition against isis and commanded us forces in afghanistan has warned that donald trump’s actions this week could start a us “ slide into illiberalism” and the beginning of the end of “the american experiment”.

headline: angela davis: ‘we knew the role of the police was to protect white supremacy’
standfirst: The veteran civil rights campaigner on growing up in segregated America, the opportunity of the Black Lives Matter movement and what inspires her to keep fightingr>
lead_paragraph: it is 1972, and angela davis is answering a question about whether she approves of the use of violence by  the black panthers. she is sitting against a backdrop of powder-blue breeze blocks, the walls of a california state prison cell. dressed in a red turtleneck, with her  signature afro and a lit cigarette, she stares at the swedish interviewer – almost straight through him – as she delivers her reply: “you ask me whether i approve of violence? that just doesn’t make any sense at all. whether i approve of guns? i grew up in birmingham, alabama. some very, very good friends of mine were killed by bombs – bombs that were planted by racists. i remember, from the time i was very small, the sound of bombs exploding across the street and the house shaking … that’s why, when someone asks me about violence, i find it incredible because it means the person asking that question has absolutely no idea what black people have gone through and experienced in this country from the time the first black person was kidnapped from the shores of africa.”

headline: us police have a history of violence against black people. will it ever stop?
standfirst: The bereaved and brutalized have been calling for justice for years but the Trump administration reversed Obama’s tentative steps towards reforml>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: in ferguson, missouri, mike brown’s body lay lifeless on the street for four hours after he was shot dead by a white officer.  witnesses described him holding his hands up in surrender before he was killed.

headline: un experts condemn modern-day ‘racial terror’ lynchings in us
standfirst: Monitors made direct link between police killings of unarmed black American men and racial lynchings in segregation erar>l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: a group of 66 united nations human rights monitors have issued a devastating critique of what they call modern-day “racial terror” lynchings in the us in the form of state-sponsored police violence against black americans.

headline: how to watch police shows in the age of black lives matter | elias rodriques
standfirst: The crime genre glorifies police violence, but should we ban such shows, or reappraise them with a critical eye?
lead_paragraph: in a 2017 episode of  brooklyn nine-nine, the acclaimed police comedy show, sergeant terry jeffords (played by terry crews) is racially profiled while walking in his own neighbourhood. he later tells his captain, raymond holt (played by andre braugher), who is also black, that he wants to lodge a complaint. captain holt responds that he should not; doing so will make it difficult for him to advance in the nypd, which comes with the prospect of making an even bigger change. this is also the route, holt explains, that he took: he endured years of abuse as the only black, gay detective to become police captain so that he might make the nypd less racist and anti-queer. in either case, the culprit is clear: racism in the nypd. the solution is equally clear: change from within.

headline: protests continue as us defense secretary rejects trump’s demand for troops
standfirst: Esper says he disagrees with Trump’s wish to use troops as crowd gathers on Capitol Hill to protest George Floyd’s killingl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: protests over the death of  george floyd continued across the us on wednesday, after a largely peaceful night. as demonstrators returned to the streets, police chiefs called for reform – and the us secretary of defense publicly rejected donald trump’s threat to deploy combat troops.

headline: 'get your knee off our necks’ sharpton delivers moving eulogy at floyd memorial

lead_paragraph: the family of  george floyd and other invitees gathered amid sobs and bubbling rage on thursday afternoon in minneapolis for the first of three memorial services across the country planned to mark the violent death of the 46-year-old african american man under the knee of a white police officer on 25 may.

headline: boris johnson says removing statues is 'to lie about our history'
standfirst: PM says George Floyd protests have been ’hijacked by extremists intent on violence’
lead_paragraph: boris johnson has said removing statues of controversial figures is “to lie about our history”, as he argued that national protests in the wake of the death of george floyd in the us had been taken over by extremists.

headline: ‘rotten racism’: newspapers around the world react to george floyd protests

headline: a photo op as protests swirled: how trump came to walk to the church
standfirst: Trump’s decision to walk to St John’s to be photographed with the Bible was another extraordinary decision made on the hoofl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: early one saturday morning in may 1970, richard nixon, under enormous pressure,  left the white house, seeking to talk to people protesting against the vietnam war around the lincoln memorial. it was a strange moment in american history but a hugely symbolic one, foreshadowing a president’s fall.

headline: cynthia nixon: 'will donald trump leave quietly? i don't know'
standfirst: The actor who once ran to be governor of New York is political to her bones, passionate about trans rights, Black Lives Matter and the future of the left. She discusses the rise of Trump – and why she’s still optimisticr>
lead_paragraph: cynthia nixon zooms on to my screen from some decking in long island. the blue-grey sky is dramatically ominous, a sea breeze blows her hair into photogenic chaos and she is, of course, pretty damn famous – especially to those of us of the  sex and the city generation. so the overall effect is of watching a film, but one that is talking straight to you. yet, within what feels like barely five seconds, we are discussing the end of democracy, with only the briefest detour to cover the impact wrought on her new york home by coronavirus.

headline: 'words of a dictator': trump's threat to deploy military raises spectre of fascism
standfirst: The president suggested the US could use troops against Americans – true to the instincts of a man surrounded by sycophantsl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: “when fascism comes to america, it will be wrapped in the flag and carrying a cross,” goes an oft-quoted line of uncertain origin.

headline: publishers want more black authors. why have they silenced us for so long? | candice carty-williams
standfirst: As Black Lives Matter protests take place across the world, the publishing world is rushing to support those ‘ignored by the mainstream’. Who is the mainstream, then?
lead_paragraph: the publishing industry is stilted and archaic. i worked in it for seven years, and left due to reasons i can’t legally talk about. though, in that time, i was able to enforce and oversee m>somem> steps towards sustainable change. at 4th estate, an imprint of harpercollins, i started the guardian 4th estate bame short story prize (still going strong, five years later). staggered by the lack of underrepresented voices, i knew i had to do something, m>anythingm> to give those voices a way to permeate the industry.

headline: blm groups play key role in may day ‘kill the bill’ uk protests

lead_paragraph: black activists have played lead roles in the “kill the bill” coalition, which has led  thousands of people to march through london and thousands of others to join protests in cities around the country against the police, crime, sentencing and courts bill on saturday.

headline: george floyd killing: pressure grows for other three officers to face charges
standfirst: l>i>J Alexander Kueng, Tou Thao and Thomas Lane were at scenei>i>County attorney said last Friday he expected chargesi>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the minneapolis police officer who spent almost nine minutes kneeling on the neck of george floyd was  charged with murder on friday. but the fate of his colleagues, who stood by as floyd’s strained cries grew silent, is yet to be determined.

headline: ‘apathy is no longer a choice’: will the george floyd protests energize young voters?

headline: leah harvey on small island: 'we are sharing the story of why our country is the way it is'

lead_paragraph: trong>did you read andrea levy’s orange prize-winning novel before coming to this production?r/>trong>i had an interesting journey leading up to this play; i auditioned for a part in the tv adaptation of levy’s the long song and as part of the research for that i watched [the tv adaptation of] small island on iplayer. a few months later, i was auditioning to play hortense in this production. i picked up the book and couldn’t put it down. it was quite an adventure to go on. i was reading it in the knowledge that i’d be playing this character so i was looking for secret nuggets for the part.

headline: burnley to show support for black lives matter in 'clear stand' against banner

headline: from black lives matter to bleak house: david lammy picks the best books about justice

lead_paragraph: in 2016, the writer and lawyer michelle alexander said the shooting of michael brown in ferguson, missouri, would come to be seen as a “critical turning point. if it winds up not being a turning point, it will be because we did not do our job.” nearly two months on since the death of george floyd, black lives matter has become one of the largest demonstrations in history, but it is still not clear whether a turning point has been reached.

headline: morning mail: cormann told to listen, 14-year-old crash driver charged, how to foster cats

lead_paragraph: good morning, this is james murray bringing you the main stories and must-reads on 8 june 2020.

headline: 'a voice for our emotions': poland's club scene fights for lgbtq+ rights
standfirst: As towns declare themselves ‘LGBT-free zones’, Polish DJs and musicians are leading furious opposition to widespread homophobia and police brutality
lead_paragraph: in august, as a giant bouncy castle was throwing a shadow on warsaw’s baroque-style ujazdów castle – home to the centre for contemporary art – a party was under way. it was the last event in the to be real programme, one day aimed at maximising the space’s fleeting inclusivity of poland’s lgbtq+ community. one of the artists was running late. “i came almost straight out of jail and played probably the most aggressive set in my life,” says dj and producer avtomat.

headline: black lives matter protests, a covid-19 outbreak and the 'link' that didn't exist | weekly beast

headline: 'i’ve seen how uprisings have come from pain': idris elba on black lives matter

lead_paragraph: “history maketh the man,” says idris elba. the actor is quoting his late father, a man who he has spent the past two years playing a version of in his 1980s-set sky sitcom,  in the long run.

headline: melitina staniouta on the belarus protests: 'i just could not keep quiet' | tumaini carayol
standfirst: The decorated gymnast has joined 400 sporting figures in protesting at the re-election of Alexander Lukashenko and police brutality
lead_paragraph: for numerous bitter days in early august, belarus went dark. after the rigged  presidential re-election of alexander lukashenko, tens of thousands of civilians took to the streets in peaceful protest, where they were met by state-sanctioned violence as the government killed the internet. haunting stories  continue to emerge of beatings directed by the government.

headline: from dukes of hazzard to kanye west: the curse of the confederate flag
standfirst: Lynyrd Skynyrd flew it, Ludacris stamped on it and Spike Lee compared it to a swastika. In the era of Black Lives Matter, what do these battles reveal about the American South’s Confederate flag?
lead_paragraph: john schneider, aka bo duke from the tv show the dukes of hazzard, recently asked his fans  a question via youtube: “was the dukes of hazzard a racially charged show? was the intention of the paint scheme on the general lee a white supremacist statement in any way? and if you think it was, i wanna know.”

headline: calls for redesign of royal honour over 'offensive' image

lead_paragraph: campaigners are calling for the redesign of one of britain’s highest honours personally bestowed by the queen because they say its badge resembles a depiction of a white angel standing on the neck of a chained black man.

headline: americans vote in primaries amid covid-19 and mass protests

lead_paragraph: eight states and washington dc are holding primaries on tuesday in the most  widespread trial yet over whether america can safely hold an election amid the pandemic and unrest as days of  protest over the police killings of african americans continues.

headline: how data reveals fashion's inclusivity problem
standfirst: Anti-racist rhetoric has exploded across the fashion industry in the aftermath of 2020’s Black Lives Matter protests. But, as young designer Tolu Coker writes, real change starts at the beginning – with education
lead_paragraph: the past two months have seen echoes of exasperation across black communities worldwide, in reaction to the us killings of  ahmaud arbery,  george floyd,  elijah mcclain and  breonna taylor. the fashion industry’s reaction to these events has seen big players –  anna wintour,  the british fashion council,  jonathan anderson,  reformation,  sarah mower and  carine roitfield, to name just a few – issuing apologies, and brands such as  all saints,  burberry and  calvin klein making vague proclamations of solidarity. well intended as those social media epiphanies may have been, it struck me that they evaded the most pressing causes of institutionalised racism within fashion: access and equity.

headline: asio boss denies expanded powers could be used to target black lives matter protesters

headline: 'how did we get here?': trump has normalised mayhem and the us is paying the price

headline: goat girl: 'we're seen as harmless because we're not men'
standfirst: With a member diagnosed with cancer and their politics deepened by BLM, the south London indie quartet have reassessed their priorities ahead of their excellent second album
lead_paragraph: south london quartet goat girl were deep into making their second album when it became clear that something was very wrong with their youngest member, guitarist-vocalist ellie rose davies. at the end of 2019, she had had lumps on her neck for some time, which eventually spread to both armpits. it wasn’t until the 23-year-old’s “fourth or fifth” trip to the doctors that she was finally referred for a blood test, then a biopsy. “by which time the cancer was at stage four,” she says.

headline: the protest review – superb set of dramas for the black lives matter movement
standfirst: trong>Available onlinetrong>r>Pain, anger and everyday racism are examined in this powerful series of short films from the Bush theatre
lead_paragraph: a week ago, the bush theatre asked six writers for their dramatised responses to the killing of george floyd in minnesota, the global protests that followed and the state society is in now. these protest plays, curated by daniel bailey, are the result of that quickfire commission. combining political theatre with digital technology, they are available across the bush’s social media platforms, including twitter and instagram, and on youtube. they range in length from one to nine minutes and are honest, impactful pieces that turn life, as it is happening, into story – and sometimes song.

headline: the boos at the nfl opener show what many in white america think of equality

lead_paragraph: “i have great respect for men and women who fought for this country. i have family, i have friends who have gone and fought for this country. they fight for freedom. they fight for the people, and they fight for liberty and justice.”

headline: amazon says 'black lives matter'. but the company has deep ties to policing

headline: harvey milk's murder is a stark reminder of the persistence of police brutality

lead_paragraph: like millions around the world, last may the image of the minneapolis police officer  derek chauvin killing  george floyd sickened and angered me and drove me to the streets to demonstrate in support of black lives matter. it also reminded me of events that occurred in my hometown of san francisco 42 years ago on friday.

headline: c of e accused of ‘utter hypocrisy’ over backing for black lives matter

headline: seth meyers on reports of trump calling us vets ‘losers’: confirmed by ‘common sense’
standfirst: Hosts react to the Atlantic’s story that Trump called Americans who died at war ‘suckers’ and yet another video of police brutality
lead_paragraph: after six months hosting from his quarantine attic, seth meyers returned to the late night studio in new york on monday evening. the main topic of discussion was, however, business as usual: another damning report of outrageous, offensive remarks by donald trump. at a press conference on monday, trump disputed a  story by the atlantic that he called americans who died at war “losers” and “suckers”. the report has since been confirmed by numerous outlets including the ap, cnn, fox news “and also by common sense”, added meyers. “i mean, it sounds exactly like something trump would say. he probably thinks anyone who dies is a sucker.”

headline: premier league player names to be replaced on shirts by black lives matter

lead_paragraph: premier league players will wear the words “black lives matter” on the back of their shirts in the opening round of fixtures upon next week’s restart. the slogan will replace the ­footballers’ surnames in one of ­several initiatives marking recent events agreed by the clubs at a meeting on thursday, which also include a minute’s silence to ­honour those who have died as a result of the covid-19 pandemic.

headline: beyoncé seeks justice for breonna taylor in letter to kentucky attorney general

headline: 'i was leaving a shop and security stopped me. i was four': young protesters on why they are marching against racism
standfirst: The UK’s Black Lives Matter protests have been spearheaded by a new generation of activists. Six demonstrators from a recent London march reveal what brought them to the streets
lead_paragraph: the killing of  george floyd by a white police officer took place thousands of miles from the uk. but the 46-year-old’s cry in minnesota that he could not breathe has sparked widespread protest in britain. in the past two weeks, there have been demonstrations across uk cities. the protesters, the vast majority of whom were under 25, chanted: “no justice, no peace, no racist police” and “the uk is not innocent”. the demonstrations were largely organised through word of mouth and social media rather than established anti-racism groups.

headline: food brands are phasing out racist mascots. will sports teams follow?

headline: colombia protests against police brutality leave at least 10 dead

headline: the minnesota paradox: how race divides prosperous minneapolis

lead_paragraph: it has been called the “minnesota paradox”. the twin cities, comprising the conjoined urban areas of minneapolis and st paul, regularly tops the list of places in the us with the best quality of living.

headline: raye's lockdown listening: 'nina simone tears your skin and burns your eardrums'
standfirst: The British dance-pop star considers Sam Cooke’s A Change Is Gonna Come amid the Black Lives Matter protests, and picks out tracks by Otis Redding, Miraa May and more
lead_paragraph: i’ve been quarantined at the family house, with instruments everywhere, and we have a little studio in the back garden so i’m not having a creative drought. i’ve been writing on zoom with ryan tedder [a songwriter for adele and beyoncé and onerepublic frontman], exploring powerful feminist messages which i’m very passionate about. i’m so used to being out and about, soaking in everything around me like a sponge, and writing down snapshots of things i see or feel. so in this stillness, i’m forced to look inside myself.

headline: 'protest': why speaking out is now seen as an act of dissent
standfirst: Often controversially linked with ‘rioting’, those protesting the killing of George Floyd are not merely complaining
lead_paragraph: are we in for a summer of protest? bubbles of anti-lockdown gatherings in the spring were followed, after the killing of george floyd by minneapolis police, by a wave of demonstrations across the us and elsewhere.

headline: i was an ehrc commissioner. it needs to start taking racism seriously | simon woolley
standfirst: The ineffectiveness of Britain’s equality watchdog, which does not have a single black commissioner, has been shown up by the Black Lives Matter movementl>i>Lord Woolley is director of Operation Black Votei>l>
lead_paragraph: even before this year’s historic black lives matter movement, and the covid-19 tragedy with its disproportionate impact on britain’s ethnic minorities, i was impatient for deep structural change to tackle race inequality. so when i heard the outgoing head of britain’s equality watchdog, david isaac, say that the government is “ dragging its feet” over tackling racism, i felt it was difficult to disagree.

headline: george floyd: governor's vow to reclaim streets rings hollow on night of chaos

headline: police brutality is just tip of the iceberg for protesters in nigeria

headline: gbolahan obisesan: give bame talent trust and theatre will thrive
standfirst: As he returns to his role in Katori Hall’s The Mountaintop, the actor, writer and director talks about Black Lives Matter, Martin Luther King and the state of UK theatre
lead_paragraph: trong>this is the third time you’ve played  martin luther king, after productions of the mountaintop in 2016 and 2018. how have your feelings about him and his legacy changed over the years?trong> r/>my feelings towards him and his legacy haven’t changed. if anything they have strengthened in pursuit of his efforts and aspirations for a more united, respectful and equitable society. his assassination was heartbreaking and was a deliberate act to silence civil rights progress and the wider rallying condemnation of social injustice and racial inequality. he led marches and in 2020 many new people are stepping up to inspire our generation to be counted and make their voices heard.  black lives matter.  equality matters. racism has no place in our world today or in the future.

headline: thousands celebrate juneteenth with anti-racism marches across us
standfirst: Celebrations combined with homage to George Floyd in Minneapolis while Atlanta protesters demanded justice for Ahmaud Arbery
lead_paragraph: tens of thousands of americans on friday marked the  juneteenth holiday commemorating the abolition of slavery with anti-racism marches, peaceful rallies, bike rides and music parties celebrating blackness held across the country.

headline: from slavery to blm: the ups and downs of 200 years of guardian race reporting
standfirst: While the paper hasn’t always got it right, journalists of colour are helping to improve representation on and off the pagel>i>Celebrate 200 years of independent Guardian journalism, and help power our future –  make a contribution, or  become a subscriber. r>r>i>l>
lead_paragraph: fifty years ago, as the guardian marked its 150th birthday, the then editor, alastair hetherington, reflected on the changes he had seen since he joined the paper 21 years earlier. intriguingly, he singled out social forces striving to upset “racial harmony”, and promised resistance.

headline: after the protests, lingering trauma: the scars of ‘non-lethal’ weapons
standfirst: Dozens of protesters sustained serious injuries from teargas, rubber bullets and stun grenades, used by police to disperse crowds during the George Floyd protests
lead_paragraph: six days after george floyd was killed by a white policeman, thousands of protesters in minneapolis took over an on-ramp leading to the university of minnesota. among them was soren stevenson.

headline: how civil servants' concerns about racism led them to cummings recruit's tweet
standfirst: Call by data specialist to ‘get out the live rounds’ after BLM protest raises questions about Cabinet Office culturer>l>i> Cummings recruit sacked after suggesting police use ‘live rounds’ on BLM protestersi>l>
lead_paragraph: it was one shocking tweet that led to a data specialist being sacked from the cabinet office, just three months after he was recruited following dominic cummings’ call for “weirdos and misfits” to work for the government.

headline: sas: who dares wins' ant middleton dropped over blm and covid tweets
standfirst: Channel 4 says its ‘views and values’ do not align with those of the former soldier and TV presenter
lead_paragraph: former soldier and tv presenter ant middleton has parted ways with channel 4, following controversial comments on the coronavirus pandemic and black lives matter.

headline: 'george floyd happens every day': activists seek justice for police killings the media forgot
standfirst: Mario Woods, Angel Ramos, Sean Monterrosa: California faces the highest rate of fatal police shootings for a state of its size. The outcry over Floyd’s death offers a ‘window of opportunity’l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>i> See all our George Floyd coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: in 2014, 28-year-old  alex nieto was killed by san francisco police while he ate a burrito on a hilltop park. in 2017, in northern california, 21-year-old  angel ramos was shot and killed by vallejo police during a large fight. in 2019, 23-year-old  miles hall was shot and killed by walnut creek police during a mental health crisis.

headline: protesters topple statue of confederate president in virginia
standfirst: Monument of Jefferson Davis torn down in Richmond as anti-racism protests continue in USl>i> George Floyd protests: live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: protesters have pulled down a statue of jefferson davis, the civil war-era president of the confederacy, amid continuing protests triggered by the police killing of george floyd and the wider issue of racism in the us.
