lead_paragraph: justin trudeau took a knee in solidarity with anti-racism demonstrators on friday, but remained silent at the event as his government faces  questions over how it plans to address police violence.

headline: nearly 1,000 instances of police brutality recorded in us anti-racism protests
standfirst: Police attacks on citizens and journalists over five months accompanied by incidents of tolerance of or collaboration with far right
lead_paragraph: the united states is currently experiencing one of the longest continued periods of civil unrest in generations, after demonstrations sparked by george floyd’s death expanded to protests against black americans killed by police and systemic racism in the country.

headline: black lives matter organisers say they’ll call off sydney rally if premier seeks dungay death investigation
standfirst: ‘We won’t stop until there is justice,’ David Dungay Jr’s nephew says
lead_paragraph: black lives matter rally organisers say they’ll consider calling off  tuesday’s now-unauthorised sydney protest if the new south wales premier commits to asking safework nsw and the director of public prosecutions to investigate whether charges should be laid against the guards involved in the death of the aboriginal prisoner david dungay jr.

headline: 'white as hell': portland protesters face off with trump but are they eclipsing black lives matter?
standfirst: On another night of confrontation with federal agents, activists said their message was in danger of being forgottenl>i> America ‘staring down barrel of martial law’ – Oregon senatori>i> ‘Made-for-TV fascism’: how Trump’s ploy could backfirei>l>
lead_paragraph: teal lindseth surveyed the sea of mothers she was about to lead into the firing line.

headline: black lives matter: health experts assess risks of covid-19 transmission at australia protests
standfirst: Protests have been called ‘dangerous’ by chief medical officer, but research shows racism can be as deadly as coronavirusr>l>i> Sign up for Guardian Australia’s daily coronavirus emailr>i>i> Download the free Guardian app to get the most important news notificationsi>l>
lead_paragraph: the advice on protests from australia’s health protection principal committee – the group of experts that advises governments during national emergencies – has been clear. people should not attend mass gatherings of any kind, because even though rates of community transmission of covid-19 are low and many states are not reporting any new cases for days in a row, there is still a risk the virus may spread.

headline: the police say they support black lives matter. tell that to people in tottenham | stafford scott
standfirst: The investigation into Mark Duggan’s death may reopen, thanks to new research into deaths in custody r>r>l>i>Stafford Scott was a co-founder of the Broadwater Farm Defence Campaign in 1985i>l>
lead_paragraph: the callous killing of george floyd resonated powerfully across all of britain’s black communities, given our long-running issues with the police. but his death at the hands of four minnesota police officers probably had more meaning in one part of the country than any other.

headline: first thing: portland mayor accuses trump of stoking violence after protest shooting
standfirst: The mayor of Portland says the US needs Trump ‘to be stopped’ after a fatal shooting during clashes between the president’s supporters and Black Lives Matter demonstrators. Plus, the FDA indicates it may approve a coronavirus vaccine before the completion of the clinical trial process
lead_paragraph: good morning,

headline: ivanka trump complains of 'cancel culture' after university cancels her speech
standfirst: WSU Tech stops first daughter’s commencement speech amid criticism of Donald Trump’s response to George Floyd protests
lead_paragraph: ivanka trump has hit out at “cancel culture and viewpoint discrimination” after plans for her to give a virtual commencement speech to students in kansas were canceled amid criticism of donald trump’s response to anti-police brutality protests in the wake of the killing of george floyd.

headline: us sports are embracing social justice. the wnba was doing it before it was cool
standfirst: How does an entire league come to share a sense of urgency around issues from Black Lives Matter to Planned Parenthood? It could be that women’s sports itself remains an act of protest
lead_paragraph: an unarmed black man is killed by a cop in the twin cities. sometime thereafter, professional basketball is played. before one game, the reigning league champions take the court for warmups in t-shirts that read ‘change starts with us’. before two others, a trio of former league mvps across three teams lead similar rallies clad in ‘black lives matter’ tees; when those three teams and their players  draw fines for violating the league’s dress code, two of those mvps agree to hold their team’s post-game news conferences jointly and tell the media: “we’re only talking about black lives matter”. across the league, players post pictures of themselves in protest shirts on their social media feeds with messages underneath crying out for justice and reform. by the end of the month, the fines are rescinded.

headline: f1 drivers respond to lewis hamilton's call to condemn racism
standfirst: • Charles Leclerc, Daniel Ricciardo and others react• Hamilton criticised silence on George Floyd killing
lead_paragraph: a number of formula one drivers have come forward to condemn racism after lewis hamilton  strongly criticised the silence from his sport over the killing of george floyd.

headline: ‘i spent a long time being this macho man’: jay blades on love, loss and the liberating power of tears
standfirst: The Repair Shop star’s most awesome job of restoration was … himself. He tells how he overcame racist teachers, police brutality, homelessness and a breakdown
lead_paragraph: the repair shop is about many things. people bring items to its picturesque thatched barn workshop to be brought back to life in front of the bbc show’s cameras. it’s about the skill and meticulousness of the restorers’ work, a chance to see the inner workings of an object, an echo of a time when we fixed things instead of buying new. one less thing destined for landfill.

headline: what is happening in portland and what does trump hope to gain?
standfirst: As protests over police brutality and racism continue, the president is looking for confrontation. It’s all about the election
lead_paragraph: confrontations between protesters and federal agents in portland, oregon, have become a national flashpoint as donald trump’s law-and-order-focused re-election campaign has run up against protests over police brutality and systemic racism. eager for continued confrontation, the president has now  turned his attention to other cities.

headline: 'st albans has never seen anything like this': britain rallies for black lives matter
standfirst: Across the regions people of all races, age and class are standing together to fight racism
lead_paragraph: dismal grey clouds hang low and gloomy in st albans on friday evening as more than 1,000 people space out in verulamium park. lightning energy comes in the form of shelley hayles, a black mother born and raised in the city, who takes the mic on a plywood table turned makeshift stage.

headline: attorney general will defend aggressive us response to portland protests
standfirst: William Barr will tell members of a House judiciary hearing that the events in Portland are disconnected from the death of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: the us attorney general, william barr, will defend the aggressive federal law enforcement response to civil unrest in america in a highly anticipated hearing on tuesday, arguing that “violent rioters and anarchists have hijacked legitimate protests” sparked by george floyd’s death at the hands of minneapolis police.

headline: america's protest crackdown: five months after george floyd, hundreds face trials and prison
standfirst: trong>Some protesters face stacked charges and threats of deportation; others have been charged with police assault with no reports of injuriestrong>
lead_paragraph: lee percy christian iii didn’t think arizona law enforcement could stop him from protesting – until they locked him up indefinitely.

headline: 'black lives matter' risks becoming an empty slogan. it's not enough to defeat racism | joseph harker
standfirst: There are three powerful words that do expose discrimination. But you won’t find them on a poster, or chanted in the street
lead_paragraph: if i hear one more white person say “black lives matter” i think my head will explode. the slogan, powerful when first popularised by black people after the shooting of trayvon martin in 2012 in the us, has now become so ubiquitous as to have lost almost all meaning. a way for people to endlessly repeat “i hate racism” while doing nothing to actually stop it.

headline: banking and slavery: switzerland examines its colonial conscience
standfirst: BLM protests and fresh historical evidence are raising questions over the legacy of the founder of modern Switzerland, Alfred Escher
lead_paragraph: alfred escher wielded so much power and influence during his lifetime that he was nicknamed king alfred i. an immense bronze statue of modern switzerland’s founding father stands, fittingly, in front of zurich’s main train station. escher was a politician, but he was also an entrepreneur who founded the country’s railway network along with its leading university and the banking giant credit suisse.

headline: ‘boogaloo boi’ charged in fire of minneapolis police precinct during george floyd protest
standfirst: Ivan Harrison Hunter, a Texas rightwing extremist, bragged about helping to set the fire then was seen shooting 13 rounds at the building
lead_paragraph: a rightwing extremist boasted of driving from texas to minneapolis to help set fire to a police precinct during the george floyd protests, federal prosecutors said.

headline: judge refuses authorisation for black lives matter protest in sydney tomorrow – as it happened
standfirst: Planned protests at a time of social distancing draw criticism, including from Scott Morrison, as Melbourne school student tests positive. headline: linda burney urges mathias cormann to ‘listen’ after he condemned black lives matter protests
standfirst: The conflict came as the deputy chief medical officer warned the protests could generate a new cluster of Covid-19 infections
lead_paragraph: the shadow minister for indigenous australians linda burney has urged mathias cormann to listen to the pain of first nations people after the finance minister condemned  saturday’s mass protests to demand an end to indigenous deaths in custody as reckless, selfish and self-indulgent.

headline: real change or symbolism? what silicon valley is – and isn't – doing to support black lives matter
standfirst: trong>Platforms from Facebook to Reddit have responded to the national uprising. Here’s what they’ve done so fartrong>
lead_paragraph: major technology platforms are re-examining how they interact with police forces and regulate hate speech online following the death of george floyd and the weeks of protests that ensued.

headline: pride, power, pedals and protest: black british photographers pick a best shot
standfirst: Black Lives Matter has underlined the crucial role played by black photographers. We asked eight British leaders in their field to pick a favourite image from their archives – and explain why it’s so important to them
lead_paragraph: i remember seeing this child in a playground. he looked so confident, like he was ready for the world. a young boy riding off into the unknown, the markings on the ground like latitude lines. i was once a little boy like that.

headline: is the free speech debate raging because intellectuals feel stripped of power? | john ganz
standfirst: In the face of Covid-19, mass unemployment and police brutality, writers and academics are seeking meaning onliner>
lead_paragraph: over the past few weeks the literary and journalistic scene has exploded in discussion – or, if we are really being honest, diatribe – about free speech, open debate and  the limits of discourse. this has been spurred on by the publication of  an open letter in harper’s magazine signed by notable writers and academics against what they describe as the spread of “intolerance of opposing views, a vogue for public shaming and ostracism, and the tendency to dissolve complex policy issues in a blinding moral certainty”.

headline: twitter deletes 170,000 accounts linked to china influence campaign
standfirst: Content focused on Covid-19 and the protests in Hong Kong and over George Floyd in the US
lead_paragraph: twitter has removed more than 170,000 accounts the social media site says are state-linked influence campaigns from china focusing on hong kong protests, covid-19 and the us protests in relation to george floyd.

headline: royal festival hall in london reopens with blm-inspired season
standfirst: First post-lockdown season will feature new commission inspired by BLM protest in London
lead_paragraph: orchestras are to return to one of britain’s most distinctive concert halls after a six-month absence with a season heavily influenced by this year’s black lives matter protests.

headline: thousands of youtube comments on sky news australia video celebrate blm activist being shot in head
standfirst: trong>Exclusive:trong> The racist and violent comments appear below a video news report about Sasha Johnson who was shot in the head in London
lead_paragraph: sky news australia’s youtube channel has published more than 9,000 comments mostly celebrating and mocking the shooting of a black lives matter activist in britain who is fighting for her life.

headline: black images matter: shade, the powerful podcast unpicking the tumult of 2020
standfirst: Lou Mensah explains why the new season of her podcast about art, race and identity examines the defining images of 2020 and beyond, from BLM protests to Vogue covers and Trump supporters
lead_paragraph: lou mensah spent the 1990s working in pr but her favourite part of the job was not the to and fro with clients. what she really liked was meeting and briefing photographers. so when she fell ill at one point, a friend gave her a camera and said: “if you’re well enough to go out today, just take some pictures.” and mensah did.

headline: diversity dance group 'proud' of itv backing in newspaper ads
standfirst: Ashley Banjo thanks people for support after Ofcom dismisses complaints about BLM routiner>
lead_paragraph: ashley banjo has said his dance group diversity has “never been prouder” after itv took out full-page newspaper adverts to show support for their controversial black lives matter-inspired performance.

headline: carlo ancelotti: 'there is a very big problem in america. and police are part of that'
standfirst: The Everton manager on the killing of George Floyd, racial inequality, and returning to football in the Mersey derby
lead_paragraph: “look,” says carlo ancelotti, leaning towards the screen, a glint in his eye and a grin beginning to creep across his face. “i used to have a coach that said: ‘coaching would be the best job in the world ... if there weren’t any games.’” and with that everton’s manager sits back again and starts laughing. lockdown was good, then? “well, my stress has gone down, definitely,” he says, smiling – the kind of person who never appeared particularly prone to pressure anyway, just a raise of an eyebrow while all around him others lose their heads.

headline: black lives shattered: outrage as boy, 14, is brazil police's latest victim

lead_paragraph: joão pedro matos pinto was young, gifted and black, and he died last month with an assault rifle shot to his back.

headline: this time, the promise of change has to be realised. black americans have had enough | niambi michele carter
standfirst: From the ‘war on drugs’ to the killing of George Floyd, African Americans are too often the victims
lead_paragraph: in the middle of a pandemic that is killing inordinate numbers of black people, many have been grieving the lives of george floyd,  breonna taylor,  ahmaud arbery,  david mcatee and many others, while living with the realities of covid-19. that george floyd lived through coronavirus to then be killed by police who cut off his oxygen is a cruel irony. yet his death makes it clear that we cannot separate the pandemic from police violence because they are both driven by the same thing – white supremacy.

headline: john sentamu: i would join george floyd protests
standfirst: Justin Welby and bishops of London and Liverpool join York archbishop’s call for racial unityl>i> George Floyd protests - latest updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: the archbishop of york has said he would join protests over the death of george floyd but condemned any use of violence.

headline: wednesday briefing: george floyd will 'change the world'
standfirst: Funeral hears eulogies to man whose death sparked worldwide protests … Babylon Health app privacy breach … Chris Packham on Covid-19 and change
lead_paragraph: good morning – warren murray with wednesday’s priority stories.

headline: video of minnesota man threatening to call police on black entrepreneurs goes viral
standfirst: Footage surfaced as Minneapolis reels from killing of African American man George Floyd, which created a global outcry
lead_paragraph: a video of a man in minneapolis questioning whether several young black men were entitled to be working out in the same gym has gone viral in the latest example of apparently racist behavior aimed at african americans going about their everyday lives.

headline: unicorn riot: the tiny media outlet on the frontlines of us protests
standfirst: Non-profit’s dedicated reporting of George Floyd protests has prompted surge of donations that could ensure its future for years to come
lead_paragraph: as protests over the killing of george floyd by a white police officer have gripped minneapolis and many other major us cities over recent weeks one previously unknown news organization has sprung to the fore.

headline: army warn they are on standby as police brutality protests intensify in nigeria
standfirst: At least 10 are dead and dozens injured in street demonstrations demanding an end to widespread abuses by security forces
lead_paragraph: nigeria’s army has warned it could step in against “subversive elements and troublemakers” as the protests against police brutality that have erupted throughout the country over the past week continue.

headline: scott morrison: black lives matter protesters should be charged if they defy advice and march
standfirst: Prime minister says protests risk Australia’s economic recovery and delay easing of restrictions
lead_paragraph: scott morrison has declared black lives matter protests put “the whole track back to economic recovery at risk” and could delay easing of restrictions by a week while governments monitor signs of outbreaks.

headline: football chiefs talk a good game on racism but it still looks like bluster | barry glendenning
standfirst: Fifa’s and Uefa’s response to the solidarity shown by players with George Floyd needs to be more than platitudes
lead_paragraph: talk is famously cheap and out of the mouths of international football administrators tumble platitudes that are not worth the paper they will soon be written on. while encouraging, the apparent freedom granted by fifa to players who wish to throw their collective shoulder to the wheel of protest against the sickening death of george floyd at the knee of a minnesota policeman should perhaps be greeted with scepticism.

headline: 'i’m getting shot': attacks on journalists surge in us protests
standfirst: Analysis by Guardian and Bellingcat finds 148 arrests or attacks on media covering George Floyd protests in the US
lead_paragraph: journalists working in conflict zones and authoritarian states have been warning for years: reporting is becoming more dangerous. what little protection a press pass or camera might have afforded in the past has meant less than ever on the  battlefields of syria,  in small-town india or on the  streets of hong kong. this was the week that trend burst into view in us cities.

headline: australian black lives matter protests: tens of thousands demand end to indigenous deaths in custody
standfirst: Mask-clad crowds defied pleas from the prime minister and state leaders for people to stay home
lead_paragraph: tens of thousands of people marched through australian cities and towns for black lives matter protests on saturday, defying an attempt from the police to ban one demonstration through the courts and despite pleas from the prime minister and state leaders for people to stay home.

headline: juneteenth 2020 will be infused with energy of anti-racist uprisings
standfirst: The celebration of the emancipation from slavery in the US comes amid protests inspired by the police killing of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: the annual celebration of emancipation from  slavery in the us, juneteenth, will be marked with a new energy and mass demonstrations this year amid the global uprisings against systemic racism sparked by the police killing of george floyd.

headline: nsw police to investigate after leaking emails of people who complained about pepper spray at black lives matter rally
standfirst: Police say they launched an internal investigation after more than 150 people had email addresses leaked, but victims of leaks say they are yet to be contacted
lead_paragraph: the  new south wales police say they have launched an internal investigation after more than 150 people had their personal email addresses leaked after complaining about the use of capsicum spray against protestors at a black lives matter rally in sydney.

headline: morrison says australia should not import black lives matter protests after deaths-in-custody rally
standfirst: Prime minister acknowledges we have ‘issues in this space’ but ‘we are dealing with it and don’t need to draw equivalence here’
lead_paragraph: scott morrison has warned against “importing the things that are happening overseas to australia” after protesters gathered in sydney to denounce the killing of george floyd in the united states and to rally against indigenous deaths in custody. further protests are planned in cities around australia in the next few days.

headline: democrats block republican resolution to censure maxine waters over chauvin comments – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> Congresswoman has said she won’t be ‘bullied’ by Republicans i>i> Derek Chauvin found guilty of George Floyd’s murder – live updatesr>i>i>National guard to assist Washington police in event of protestsr>i>l>

headline: 'hang on to hope': houston police chief art acevedo on race, reform and trump
standfirst: The first Hispanic police chief in the fourth-largest US city believes the death of George Floyd has created ‘a great awakening’
lead_paragraph: in scenes mirrored across the country, thousands mourned george floyd and marched against racism and police brutality in houston, where he was raised and buried. among the demonstrators was the city’s police chief.

headline: george floyd protesters condemn 'opportunistic' looting and violence
standfirst: Minneapolis protesters spoke out in interviews, saying looting and violence is not being done in the name of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: protesters in minneapolis have condemned as “opportunistic”  looting and violence taking place in cities across the us, saying it is not being done in the name of george floyd, the 46-year-old african american man who was killed during an arrest this week.

headline: minneapolis: journalists teargassed while covering george floyd protests
standfirst: Teargas fired ‘at point-blank range’ at group that identified themselves as journalists as police worked to impose curfew
lead_paragraph: several journalists reporting on the protests in  minneapolis on saturday were teargassed as police worked to impose an evening curfew, just a day after a cnn reporter in the city was arrested live on air.

headline: george floyd protests: what we know so far
standfirst: Minneapolis has been rocked by three days of protests over the death of George Floydl>i> Live coverage of Minneapolis protestsi>l>
lead_paragraph: the us has been rocked by a  third night of protests over the death of george floyd in police custody. here is what we know so far:

headline: nsw police seek to block newcastle black lives matter protest ahead of rallies across country on weekend
standfirst: Police high court challenge argues protest breaches NSW health order on public gatherings but organisers say event will go ahead
lead_paragraph: new south wales police have applied to the state’s supreme court to block another  upcoming black lives matter and indigenous lives matter protest scheduled for the weekend.

headline: we must keep fighting for justice for breonna taylor. we must keep saying her name | arwa mahdawi
standfirst: Black women are rarely centered in narratives about police violence and they are rarely the catalysts for mass outrage
lead_paragraph: m>sign up for the week in patriarchy, a newsletter​ on feminism and sexism sent every saturday.m>

headline: newcastle's deandre yedlin feels us is an unsafe place for a young black man
standfirst: l>i>‘My heart goes out in solidarity to George Floyd’i>i>Former Tottenham defender has 62 USA capsi>l>
lead_paragraph: deandre yedlin, newcastle’s usa defender, has shared his grandfather’s opinion that their country is not a safe place for a young black man.

headline: the dead are arising by les payne and tamara payne review – the radical ascent of malcolm x
standfirst: A compelling picture of Malcolm X’s journey from delinquent to revolutionary has a clarity that speaks volumes in the age of BLM
lead_paragraph: “if you’re black you were born in jail,” said malcolm x in 1964, the year before his assassination. the american dream was a nightmare as far as the black muslim and former spokesman for the nation of islam (noi) was concerned. but, he argued, there would be no peace for “blue-eyed devils” (white people) either, without a reckoning for the sins of slavery and the continued brutalisation of enslaved people’s descendants.

headline: george floyd-style killing 'could happen in the uk', says michael fuller
standfirst: trong>Exclusive: trong>Britain’s only ever black police chief says communities feel ‘humiliated’
lead_paragraph: britain’s only ever black chief constable has warned that a george floyd-style killing could happen here, with police embroiled in a crisis over racial justice they were failing to address.

headline: allissa richardson: 'it’s telling that we’re ok with showing black people dying'
standfirst: The author and academic on why smartphones have been a game changer in African Americans’ struggle against police brutality – and the ethics of sharing violent images
lead_paragraph: trong>in her new book, trong>m>trong>bearing witness while blacktrong>m>trong>, trong>trong>allissa richardsontrong>trong>, an assistant professor of journalism at the trong>trong>university of southern californiatrong>trong>, trong>trong>explores how video footage captured and shared by victims, activists and shocked bystanders has trong>trong> trong>trong>alerted the world to a struggle for justice trong>trong>that has a very long history.trong>

headline: breonna taylor shooting: hunt for answers in case of black woman killed by police
standfirst: Amid the virus, the killing of Taylor, 26, in her own home has escaped scrutiny – but anger is building, as are calls for a judicial review
lead_paragraph: it has been two months since breonna taylor was sleeping in her apartment on the south side of louisville, kentucky, when plainclothes police officers arrived outside her door in the early hours of 13 march.

headline: taylor swift: 'racial injustice has been ingrained in us state government'
standfirst: Pop star urges fans to vote for candidates committed to fighting police brutality, and shares Barack Obama essay
lead_paragraph: taylor swift has accused local and state governments in the us of harbouring institutional racism, and has called on her fans to elect candidates committed to fighting police brutality.

headline: george floyd, isolation and zoom: hundreds of artists fuel pandemic exhibition in san francisco
standfirst: trong>The reopened de Young Museum hosts 877 works by Bay Area artists telling the story of the momenttrong>
lead_paragraph: nearly seven months after san francisco became the first us city to enter a pandemic lockdown, its cultural institutions and nightlife are beginning to resurface.

headline: wesley snipes on art, excellence and life after prison: 'i hope i came out a better person'
standfirst: After a fall as dramatic as any of his film roles, Snipes is back on track, starring with Eddie Murphy in the long-awaited Coming 2 America. He discusses police brutality, Michael Jackson – and his secret society
lead_paragraph: wesley snipes seemed to have everything in the 90s and early 00s. he was a film star, gifted, gorgeous, chiselled from top to bottom. box office gold. there seemed to be no genre he couldn’t star in: thrillers (detective thomas flanigan in king of new york), action movies (drug baron nino brown in new jack city), sports comedies (basketball hustler syd deane in white men can’t jump), lgbt comedies (drag queen noxeema jackson in to wong foo, thanks for everything! julie newmar), arthouse romances (commercials director max carlyle in one night stand) and dramas (architect flipper purify in jungle fever). in 2004,  his salary was a reported $13m for producing and starring in the third blade blockbuster, blade: trinity. snipes could not have been flying much higher. and then he fell.

headline: first thing: protests in minneapolis suburb after fatal police shooting
standfirst: Police shot and killed a man in Brooklyn Center, close to Minneapolis where the trial over the death of George Floyd continues. Plus, Facebook failed to crack down on world leaders deceiving and harassing citizensl>i>trong> Don’t already get First Thing in your inbox? Sign up heretrong>i>l>
lead_paragraph: good morning.

headline: dave chappelle addresses george floyd killing in netflix special
standfirst: Chappelle performs a surprise new set, entitled 8:46, before a socially distanced audience
lead_paragraph: comedian dave chappelle has released a blistering  netflix special in which he addresses the killing of george floyd, police brutality and the horrific legacy of slavery. the 25-minute set is entitled 8:46, referencing the period of time (eight minutes and 46 seconds) that police officer derek chauvin held his knee on floyd’s neck in minneapolis last month.

headline: a young girl who watched george floyd suffocate finds her place in the protest movement
standfirst: Protesters leave signs and tributes as years of frustration at racial disparities in policing come to the surface l>i> George Floyd killing – follow live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: nine-year-old judeah reynolds watched george floyd suffocate under a minneapolis police officer’s knee.

headline: young people inspired by george floyd ask what is more powerful: voting or protest?
standfirst: For many youngsters who took to the streets of Minneapolis this summer, the protests were a political awakening
lead_paragraph: on 25 may, white minneapolis police officer derek chauvin killed george floyd by kneeling on his neck for nearly nine minutes. the viral video of the horrific slaying became a catalyst for a civil uprising that started in the city. soon it would spur the largest-scale protests in american history.

headline: 'hope flows through her': artist marc quinn on replacing colston with a black lives matter statue
standfirst: The sculptor has placed a statue of a woman doing a black power salute on the vacant plinth in Bristol. Our writer, who was at the dawn unveiling, tells the full story of its creation – and speaks to Jen Reid, the protester whose gesture inspired him l>i> ‘Amazing moment’: new statue appears at dawni>l>
lead_paragraph: there’s a lookout stationed at the end of colston street and a load of people, some dressed in hi-vis vests, are gathering at a nearby restaurant. then, in the dawn light, a statue concealed in plastic wrapping can be seen approaching on a hiab truck. it turns the corner and reverses towards the plinth where  the statue of edward colston once stood. there’s a sense of mischief in the air on this bright clear morning in bristol – and revolution.

headline: officers charged in george floyd killing seek to place blame on one another
standfirst: l>i>Former police quartet appear in court for special hearingi>i>Floyd died after Derek Chauvin held his knee on his necki>l>
lead_paragraph: attorneys for four former minneapolis officers charged in the killing of george floyd say each should get his own trial, as the officers point fingers at one another.

headline: first thing: protests over police killing break out across us
standfirst: Death of George Floyd sparks third night of unrest in Minneapolis and other cities. Plus, an exclusive interview with Woody Allen
lead_paragraph: good morning.

headline: 'my hero was tiger woods': rory mcilroy urges tolerance and education in golf
standfirst: l>i>McIlroy wants golf to be more tolerant after George Floyd killingi>i>Charles Schwab Challenge starts on Thursday in Texasi>l>
lead_paragraph: rory mcilroy hopes golf can play its part in delivering a more multicultural society as it returns to tournament action days after the  funeral of george floyd. mcilroy cited his own idolisation of tiger woods as a reason why skin colour shouldn’t lead to the placement of barriers.

headline: black cnn reporter arrested on air at protests over george floyd killing
standfirst: Journalist Omar Jimenez had just shown a protester being arrested when Minneapolis police officers surrounded him, without giving a reasonl>i> George Floyd killing – follow live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: police in minnesota arrested a black  cnn reporter reporting live on television early on friday morning while covering  the minneapolis protests over the death of  george floyd, and led him and three crew members away in handcuffs, in what has been criticized as a racist incident.

headline: detroit's largely peaceful protests seen very differently from white suburb
standfirst: St Clair Shores was a destination for white flight after the 1967 riots and some residents view the George Floyd protests sceptically
lead_paragraph: each evening since a white minneapolis police officer killed george floyd during an arrest, emotional protests have erupted in downtown detroit. thousands of protesters march nightly through the city’s streets demanding justice for floyd and an end to police brutality, especially against african americans.

headline: how to find the hope in the bad news: this week's optimism | upside
standfirst: George Floyd, Covid-19 and Hong Kong suggest a world in turmoil. But within are stories of humanity and opportunities for change
lead_paragraph: so now we have not one global crisis but three. minneapolis, covid-19, hong kong – race, health, geopolitics. how do you find the hope in that lot?

headline: can joe biden convince protesters he'd be a 'transformational' president?
standfirst: ‘It’s not enough to just be better than Trump’, Democratic hopeful told, amid anti-racist uprising sparked by killing of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: hours before peaceful protests against police brutality were forcibly dispersed so donald trump could pose with a bible in front of st john’s, joe biden also went to church.

headline: young, british & black: the voices behind the uk’s anti-racism protests
standfirst: The death of George Floyd in the US sparked the UK’s biggest anti-racism protests in centuries. We spoke to 50 young people at the heart of these rallies
lead_paragraph: none

headline: james mattis condemns trump’s handling of george floyd protests
standfirst: In an extraordinary statement, the former defence secretary accused the president of abusing his executive authority with Monday’s publicity stuntr>
lead_paragraph: donald trump’s first defence secretary, james mattis, has delivered a blistering condemnation of the president, accusing him of abusing executive authority in his response to the recent wave of anti-racism protests that have convulsed cities across the us, and calling for him for to be held accountable.

headline: george floyd protests: man killed in detroit as demonstrations rage across us – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> George Floyd protests: Saturday coverage – livei>i> Crowds call for justice in Minneapolis, Atlanta, Kentucky, New York and Californiar>i>i> White House temporarily locked downi>i> Demonstrators deface CNN HQi>i> Officer who knelt on Floyd charged with murderi>i>Get a fresh perspective on America – sign up to our  First Thing newsletterr>i>l>

headline: protests rock cities across us as anger over george floyd's killing spreads
standfirst: l>i>Rallies in Minneapolis, New York, Louisville, Washington, California and beyondi>i>Peaceful scenes in day turn volatile in eveningi>i> George Floyd killing – follow live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: thousands of people ignored a curfew in minneapolis to protest for a fourth night in a row, as anger around police brutality and the death of george floyd erupted into violence across the us, from new york to california.

headline: 'i can't breathe': death of black man in custody ruled a homicide in washington
standfirst: Manuel Ellis died of respiratory arrest on 3 March, medical examiner report finds amid nationwide protests against police brutality
lead_paragraph: the death of an african american father of two who called out “i can’t breathe” while handcuffed in police custody in march in washington state has been ruled a homicide, according to a medical examiner’s report released wednesday.

headline: george floyd: as protests rage across us, trump comments inflame tensions
standfirst: l>i>President celebrates Secret Service for ‘most ominous weapons’ r>i>i>DC mayor Bowser laments ‘reminder of segregationists’i>i> George Floyd: protests rock cities as Trump lashes out – livei>i> Rev William Barber: America must listen to its woundsi>l>
lead_paragraph: donald trump on saturday belittled some of the protesters who have taken to the streets in cities across the united states, and raised the prospect of deploying violence against the american people for the second time in two days.

headline: trump's use of the military backfired – but will it back him if he loses? | robert reich
standfirst: Faced with the George Floyd protests, the president wants to be seen as a strongman. What happens if he loses at the polls?
lead_paragraph: history teaches that mass protests against oppression can lead either to liberation or brutal repression.

headline: trudeau: canadians watching us unrest and police violence in ‘shock and horror’
standfirst: Prime minister condemned racism and called on Canada to ‘stand together in solidarity’ against racial hate as protests continue in USl>i> George Floyd killing – follow live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: canadians are watching unrest and police violence in the united states in “shock and horror”, justin trudeau said on friday – but the prime minister cautioned that his country also has entrenched  problems with racism.

headline: racism, protest and a dangerous president | letters
standfirst: Readers respond to the widespread US protests that started with the death of George Floyd in Minneapolis, and Donald Trump’s inflammatory language
lead_paragraph: re richard wolffe’s article ( href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2020/jun/02/weve-reached-the-mad-emperor-stage-and-its-terrifying-to-behold" title="">trump has reached the ‘mad emperor’ stage, and it’s terrifying to behold, 2 june), is the media and public characterisation of donald trump symptomatic of the systemic (and often unconscious) racism that this week’s protests challenge? we mock him and describe him as a toddler, a fool. but his actions are those of a fascist and would-be dictator – he spreads misinformation and wants to shut down media dissent; he encourages violence against those who disagree and threatens his citizens with the military; and he shows every sign of being a white supremacist.

headline: george floyd protests around the us: what is happening?
standfirst: In DC peaceful protesters were teargassed to make way for photo shoot of Trump and in New York stores were looted Monday night
lead_paragraph: monday night saw continued peaceful protests and violence in many major us cities. here’s an at-a-glance guide:

headline: george floyd: medical examiner says death was a homicide
standfirst: Report comes as the family releases results of a private autopsy which determined the cause of death as asphyxiation
lead_paragraph: a medical examiner has classified george floyd’s death as a homicide, saying his heart stopped as police restrained him and suppressed his neck.

headline: 'we can enact the future we want now': a black feminist history of abolition
standfirst: From Audre Lorde to George Floyd, Lola Olufemi writes of how abolition has evolved in the US and UK, ahead of the programme Revolution is not a one-time event
lead_paragraph: ­­at an event held in honour of malcolm x in 1982, audre lorde delivered an address titled learning from the 60s, during which she proclaimed, “revolution is not a one-time event.” by this, lorde meant that revolution belongs to everyone and no one simultaneously; if it is to proceed, it must cease to be the “sole and particular province of anyone particular race, or sex, or age, or religion, or sexuality, or class.” revolutions reoccur: they follow each other, making circles of time and all the political demands that push them forward.lorde’s statement makes clear the purview of the black feminist tradition; nothing must be allowed to remain. we must be prepared for the multi-purpose, multi-layered revolution, in which political ideologies and mantras will, and must, collide.

headline: 'just ridiculous': what it’s like to wait five hours in line to vote in the us
standfirst: Georgia’s bungled primary election added to cocktail of frustrations held by voters amid pandemic and protests against police brutality r>
lead_paragraph: simone alisa arrived at her polling place in atlanta’s old fourth ward at 9.45am on tuesday. five hours later, she would cast her vote.

headline: munroe bergdorf on fashion's pr problem: 'don't use this movement to improve your public image'
standfirst: In an exclusive interview, the model and activist discusses brands’ responses to the death of George Floyd and the protests surrounding itr>
lead_paragraph: the model and activist  munroe bergdorf has hit out at fashion companies for attempting to align themselves with the  worldwide protests against racism without getting their own houses in order first.

headline: marcus thuram and jadon sancho both pay tribute to george floyd after scoring
standfirst: l>i>Sancho reveals message reading ‘Justice for George Floyd’i>i>Thuram takes knee before both players post on social mediai>l>
lead_paragraph: jadon sancho and marcus thuram sent out a powerful message of solidarity towards those protesting against the killing of george floyd by american police, after scoring in their respective bundesliga games on sunday. both players followed up their on-field gestures with social media posts calling for change.

headline: the observer view on the killing of george floyd
standfirst: Donald Trump’s spouting of white supremacist hatred will surely come back to bite him come election timetrong>trong>
lead_paragraph: there is a dreadful familiarity about the killing of an unarmed black man, george floyd, by white police officers in minneapolis last monday. floyd’s final moments were videoed from a bystander’s phone. he repeatedly pleads for mercy. his last words, “i can’t breathe”, have become a rallying cry for often violent protests that have since shaken cities across america.

headline: australia protests: thousands take part in black lives matter and pro-refugee events amid covid-19 warnings
standfirst: Refugee advocates defy court order in Sydney as Victorian GP among nation’s new coronavirus cases
lead_paragraph: thousands of people have taken part in black lives matter and pro-refugee protests and marches across australia, with refugee advocates in sydney defying a court order to take to the city’s streets.

headline: schalke's weston mckennie wears 'justice for george floyd' armband
standfirst: l>i>Midfielder tweets: ‘We have to stand up for what we believe in’i>i>Floyd’s death at hands of Minneapolis police prompts protestsi>l>
lead_paragraph: the schalke midfielder weston mckennie took to the pitch for saturday’s bundesliga game with werder bremen wearing an armband reading “justice for george”, the african-american whose death at the hands of minneapolis police has led to protests across the united states.

headline: deportation row: david lammy asks 'when will black lives matter again'
standfirst: Labour MPs condemn removal of 50 people to Jamaica with Windrush report pending
lead_paragraph: david lammy has challenged the government over the home office’s decision to resume deportation flights to jamaica, asking it to demonstrate that “black lives matter”.

headline: thousands in new zealand protest against george floyd killing
standfirst: Speakers highlight racism against Indigenous people and call on Ardern to denounce killing
lead_paragraph: tens of thousands of new zealanders have come out in support of the black lives matter movement, after the death of george floyd in the us.

headline: friday briefing: us roils with george floyd death protests
standfirst: National guard sent to Minneapolis … rule of six for gatherings from Monday … and Woody Allen comes out fighting
lead_paragraph: hello, welcome to friday, warren murray here with news to start the day.

headline: devon and cornwall police officer investigated over george floyd meme
standfirst: Exclusive: officer alleged to have shared offensive image of man who died in US police custody
lead_paragraph: a british police officer is under criminal investigation by the police watchdog over the sharing of an offensive meme of george floyd with other officers in a private social media chat group.

headline: aleksandar katai cut by la galaxy over wife's 'racist and violent' instagram posts
standfirst: l>i>Serbian released by Galaxy after wife’s racist Instagram postsi>i>Tea Katai mocked protests related to killing of George Floydi>l>
lead_paragraph: aleksandar katai has been released by the la galaxy after a series of alarming social media posts by his wife, tea.

headline: george floyd protests: reporters targeted by police and crowds
standfirst: Journalists report and record being shot at, teargassed, arrested and intimidated
lead_paragraph: journalists covering  the protests and riots that have erupted in us cities after the killing of george floyd have reported being shot at, teargassed and arrested, as well as being intimidated by crowds.

headline: 'what does the un stand for?': anger follows memo on anti-racism protests
standfirst: Secretary general has clarified staff are ‘not banned’ from demonstrations after previous guidance warned support for action on George Floyd killing risked reputational damage
lead_paragraph: the un’s secretary general, antónio guterres, sought to defuse a row over guidance to staff suggesting they should not participate in protests triggered by the police killing of george floyd. he clarified that staff were “not banned” from joining anti-racism demonstrations, as long as it was in an “entirely private capacity”.

headline: black mep describes being victim of belgian police brutality
standfirst: MEP was ‘brutally’ stopped from filming incident involving police and black youths
lead_paragraph: a black mep has said she was a victim of police violence at the hands of belgian officers, on the day the european parliament debated anti-racism protests sparked by the killing of  george floyd.

headline: rafael nadal would 'not travel to new york today' to play us open
standfirst: l>i>Nadal against competing again until it is safe to traveli>i>Violence ‘not the way to protest’ over George Floydi>l>
lead_paragraph: rafael nadal has said tennis should not resume until players are able to travel safely in order to compete around the world.

headline: 'an awakening': the george floyd protests spur surge in black voter registration
standfirst: Activists say enfranchisement effort has not been seen at such a scale since the civil rights era
lead_paragraph: gregory sarafan spends most election years assisting team leaders with registration events at concerts, where they target young, unregistered voters. but sarafan, regional coordinator for the voter registration organization headcount, knew that this summer, he was more likely to find that demographic marching through the streets to protest against police brutality after the deaths of george floyd and breonna taylor.

headline: kanye west takes anti-vaccine, anti-abortion stance in us presidential bid
standfirst: Rapper also unveils intention to end police brutality, return ‘fear and love of God’ to schools and appoint Elon Musk to run space programme
lead_paragraph: kanye west has given more details about the policy platform he will adopt in his bid to become us president in november, declaring himself anti-abortion, sceptical about a covid-19 vaccine and keen to return “fear and love of god” to education.

headline: america isn't breaking. it was already broken, and these are just the symptoms | andrew gawthorpe
standfirst: It’s not just the pandemic, or the killing of George Floyd, or Trump – it’s centuries of oppression, like kindling to a firer>
lead_paragraph: look at america today and you see a land defined by death. people are dying alone in hospital beds and bedrooms. they’re dying in the streets. they’re dying inside as the economy collapses around them and their hopes for tomorrow evaporate. they’re dying because they can’t breathe.

headline: joy labinjo: 'when i’m painting i feel happy and alive'
standfirst: The young British-Nigerian painter talks about finding inspiration in British black art of the 1980s, the impact of BLM, and what’s getting us through Covid-19
lead_paragraph: “i like coming to the studio and it just being me,” british-nigerian artist joy labinjo says when i ask whether she gets lonely. the 25-year-old’s career has risen rapidly since graduating from newcastle university in 2017. that year she won the woon art prize, then in 2019 had a solo exhibition at the  baltic; she now has works in the current  royal academy summer exhibition and a forthcoming mural commission at brixton station, south london. at  frieze london last autumn, three of her paintings sold within two hours of the fair’s opening. all of which means she is very busy. of course she’s spending less time with her peers because of the pandemic, but she is fine with living up to the isolated artist trope. “it’s easier to focus with fewer social engagements,” she says.

headline: the guardian launches six-day black history timeline in print and online to mark the black lives matter movement
standfirst: Starting today, the Guardian will celebrate world-shaping individuals and momentous events of black history with a six-part series of wallcharts
lead_paragraph: the guardian is proud to announce it will publish a black history poster series in the guardian newspaper today and from monday 13 - friday 17 july, documenting key historical moments and the black lives matter movement of the past decade.

headline: george floyd could not breathe. we must fight police violence until our last breath | derecka purnell
standfirst: The Minnesota police department that killed George Floyd has been violent and racist since its inception. Can we really have faith in reform?
lead_paragraph: white police officer  derek chauvin pinned george floyd to the concrete as he hollered that he could not breathe. george screamed. screamed for his mother. screamed for his breath. for his life.

headline: police apologise to woman told to cover up anti-boris johnson t-shirt
standfirst: British Transport Police say instruction to Jessie-Lu Flynn at BLM protest was unlawful
lead_paragraph: police have apologised to a woman after she was challenged by officers at a black lives matter demonstration for wearing an anti-boris johnson t-shirt and admitted that asking her to cover up the slogan on her clothing was unlawful.

headline: 'the confederacy of california': life in the valley where robert fuller was found hanged
standfirst: Racism has been sewn into the fabric of southern California’s Antelope Valley for generations. But a national reckoning with police brutality offers hope
lead_paragraph: in a corner of desert country at the northernmost edge of los angeles county, black boys have grown up watching their fathers handcuffed by sheriff’s deputies during routine traffic stops. black girls have had racial slurs shouted at them from passing cars and been warned not to go out by themselves at night.

headline: trevor noah on those doubting the protests: 'they’re going to be eating their words'
standfirst: Late-night hosts assess the significant impact of nationwide protests against police brutality and systemic racism in less than two weeks
lead_paragraph: after two weeks off, trevor noah returned to the daily show on monday night and addressed  the protests against anti-black racism and police brutality which have erupted nationwide after the police killings of george floyd and breonna taylor. the movement has spread across the world; as a protester in london told american news: “we’ll keep fighting the same fight that you are.”

headline: sotheby's to auction defining image of blm protests
standfirst: Picture taken by novice who became first black male to photograph British Vogue cover
lead_paragraph: it was one of the defining photos of this summer’s civil rights protests, and was all the more remarkable for being taken by a man who taught himself on youtube after receiving a camera from his wife on his 39th birthday.

headline: trump twists stats on police brutality: 'more white people' are killed
standfirst: President makes remark in CBS interview but research shows Black Americans are up to 3.5 times as likely to be killed by policer>
lead_paragraph: donald trump has once again stoked racial grievances, telling an interviewer who asked a question about the police killing of  george floyd that white people also get killed by law enforcement in the us.

headline: laura adlington: ‘i feel honoured that bake off brought a bit of joy this year’
standfirst: The Bake Off finalist on her highs and lows, making friends with Matt Lucas – and that Freddie Mercury cake r>l>i> Patrick Hutchinson: ‘My natural instinct is to protect the vulnerable’i>i> See the Observer’s faces of 2020 in fulli>l>
lead_paragraph: queen of flavour laura adlington, a digital manager from kent, won the hearts of m>the great british bake offm> fans when she made it to the final despite a number of melting, messy bakes – and having the untidiest workbench the series has ever seen.

headline: patrick hutchinson: 'my natural instinct is to protect the vulnerable'
standfirst: The Londoner became a defining image of Black Lives Matter when he stepped in to save a counter-protesterl>i> Captain Tom: ‘I’ve always believed things will get better. The sun will shine again’i>i>  See the Observer’s faces of 2020 in fulli>l>
lead_paragraph: if patrick hutchinson had a penny for every time someone has asked him whether he got a thank you from the man whose life he saved, he says he’d be a very rich man. “and if i had another penny for the shocked expression i get when i say i haven’t heard a word from him, well…” a wry shrug follows.

headline: ‘we must give black talent the stage’ says young vic's kwame kwei-armah
standfirst: Playwright and director says BLM and the lockdown have prompted him to stage an ambitious season of black work
lead_paragraph: british culture has been guilty of “hoodwinking” black people into thinking they are “invaders”, the artistic director of london’s young vic theatre, kwame kwei-armah, has told the m>observerm>. in his strongest comments yet on race, the british actor, playwright and director said the  href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/black-lives-matter-movement" title="">black lives matter protests had prompted him to speak out.

headline: how can the church of england speak about race when its leaders are so white? | arun arora
standfirst: The killing of George Floyd and the Covid-19 death rate among the BAME community are just two issues about which congregations are seeking solace
lead_paragraph: the reaction of many of those in leadership positions in the church of england to the killing of george floyd has been to ask bame people about their experience, not only in the united states but also in britain.

headline: protesting from a pedestal: ‘no one can ignore a black woman on a horse’
standfirst: Brianna Noble didn’t plan to ride her horse into the George Floyd protest in Oakland, but it was her way of doing something positive
lead_paragraph: the photo was shared and liked around the world: brianna noble riding her horse in front of the crowd at a california protest marking the death of george floyd.

headline: 'show respect and listen': scenes from australia’s first indigenous-run police station
standfirst: Amid growing global civil unrest against police brutality and racism, a small station 330km west of Uluru is trying things differently
lead_paragraph: as protests against police brutality and racism have spread around the world in the wake of the death of george floyd, two new films demonstrate the extremes of police dealings with indigenous australians.

headline: seattle police use teargas to disperse peaceful protesters – as it happened
standfirst: This live blog is closed.  Follow our continuing live coverage herel>i> Are you taking part in US protests after the death of George Floyd?r>i>i>Sign up to our  First Thing newsletterr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2020-06-03t09:31:48.491z">10.31am pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: an athlete, a father, a 'beautiful spirit': george floyd in his friends' words
standfirst: People who knew the man killed in a violent police incident say he was an ‘always cheerful’, ‘gentle giant’ who was laid off when Minnesota shut downl>i> George Floyd killing – follow live updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: before his  death beneath a minneapolis police officer’s knee,  george floyd was suffering the same fate as millions of americans during the coronavirus pandemic: out of work and looking for a new job.

headline: first thing: trump argues – for more than an hour – that biden will destroy us
standfirst: President claims ‘radical’ Biden is a threat to America as he announces intergalactic policy ideas. Plus, 17-year-old charged with murder after two shot dead at Kenosha protests over police brutality
lead_paragraph: good morning.

headline: there's a social pandemic poisoning europe: hatred of muslims |  patrycja sasnal  and yasemin el menouar
standfirst: If anti-Muslim prejudice is not targeted, steps to counter racism in Europe in the wake of BLM protests will be meaningless
lead_paragraph: rarely does the eu act so swiftly. less than four months since the killing of george floyd in police custody and the black lives matter campaign that spilled into europe and galvanised continent-wide protests, the eu is appointing its first ever  anti-racism coordinator. this brilliant idea will make little sense, however, if anti-muslim hatred is not part of their portfolio. because instead of building a “ truly anti-racist union”, as the president of the european commission, ursula von der leyen, would wish, we have so far built an anti-muslim one.

headline: $240 for ‘the breonna’: outrage as jewelry line uses names of police brutality victims
standfirst: Jewelry line shuts down after using protest debris to make pieces condemned for profiting from deaths of black people
lead_paragraph: the gibbes museum of art in charleston, south carolina, has pulled a controversial line commemorating black victims of police brutality this week, after receiving multiple critiques and accusations of co-opting trauma from black activists.

headline: george floyd killing triggers wave of activism around the world
standfirst: Protests have spread to UK, France, Israel, Australia, south-east Asia and parts of Africa
lead_paragraph: his face is on murals in belfast, on a shard of the berlin wall and on a blown-out building in idlib. “i can’t breathe,” some of the last words george floyd uttered as he was killed, are painted across a wall in montreal. a slaver’s statue in bristol has been uprooted. statues of a colonial king have been burned and defaced across belgium. in the netherlands, the prime minister says a blackface christmas ritual must end.

headline: how a decade of disillusion gave way to people power | rebecca solnit
standfirst: From Black Lives Matter and #MeToo to school climate strikes, the power of popular movements can no longer be ignored
lead_paragraph: as i write, immense protests are taking place in india against the  href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/21/citizenship-act-tushar-gandhi-great-grandson-india-muslim-infiltrators-backlash" title="">new anti-muslim law and hong kong activists, who have been  href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/24/hong-kong-police-teargas-disperse-christmas-eve-protests" title="">protesting for their own rights for months, stand in solidarity with the  href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2019/dec/22/hong-kong-police-clash-with-protesters-after-uighur-rally" title="">uighur people being persecuted on the other side of china. the decade will end in protest. but who can look back a decade when a week in trump time is like a century, and hardly anyone can remember the overstuffed chaos of the month before, let alone 2017, to say nothing of the remote era before he was president?

headline: racism in america is not the exception – it's the norm | nesrine malik
standfirst: Those clutching their pearls at police brutality think the US’s inherent virtue will prevail. But it was never there to begin with
lead_paragraph: when a black cnn reporter  was arrested live on air last week while covering the protests in minneapolis, it was met with denunciation that something like this could happen in the us. it was “ a sign of american disintegration”, wrote the washington post. the head of civil liberties grouptrong> trong>pen america called it a “ dystopian spectacle”. on social media, the accompanying indignation to his arrest was that: “this is america, arresting journalists for doing their job doesn’t happen here.” but the list of things that don’t supposedly happen in america continues to grow. peaceful protesters don’t get teargassed: this is america. presidents don’t threaten to  unleash troops on those protesting against killing and oppression: this is america.

headline: deray mckesson on black lives matter: 'it changed the country'
standfirst: The civil rights activist discusses the significance of the street demonstrations in Ferguson, Missouri, and what’s next for the movement as the 2020 election looms
lead_paragraph: the power of street protest. the disruption of technology. the fight for racial equality. the struggle against disillusionment. few have lived the high and lows of this decade as viscerally as deray mckesson of the black lives matter movement.

headline: aboriginal deaths in custody: black lives matter protests referred to our count of 432 deaths. it's now 437
standfirst: We published a new total of 434 on the day of the protests. But even that is already out of dater>l>i> Deaths Inside interactive: every Indigenous death in custody since 2008 trackedr>i>i> Full Story podcast: Australia’s shameful record on black deaths in custodyi>l>
lead_paragraph: over the weekend, black lives matter protests brought thousands on to the streets campaigning for an end to aboriginal deaths in custody.

headline: hopeful that minneapolis policing will change? meet the police union's chief ...
standfirst: Bob Kroll, who described George Floyd as a ‘violent criminal’, has a history of resisting any reform of a department with a history of racial abuse
lead_paragraph: amid the worst civil unrest in the us in half a century, there have been notably few americans willing to speak up on behalf of the man who lit the fuse: derek chauvin, the now former police officer charged with the murder of george floyd in minneapolis.

headline: roma boy 'kicked in face' highlights french police brutality claims
standfirst: Interior minister says he does not understand officers’ version of events
lead_paragraph: there are growing calls for justice from the families of two alleged victims of police violence in france including a 14-year-old roma boy left with severe facial injuries after his arrest.

headline: iopc launches investigation after alleged police brutality in birmingham
standfirst: The inquiry follows six complaints about overuse of force against black men in the city, including the use of stun guns
lead_paragraph: a police watchdog has launched an inquiry following allegations of racially motivated brutality including the use of stun guns by officers in birmingham.

headline: donations to inclusive publishers' appeal leap after george floyd killing
standfirst: Pandemic fundraiser for Knights Of and Jacaranda has seen donations of more than £100,000 in the past weekr>
lead_paragraph: more than £100,000 has poured in from the public over the last week to help diverse independent publishers in the uk survive the coronavirus pandemic.

headline: morning mail: trump demands protest crackdown, facebook staff rebel, 'fan in the stand' furore
standfirst: trong>Tuesdaytrong>: New York joins cities under curfew as George Floyd rallies continue. Plus: Queensland’s Nathan Turner tests negative to coronavirus after his death
lead_paragraph: good morning, this is emilie gramenz bringing you the main stories and must-reads on tuesday 2 june.

headline: the racism that killed george floyd was built in britain | afua hirsch
standfirst: This is not just ‘horrible stuff that happens in America’. Black people know we need to dismantle the same system here
lead_paragraph: pay attention to african americans.

headline: how do you stop the far-right using the punisher skull? make it a black lives matter symbol
standfirst: Gerry Conway, co-creator of the popular Marvel outlaw, has been appalled to see his iconography appropriated by white supremacists - and aims to turn the tables r>
lead_paragraph: sometimes it takes a bootleg t-shirt to stop a bootleg t-shirt. for years, the military, the police and white supremacists have displayed the skull symbol of marvel’s comic-book outlaw the punisher on unauthorised clothes, bumper stickers and spray-paint stencils. but, as black lives matter protests around the world draw attention to institutionalised racism, gerry conway, the punisher’s politically progressive co-creator and writer, is launching an unusual fundraiser:  his own line of shirts designed by people of colour to take the symbol back from the right, with proceeds to go to black lives matter.

headline: george clooney on george floyd killing: racism is america's pandemic
standfirst: ‘In 400 years we’ve yet to find a vaccine,’ writes actor in attack on Donald Trump’s response to demonstrations as ‘a racial dog whistle’
lead_paragraph: george clooney has called for a “systemic change” of law enforcement, criminal justice and political leadership in the us, in an essay reacting to the crisis triggered by the killing of  george floyd by minneapolis police officers last week. writing for  the daily beast, clooney said urgent action was required to combat the racism “pandemic” raging in the country.r/>r/>“there is little doubt that george floyd was murdered,” wrote clooney. “we watched as he took his last breath at the hands of four police officers.” he then praised the “defiant reaction” of millions of people around the world who are taking part in the demonstrations.r/>r/>“we don’t know when these protests will subside. we hope and pray that no one else will be killed. but we also know that very little will change. the anger and the frustration we see playing out once again in our streets is just a reminder of how little we’ve grown as a country from our original sin of slavery.

headline: trump claims 'radical left' have 'taken over' seattle during policing protests – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> Beyoncé demands justice for Breonna Taylori>i> Rayshard Brooks killing: Democrats lead calls for police reformi>i> Biden VP contenders in spotlight after Rayshard Brooks killingi>i> Robert Reich: Trump stokes division – and the oligarchy purrsr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2020-06-14t22:08:26.472z">11.08pm pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: #theshowmustbepaused: music industry plans day of silence for george floyd
standfirst: Stars including Quincy Jones and Billie Eilish join executives in promoting effort to halt operations as protests continuer>
lead_paragraph: on tuesday, the music industry will observe a “blackout day” in the wake of george floyd’s death and the protests raging across the country.

headline: democrats block 'empty' republican police reform bill
standfirst: l>i>Democrats say bill is a toothless response to police brutalityi>i>Rival reform bill expected to pass in the House this weeki>l>
lead_paragraph: congress was at a standstill on police reform on wednesday after senate democrats successfully blocked a republican bill criticized as a toothless response to police brutality.

headline: why antiracism protests are achieving more progress under trump than obama | cas mudde
standfirst: Between Trump, Covid-19, and police brutality, America is a perfect political storm. But the left must keep fighting even if Biden winsr>
lead_paragraph: the us is now in its fourth week of mass protests against institutional racism and police brutality. substantive debates about police reform – including formerly radical proposals to “ defund the police” – have entered the mainstream political discussion and in some cases already achieved  political traction. while it is still early, and history is a warning against too much optimism, it seems clear that the protests in the wake of the brutal murder of george floyd are producing more, and more concrete, results than similar recent protests did.

headline: coronavirus us: polls put biden ahead of trump as deaths top 1,000 a day – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> Texas hospital sets up ‘death panel’ as Covid-19 cases surgei>i> How Hawaii avoided a spike – but damaged its economyi>i> ‘White as hell’: are Portland protests eclipsing BLM?i>i>Sign up to our  First Thing newsletteri>l>

headline: the day bristol woke up to a new statue
standfirst: City responds to guerrilla installation of sculpture inspired by the day the Colston statue felll>i> Marc Quinn’s BLM statue divides art worldi>l>
lead_paragraph: when bristol went to bed on tuesday night, the question was theoretical: what should replace the toppled statue of the slave trader edward colston?

headline: reality v donald trump:the 3 july edition of the guardian weekly
standfirst: With his disastrous handling of the Black Lives Matter and coronavirus spiking again in parts of the US – has the president finally run out of road?  Get the Guardian Weekly delivered to your home
lead_paragraph: it was m>anotherm> eventful week  in the united states. on monday, the supreme court struck down a restrictive law that could have undone the landmark roe v wade abortion decision. meanwhile, it was revealed that  russia had allegedly offered bounties for attacks on us forces in afghanistan (something the president was told about in february, despite saying last weekend he hadn’t been). trong> trong>

headline: ‘i’m suffocating’: french delivery driver’s last words echo george floyd case
standfirst: Four police officers questioned for involuntary homicide over death of Cédric Chouviat
lead_paragraph: a french delivery driver who died after being arrested in paris pleaded, “i’m suffocating” several times as police held him to the ground.

headline: stocks rise despite us-china jitters; outdoor markets open in england – business live
standfirst: l>i> Global shares buoyed on relief over Trump’s China response and easing of coronavirus lockdownsr>i>i> Gold and silver climb as US cities rocked by protests over killing of George Floydi>i> UK and eurozone manufacturing declines ease while China’s factories return to growth in Mayi>l>

headline: 'creative activism' inspired by george floyd at forefront of london arts festival
standfirst: Roy Williams’ 846, a collection of audio plays, will be performed at Greenwich+Docklands festival
lead_paragraph: artists need to engage in “creative activism” to help combat racism, according to the creators of a piece of theatre inspired by the police killing of george floyd, which will take centre stage at the first major live arts festival since the covid-19 lockdown began.

headline: ten years of black twitter: a merciless watchdog for problematic behavior
standfirst: From Black Lives Matter to #OscarsSoWhite, the decade would not have been the same without black voices on social media
lead_paragraph: there is power in numbers. no internet subsection displayed this fact better than black twitter, which touched nearly every sphere of american culture and politics this decade.

headline: will europe face up to its colonial past? the 19 june guardian weekly
standfirst: As Black Lives Matter protests continue, we look at how the conversation has made countries in Europe look back more critically at their past Get the Guardian Weekly delivered to your home
lead_paragraph: last saturday, central london was taken over by counter-protesters, largely of the far right, who descended on westminster to protect the capital’s already boarded-up statues. in the midst of daylong attacks on the police, one man was photographed  urinating next to a memorial to a police officer killed in 2017 while trying to stop an act of terrorism. it was a depressing day. yet there was a hopeful moment: the sight of black lives matter supporter patrick hutchinson rescuing a white counter-protester from a skirmish and carrying him to safety.

headline: john boyega worries blm rally speech in june will harm career
standfirst: Actor reveals concerns and talks about being stopped and searched in new interview
lead_paragraph: john boyega has said he is genuinely worried that  his impassioned speech at a black lives matter protest in london in june will have damaging consequences for his career.

headline: 'deaths in our backyard': 432 indigenous australians have died in custody since 1991
standfirst: Aboriginal people whose family members have died in custody express solidarity with people on the streets of US cities protesting against the death of George Floyd
lead_paragraph: australia’s track record on deaths in custody is again under scrutiny, as aboriginal people whose family members died in similar circumstances to  george floyd express solidarity with protestors on the streets of major us cities following the death of the unarmed black man.

headline: persuasion, not coercion, should be the goal of blm and extinction rebellion | kenan malik
standfirst: XR activists who blockaded a newspaper print works and BLM supporters who urged Lauren Victor to raise her fist stepped over a line
lead_paragraph: “it is never ok to coerce people’s participation; that is just bullying.”  so wrote lauren victor last week. victor is a us black lives matter supporter who has participated in many blm protests. she is also the woman who, in a video that went viral, refused to raise her fist when a group of blm supporters invaded a restaurant in washington dc and demanded that all diners do so. why did she not comply? “i wholeheartedly support the black lives matter movement,” victor wrote. “however, i also support an individual’s choice to participate in a protest or not.”
