headline: sam newman resigns from channel nine after comments about george floyd
standfirst: Former player and host of the Footy Show was roundly condemned by colleagues, players and in a widely shared petition
lead_paragraph: the controversial afl commentator sam newman has resigned from all channel nine television shows after a petition to sack him was widely shared on friday.

headline: no ban on england fans singing swing low, sweet chariot at twickenham
standfirst: l>i>Lyrics of song linked to slavery will no longer be up in stadium i>i>England teams will be allowed to kneel for BLM before gamesi>l>
lead_paragraph: england supporters will not be banned from singing swing low, sweet chariot when allowed back into twickenham but it is understood the lyrics will no longer be emblazoned around the stadium and the rugby football union has stopped selling merchandise that references the song.

headline: trump complains about 'ugly anarchists' as police continue aggression on us protesters
standfirst: Seattle mayor tells Trump to ‘go back to your bunker’ after president threatens to take action as protests against racism and police brutality persist
lead_paragraph: donald trump has blamed “anarchists” and “domestic terrorists” for a protest in seattle overnight and threatened to intervene as anti-racism demonstrations again erupted across much of the us, in rage at the killing of  george floyd by police in minneapolis last month.

headline: first thing: with america ablaze, trump retreated to the bunker
standfirst: Fires burned near the White House as cities across the US imposed curfews to curb the George Floyd protests. Plus, Timothée Chalamet is Generation Z’s James Dean
lead_paragraph: good morning.

headline: osaka and gauff should not be discouraged from their protests | tumaini carayol
standfirst: The two young stars’ criticisms of police brutality after George Floyd’s killing were brave in a culture uneasy with black athletes speaking out
lead_paragraph: a couple of weeks ago naomi osaka decided that it was time to eradicate her shyness once and for all. it was exhausting, she said, missing out on moments because she was too terrified to speak in the presence of people she admired. her options for socialising limited in quarantine, she set up a series of interviews with players. before long, fellow players frances tiafoe, stefanos tsitsipas, gaël monfils and iga swiatek were her subjects. “i’m coming for every tennis reporter’s neck,” she said.

headline: texas the stage as golf makes closed-doors return to tournament play | ewan murray
standfirst: PGA Tour’s first event since March will mark the death of George Floyd at 8.46am and has the world’s top three grouped together for the first two rounds
lead_paragraph: in the most optimistic of outlooks, a journey which begins with ryan palmer cracking a tee shot at the colonial country club in forth worth, texas, will conclude with the crowning of a masters champion in front of adoring galleries at augusta on 15 november.

headline: uk protests: statue of 18th-century slave owner robert milligan taken down in london — as it happened
standfirst: Oxford students condemn university’s ‘silence’ on Cecil Rhodes; square in Plymouth named after slave trader to be renamedl>i> Protesters rally in Oxford for removal of Cecil Rhodes statuei>i> Derbyshire town’s ‘racist’ bust that faced removal is hidden by residentsi>i> All statues in London and Manchester to be reviewed for slavery linksi>i> Are you taking part in UK protests?r>i>i> US protests continue as George Floyd funeral takes place – live updatesi>l>

headline: what the george floyd protests have achieved in just two weeks
standfirst: Minneapolis committed to dismantling its police, New York City vowed to reform the NYPD and statues were toppled across the country
lead_paragraph: in the weeks since video evidence showed a police officer kneeling on the neck of george floyd, an unarmed black man, for almost nine minutes, protests have erupted across the us and the rest of the world.

headline: covid has highlighted america's flaws, says bank boss jamie dimon
standfirst: JP Morgan chief says pandemic and George Floyd killing magnify problems of racism and povertyl>i> Coronavirus – latest updatesi>i> See all our coronavirus coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: the jp morgan boss has said the covid pandemic and the police killing of george floyd have shone a spotlight on america’s flaws and its failure to address inequality and racism.

headline: movement to defund police gains 'unprecedented' support across us
standfirst: Activists say the way to stop police brutality and killings is to cut law enforcement budgets and reinvest in services. Some lawmakers now agree
lead_paragraph: thetrong> trong>movement to defund the police is gaining significant support across america, including from elected leaders, as  protests over the  killing of george floyd sweep the nation.

standfirst: James Mattis accuses Trump of dividing US and ordering military to violate constitutional rights of Americansl>i> James Mattis accuses Trump of dividing US i>i> Meghan, Duchess of Sussex speaks out over George Floyd killingr>i>i> Are you taking part in US protests?r>i>i>Sign up to our  First Thing newsletteri>l>

headline: a photo of my daughter and me at a black lives matter march made news. this is my story | greta morton elangué
standfirst: Representation is everything in this hypervisual world and there are so many ways to be black. What is mine?
lead_paragraph: on monday i discovered that a photo of myself and my eight-year-old daughter has appeared in the guardian. this is a first. i work in the arts but our life is private, quietly enclosed.

headline: roger robinson: 'poets can translate trauma'
standfirst: The writer and musician talks about his prize-winning poetry collection, his Caribbean education and why the death of George Floyd has been felt so strongly in the UK
lead_paragraph: roger robinson is a writer who has taught and performed worldwide. his fourth poetry collection, m>a portable paradisem>m>, m>won the royal society of literature’s ondaatje prize last month, an award for a work evoking the spirit of a place: while his previous books have focused on the memory of the caribbean, here he turns his gaze on england, unflinchingly portraying a place far from paradise as he tackles topics including the grenfell tower disaster, the windrush scandal, and the legacy of slavery. the collection also won the ts eliot prize and is shortlisted for the derek walcott prize. robinson was born in hackney in 1967 to trinidadian parents and moved to trinidad aged four, before returning to the uk at 19.

headline: 'i ain't voting till black lives matter': what does an activist's radical strategy mean for 2020?
standfirst: Walter ‘Hawk’ Newsome has built a campaign on encouraging black people to withhold their votes until black issues are addressed. Will it change this year’s election?
lead_paragraph: death was the catalyst for walter “hawk” newsome’s most contentious idea. it came to him during the first few days of july in 2016. this was the week that a minnesota police officer shot 32-year-old philando castile  five times and killed him in his car; an off-duty new york police officer  killed 37-year-old delron dempsey in front of his family; and two louisiana cops fatally shot alton sterling  six times.

headline: pass over review – spike lee directs antoinette nwandu’s masterful tragedy
standfirst: trong>Available onlinetrong>r>Lee’s 2018 film of Nwandu’s powerful play, written as a response to the shooting of Trayvon Martin, resonates after the George Floyd killing
lead_paragraph: two homeless men in spike lee’s film who inhabit a shabby street corner fear for their lives, although there is no visible threat. they joke and banter, but terror buzzes beneath the repartee. one keeps vigil while the other sleeps. their stalkers, it becomes clear, are the police, though their purported crimes remain undefined: “we’re just two black men standing here and we ain’t doing shit.” they puzzle over the death toll of black men around them. “what his crime is?” asks one man. “breathing while black?”

headline: 'he just doesn't get it': has trump been left behind by america's awakening on racism?
standfirst: The killing of George Floyd has been a turning point for for everyone but the president – who has seldom been so isolated from his own party and the public
lead_paragraph: longtime observers of donald trump have often compared him to an old man sitting at the end of a bar, holding forth with crazed opinions, overwhelming self-assurance and taboo-busting shock value guaranteed to draw a crowd.

headline: spike lee: send us your questions for the director of do the right thing and malcolm x
standfirst: What would you like to ask the man behind numerous seminal features – as well as recent shorts about New York in lockdown and the death of George Floyd?
lead_paragraph: for the past three decades, spike lee has been one of the most vital forces in film-making. his movies – snappy, engaged, uncompromising, entertaining, literate, disturbing – reinvigorated the cinematic landscape and shook the status quo.

headline: george floyd protests give fresh impetus to uk anti-racism campaign
standfirst: Thousands have taken to the streets, prompting concerns about risks of breaking lockdown rules
lead_paragraph: it was the week that britain’s young people stood up against racial injustice after watching the brutal killing of george floyd, declaring in their thousands that black lives matter via a succession of passionate and largely peaceful protests that show no sign of abating.

headline: spike lee: 'race relations today are the direct result of having a black president'
standfirst: Prior to the release of Da 5 Bloods, the director takes questions from readers, film-makers and politicians about George Floyd, Covid-19 and the worst thing about actors
lead_paragraph: for more than three decades,  spike lee has been one of the most vital forces in film-making. his latest movie, da 5 bloods – about four african american veterans who return to vietnam in search of the remains of their squad leader –  is described by peter bradshaw as “a blast of satire and emotional agony about … the fact that black deaths matter”.

headline: black pound day founder urges blm marchers to 'spend black'
standfirst: So Solid Crew’s Swiss says anti-racism activists should support black-owned businesses
lead_paragraph: people who attended anti-racism marches this summer should turn their attention “to what really matters” and spend their money with black-owned businesses, the founder of black pound day has said.

headline: 'revolting': trump condemned for saying george floyd is praising us economy
standfirst: President made the comments after better-than-expected jobs report showed national unemployment rate falling
lead_paragraph: donald trump was condemned on friday for making the “revolting, enraging, disrespectful” claim that george floyd, an african american man killed by police, is looking down from heaven and praising the us economy.

headline: set the night on fire by mike davis and jon wiener – review
standfirst: A history of 60s Los Angeles traces the city’s turbulent era of rebellion, police brutality and rise of the counterculture
lead_paragraph: in the mid-1960s, california occupied a singular place in the american popular consciousness as a perpetually sun-drenched, wave-lashed paradise populated by tanned white people. tv shows such as m> 77 sunset stripm> competed with teen movies such as m> beach partym>  and m> bikini beachm> to buoy up the myth, while a succession of classic beach boys hits hymned california’s endless summer.

headline: morning mail: george floyd charges, flawed coronavirus study, madeline mccann suspect
standfirst: trong>Thursdaytrong>: Three more officers charged over Minnesota death. Plus, why Alexis Wright’s novel Carpentaria gets into your bones
lead_paragraph: good morning, this is richard parkin bringing you the main stories and must-reads on thursday 4 june.

headline: we must confront racist history of uk parliament's art, says curator
standfirst: trong>Exclusive: trong>Officials looking again at collection of 9,000 pieces in light of BLM protests
lead_paragraph: the curator of parliament’s extensive art collection has acknowledged that many artefacts that adorn the plinths and corridors of westminster have a “racist history” and were bought with slave-owning and colonial wealth.

headline: uk schools: what are you doing for black history month?
standfirst: We’d like to hear from UK schools about plans for projects and activities during Black History Month that have come about because of the BLM protests this summer
lead_paragraph: black history month in the uk is observed in october and we’d like to find whether the  black lives matter protests across britain, during the summer, have inspired schools and teachers to provide any special projects or initiatives this year.

headline: fighting the racism that killed george floyd requires more than hashtags | nesrine malik
standfirst: White people must understand that true solidarity is helping the cause when it’s not fashionable to do so
lead_paragraph: every few years, being black becomes a macabre spectacle. what is usually a complicated private identity becomes a public one.  a black man is killed by a white police officer in the united states, and suddenly the world is attuned to your race.

headline: from blm to lgbt+: why sex and the city will need a 2020 rethink
standfirst: Back with a new name – and minus just one core cast member – the 90s classic show will have to update its race and sexual politics for a very different world
lead_paragraph: sex and the city is back, with a new name – and just like that … – and a new cast, which is to say, the old cast, minus samantha (kim cattrall). anyone who is surprised to see them recovered from the bruising experience of the movie sequel just has too long a memory. sex and the city 2  was more than 10 years ago. the statute of limitations on awful moments in culture has long since expired.

headline: spike lee releases short film as part of george floyd protests
standfirst: Lee intercuts footage of his 1989 film Do the Right Thing with that of the arrests of Floyd and Eric Garner – both of which resulted in their deathsl>i>trong>Warner: some viewers may find the following content distressingtrong>i>l>
lead_paragraph: spike lee has released a short film as  protests against the death of george floyd continue, which equates floyd’s treatment at the hands of police with  eric garner’s and radio raheem, the character in lee’s 1989 film  do the right thing.

headline: virgil abloh criticised for response to looting during george floyd protests
standfirst: Off-White and Louis Vuitton designer accused of not ‘reading the room’ in Instagram post about damage caused to streetwear shops in Los Angeles

headline: alfre woodard: 'we want all those with a stake in the death row business to see this film'
standfirst: The star of the award-winning film Clemency talks about the US prison system, her enslaved great-grandfather and her hopes for Black Lives Matterl>i> Read Mark Kermode’s five-star review of Clemencyi>l>
lead_paragraph: the focus of  black lives matter protests has inevitably fallen on the most visible injustice - instances of police brutality. more systemic racial disparities in the american penal system are too often hidden from plain sight. the us incarcerates more of its citizens –  2.2 million people – than any other country on earth. african american adults are nearly six times more likely to receive a prison sentence than white adults. nearly half of the 206,000 people serving life sentences in 2018 were black, though black people represent only 13.4% of the population; almost equal numbers of white and black prisoners are currently on death row – just over  1,000 of each ethnicity – but as the prosecution of capital punishment has declined, so the racial imbalance has increased.

headline: george floyd: reporting on a week of fury, pain and deep solidarity
standfirst: Guardian reporters in the US and around the world reflect on a week of profound unrest – and, possibly, change
lead_paragraph: this has been by far the most serious unrest i’ve covered in the us. r/>i was in ferguson six years ago where the protests looked more dramatic on the television than they actually were, with a few buildings looted and burned, and confrontations with the police a staged nightly ritual over the same few blocks. r/>minneapolis was on a different scale, both in the depth of anger and the levels of protest and destruction. many thousands turned out to lay siege to the police station in the precinct where george floyd was killed before they stormed and burned it. many thousands more marched in different parts of minneapolis and st paul before the protests spread across the country. r/>r/>for two nights in a row, the police evaporated – leaving a huge area around about three miles of a main shopping thoroughfare, lake street, under the control of protesters, looters and arsonists. hundreds of businesses had their windows smashed, were looted, or were burned. r/>r/>the scale of the demonstrations and destruction reflected the scale of the anger. r/>that seemed to me in part because of the video of george floyd’s death was so clear-cut and painful. it’s telling that so few people have tried to justify the former police officer derek chauvin’s kneeling on floyd’s neck for nearly nine minutes as the life drains out of him, unlike the many who spoke up in support of the officer who shot michael brown in ferguson. r/>r/>but that video also added to a sense of the frustration at yet another killing of an african american man by the police, and that so little seems to change even with the rise of black lives matter. the way that chauvin looks into the phone cameras, knowing he is being filmed, and kept his knee on floyd’s neck regardless of his pleas and cries for his mother seemed to symbolise the contempt of the police for the movement. r/>r/>as a result, the more peaceful demonstrations drew people who do not normally protest. i even met a few republicans who were horrified by what they saw on the video and thought the time had come to stand up.r/>r/>through all of this, social distancing broke down completely. riots in different times usually meant protesters tied bandanas or t-shirts around their faces to shield their identities. in 2020 everyone had a mask readily to hand. there were times when it looked as if the local medical school was charging the police accompanied by particularly fashionable rioters in designer masks.r/>r/>in a sign of our times, reporters found themselves not only hit with baton rounds and teargas by the police when it was clear they were shooting at journalists, but facing physical threats from some among the protesters. these tended to be young men, both white and black, who see the media as part of the conspiracy. r/>r/>and if you look like me (ageing, no hair), there’s the occasional person who imagines you are a police spy and lets you know with varying degrees of hostility. although this was pretty easily dealt with the moment they heard my accent.r/>

headline: 'i've seen grown men cry' – why avatar: the last airbender still touches millions

lead_paragraph: there is a scene in avatar: the last airbender that summons the ethereal enchantment and anguish of a  studio ghibli movie every time you watch it. iroh, the former crown prince of the imperial fire nation (voiced by the late japanese american actor mako), now a diminished, greying old man,  sits by the graveside of his son. drowning in regret and a gilded sunset, his gruff voice slides mournfully as he sings: “leaves from the vine, falling so slow, like fragile, tiny shells drifting in the foam.”

headline: royal academy summer exhibition review – as if the pandemic never happened
standfirst: trong>Royal Academy, Londontrong>r>Amid a sea of tasteful landscapes, only the BLM room and apocalyptic works by Tracey Emin and Anselm Kiefer are in tune with our troubled times
lead_paragraph: for some reason i expected a sense of urgency. the  royal academy summer exhibition has been directly hit by the pandemic – delayed until they’ve had to scribble “winter” over its traditional title. the academy itself is facing such financial chaos as a result of this year’s revenue loss it says it will have to sack 150 people,  or maybe sell its michelangelo. but if you arrive, as i did, anticipating a survey of the state of our harrowed souls, a great gathering of lockdown projects that take the rapid pulse of the time, you’re thinking of a very different institution. this place is more than 250 years old and, boy, does it feel like it.

headline: to honour george floyd, we must learn the lessons of the lawrence inquiry | matthew ryder
standfirst: A focus on accountability for police treatment of black people should be our first priority
lead_paragraph: outrage at the killing of  george floyd by a police officer in minneapolis has spread across the world in recent weeks. the horrific images of a man killed by a knee to his neck have resonated with cases of lethal injustice closer to home. in britain, among the names that come to mind is that of  stephen lawrence, the black teenager whose murder by white youths and the bungled investigation into it exposed the racism of our most powerful police force. but earlier this week neville lawrence, stephen’s father,  spoke publicly to remind us not only why that case was so important, but also of the danger of losing focus on what it taught us.

headline: could the killing of george floyd be a turning point for american denial? | emma brockes
standfirst: This latest death at the hands of police has sparked a sense of emergency, as the cracks in the American story are further exposed
lead_paragraph: it was don delillo, the novelist, who in the wake of 9/11 said of america, “the culture absorbs almost everything”. it’s a conservative reflex – to co-opt any rebellion into the country’s existing idea of itself – and as protests against the death of  george floyd roiled this week, you could see that reflex in action. instagram filled with solidarity from white people that sounded a lot like personal branding. corporations with terrible hiring records put out statements about standing together. a friend who works for a big company, on receiving a lachrymose global email from her ceo, said drily, “what is he talking about? they don’t even give us martin luther king day off.”

headline: the death of george floyd was an act of murder, plain and simple | ben crump and jasmine rand
standfirst: The Minneapolis police department’s failure to arrest the officers responsible threatens our most basic sense of justicer>
lead_paragraph: “get off of his neck.” “please! please!” “i can’t breathe.” police in america have far too many non-lethal ways to reliably kill black men without facing criminal charges. the weaponization of racism does not require a gun or a bullet. in this case, a police officer’s knee was the weapon used to kill  george floyd. the observing officers’ indifference was also a weapon used to kill floyd, and the minneapolis police department’s failure to arrest the officers responsible is a weapon threatening to kill our most basic sense of justice.

headline: ‘emmett till was my george floyd’: john lewis makes final rousing call for progress in essay

headline: george floyd killing: sister says officers should face murder charge as protests grow
standfirst: Street protests break out in Minneapolis and Los Angeles after Bridget Floyd says police officers involved ‘should be in jail’
lead_paragraph: the sister of george floyd, the black man killed by police in minneapolis after an incident  captured on video in which an officer knelt on his neck as he lay on the ground, has called for those involved in his death to be charged with murder.

headline: dispatch from minneapolis: the night the city cracked down on george floyd protests
standfirst: Protesters who refused to obey the curfew Saturday faced teargas, flash bombs and baton rounds from police
lead_paragraph: the governor had promised saturday would be different and it was.

headline: wnba players walk off court during national anthem before season opener
standfirst: l>i>New York and Seattle players walk off court during anthemi>i>Players say they are dedicating the season to Breonna Taylori>i> Sabrina Ionescu finishes with 12 points in patchy pro debuti>i> The WNBA embraced social justice years before it was cooli>l>
lead_paragraph: the new york liberty and seattle storm made a statement before tipping off the wnba season on saturday at the img academy in bradenton, florida.

headline: ‘a national crisis’: how the killing of george floyd is changing us politics
standfirst: As people protest across the US, Donald Trump and Joe Biden have offered divergent responses that point to a divisive political debate on race relations
lead_paragraph: riots in minneapolis and across the us triggered by video footage showing george floyd, a black man, killed under the knee of a police officer, has caused a dramatic shift in the national political debate in america and thrust race to the center of the stage.

headline: friday briefing: talk to us, us attorneys tell andrew
standfirst: Ghislaine Maxwell’s arrest increases pressure on royal … PM to warn people to behave when pubs reopen … Vivica A Fox on Trump and BLM
lead_paragraph: morning everyone. i’m martin farrer and these are the top stories this morning.

headline: how us k-pop fans became a political force to be reckoned with
standfirst: Expect more online raids of the kind that drowned out a racist BLM backlash and humiliated Donald Trump, experts say
lead_paragraph: it started as an attempt to blunt the impact of the black lives matter movement but it ended in derision. when the #whitelivesmatter hashtag appeared on twitter, its unintended descent into ridicule was driven not by hardened political activists but by a loose coalition of young people worldwide united by their love of south korean pop music.

headline: 'am i next?': coco gauff, stephen jackson join outcry over george floyd killing
standfirst: l>i>Former NBA player Jackson speaks at rally for fallen ‘friend’i>i>Teenage star Gauff issues call to action with powerful videoi>i>Bengals’ Joe Burrow, Dolphins’ Brian Flores also speak outi>l>
lead_paragraph: former nba player stephen jackson has said he will not allow the police to “demean the character” of his childhood friend, george floyd. jackson’s words come amid growing outcry from athletes over floyd’s death in police custody, including teenage tennis star coco gauff.

headline: nine out of 10 americans say racism and police brutality are problems, poll finds
standfirst: l>i>69% of those over 55 see racism as serious problemi>i>Majorities back range of police reforms but wary of ‘defunding’i>l>
lead_paragraph: nine in 10 americans believe that racism and police violence are problems in the country, a guardian/ opinium research poll has found, a sign that public opinion is shifting away from the views put forward by donald trump.

headline: death of man after face mask arrest shines light on mexican police brutality
standfirst: Video shows officers forcing man into a police truck as bystanders plead for his release
lead_paragraph: mexicans have responded with outrage after a man was found beaten to death hours after he was arrested by police officers for not wearing a face mask in public.

headline: 'it was time to take charge': the black youth leading the george floyd protests
standfirst: Members of Generation Z are organizing events and registering voters across the US as activism shapes their own lives
lead_paragraph: shayla avery texted a friend after the police killing of george floyd in minneapolis, nearly 2,000 miles away in berkeley, california.

headline: delroy lindo: 'british racism is as violent and virulent as america's'
standfirst: The US actor is starring as a black Trump supporter in Spike Lee’s Da 5 Bloods. He talks about the racism he endured in Britain – and why the George Floyd protests are a sign of hope
lead_paragraph: delroy lindo has waited 25 years to work with spike lee again and da 5 bloods gives him one of the best roles of his career. but when he first read the script, the actor had a few questions about his character. chiefly: “does he have to be a trump supporter?”

headline: run the jewels: ‘i want the oppressors to know they haven’t created complete hopelessness’
standfirst: After Killer Mike’s impassioned speech about the death of George Floyd went viral, he and his partner El-P explain why a mix of serious politics and surreal goofiness makes their music perfect for our times
lead_paragraph: run the jewels have enjoyed one of the more improbable rises to fame in recent hip-hop history. two figures nearing 40, from the genre’s margins – killer mike on the fringes of outkast’s atlanta-based circle of rappers and producers, his partner el-p a founder member of company flow and longstanding critical darling of east coast underground rap – who pooled their resources to record a mixtape. they gave it away and watched, astonished, as it and its two successors became runaway successes.

headline: brees sorry after lebron james leads backlash to qb's criticism of anthem protests
standfirst: l>i>QB said he does not agree with peaceful protest during anthemi>i>Comments came in wake of police killing of George Floydi>i>Does not say whether he has changed views in statementi>l>
lead_paragraph: new orleans saints quarterback drew brees has apologized for his lack of “compassion or empathy” after he said he disagrees with athletes protesting against racism during the national anthem.

headline: the george floyd uprising has brought us hope. now we must turn protest to policy
standfirst: We have begun to see progress against racial injustice. But even as we march, we must fight – and vote – for our very lives
lead_paragraph: the slow-motion execution of george floyd has ignited an incandescent social movement. in  every state and around the world, people of all colors, genders, and ages are coming together to march in fury and in hope, to renounce the past and redeem the future.

headline: the uprising - the george floyd protests: the 12 june guardian weekly
standfirst: This week we look back at the Black Lives Matters protests that have spread across the globe – and the impact they’re having. Plus, what a second wave of Covid-19 could look like.  Live coverage here Get the Guardian Weekly delivered to your home
lead_paragraph: the black lives matter protests that spread from minnesota across the planet in the past few weeks have already created tangible change. in minneapolis, where  george floyd was killed, city officials have committed to dismantling the police force; statues of confederates and slave owners across the us have been toppled – as has  a notorious example in the uk and, around the world, the daily reality of systemic racism has been further exposed – especially to white people. this week, we begin with six black writers offering their thoughts on the impact of the protests before chris mcgreal chronicles a week that rocked the world and kenya evelyn looks back at floyd’s life and the burden of being black in the united states.

headline: japan's public broadcaster condemned over 'offensive' blm anime
standfirst: Social media users have condemned the video for perpetuating stereotypes of African-Americans
lead_paragraph: japan’s public broadcaster, nhk, has come under fire after its attempt to explain the  black lives matter movement in anime form was condemned as offensive and misleading.

headline: the george floyd murder and covid-19 have hurt trump, but maybe not fatally
standfirst: The president’s approval ratings have dipped sharply but he could still beat Biden
lead_paragraph: voter disapproval of donald trump’s handling of the george floyd protests and the covid-19 pandemic, plus the accompanying economic meltdown, have undoubtedly hurt the president’s re-election chances.

headline: 'what if i was george floyd?': jaguars march to sheriff’s office amid nfl outcry
standfirst: l>i>Jaguars march from stadium to sheriff’s office as team in protesti>i>NFL’s biggest stars send video to league about racial inequalityi>i> Goodell: NFL was ‘wrong’ to not listen to player on protestsi>l>
lead_paragraph: the jacksonville jaguars marched from their home stadium to the steps of the local sheriff’s department in protest of inequality and police brutality on friday, joining an unprecedented groundswell that’s brought together some of the nfl’s biggest stars.

headline: trump says white people also killed by police, when asked about george floyd – as it happened
standfirst: l>i> President makes remarks in CBS News interviewi>i> Trump administration agrees to rescind policy on foreign student visasr>i>i> Biden unveils $2tn clean energy proposali>i> Ghislaine Maxwell denied baili>i> California dramatically rolls back reopening processi>i> How racial bias dogs US coronavirus response at every levelr>i>i> Alabama, Maine and Texas vote in primariesi>i>Sign up to our  First Thing newsletterr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2020-07-15t00:09:54.436z">1.09am pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: ‘we’re suffering the same abuses’: latinos hear their stories echoed in police brutality protests
standfirst: In a three year span, Latinos in California represented 46% of deadly police shootings – second to the rates for African Americans
lead_paragraph: on saturday night, just before 11, california highway patrol officers opened fire on the car erik salgado was driving in east oakland, killing the 23-year-old and injuring his pregnant girlfriend.

headline: lewis hamilton says blm protest is human rights issue, not about politics
standfirst: l>i>Hamilton expects new rules to ban repeat of his T-shirt protesti>i>FIA set to clarify in Sochi what drivers can and cannot weari>l>
lead_paragraph: lewis hamilton has insisted his support for anti-racism and protests against incidences of racial injustice will not be inhibited by any new fia rulings. hamilton attracted controversy at the last meeting at mugello by wearing a t-shirt bearing the words  href="https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2020/sep/15/lewis-hamilton-escapes-censure-for-breonna-taylor-t-shirt-vows-keep-protesting-amid-fia-review-motor-racing" title="">“arrest the cops that killed breonna taylor” before and after the race.

headline: uk coronavirus: pm says prof ferguson's claim that delaying lockdown by a week doubled death toll is 'premature' – as it happened
standfirst: Imperial College academic’s team wrote paper that led to UK government announcing the lockdown;  UK records a further 245 coronavirus deaths, taking total to 41,128l>i> Earlier UK lockdown ‘could have saved 20,000 lives’r>i>i> ‘Support bubble’ plan lets single parents in England combine householdsi>i> UK economy likely to suffer worst Covid-19 damage, says OECDr>i>i> Coronavirus global updates – liver>i>i> Black Lives Matter protests – livei>i> Evening summaryi>l>

headline: george floyd: protesters clash with secret service as unrest comes to the white house
standfirst: l>i>Police form barricade as hundreds line up outside White Housei>i> Trump has inflamed tensions as protests rage across USr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: the unrest has come to donald trump’s doorstep as protesters clash with the secret service and police outside the white house for the second successive day.r/>r/>chanting “i can’t breathe”, “black lives matter” and “fuck donald trump!”, hundreds of demonstrators on saturday circled the white house grounds, which have come to resemble a fortress more than at any time in recent memory.r/>r/>armored secret service, along with district of columbia police and park police, lined up in front of the protesters, forming a barricade as the us president returned to the white house from a trip to florida. lafayette square, the park in front of the executive mansion, was sealed off with steel barriers.

headline: trump says chokeholds sound 'innocent and perfect' and compares himself to lincoln
standfirst: President calls plan for Juneteenth rally ‘a celebration’ despite its location in Tulsa, known for massacre of African Americansl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: donald trump further stoked controversy over race issues and policing by remarking on friday that chokeholds sounded “so innocent and so perfect”, and once again claimed he has been the best president for black americans – only partially conceding that abraham lincoln may have surpassed him.

headline: ‘the man who shot my mum is still living his life’: cherry groce's son on life after police brutality
standfirst: Lee Lawrence was 11 when armed officers broke into his bedroom and shot his mother, paralysing her from the chest down. Has he finally found something close to justice?l>i> Read an extract from his book i>l>
lead_paragraph: lee lawrence was seven when he decided he wanted to be a police officer. he adored cop shows:  href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2014/mar/18/favourite-tv-starsky-hutch" title="">starsky  href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/tvandradioblog/2014/mar/18/favourite-tv-starsky-hutch" title="">& hutch,  href="https://www.theguardian.com/tv-and-radio/2014/jul/17/the-professionals-box-set-review" title="">the professionals,  href="https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0075488/" title="">chips – you name it, he watched it. yes, there were the chases, thrills and spills, but it was more than that. “there was always that sense in me, as a kid, that i like fairness, i want to help people, to be the good guy.”

headline: stocks shrug off us unrest, china tensions amid easing of covid-19 lockdowns - as it happened
standfirst: Rolling coverage of the latest economic and financial news, as tensions simmer across the US and Hong Kongl>i> George Floyd killing: widespread curfews fail to stop fresh wave of protests across USi>i> US may take in Hongkongers ahead of China security laws, Pompeo suggestsi>l>

headline: night of flames and fury as minneapolis swells with outrage over george floyd killing
standfirst: The 3rd precinct station was not the only building that burned overnight, as furious protesters’ demand for justice intensified
lead_paragraph: the moment the convoy of police cars crashed through the locked gates out of minneapolis’s 3rd precinct station and made a dash for safety, the crowd knew that the area was theirs.

headline: ‘stop treating protests like coachella’: influencers criticized for capitalizing on movement
standfirst: Some influencers exposed for staging photoshoots within protests while others called out for makeup trends that promote blackfacel>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: as the world faces a reckoning over racism and police violence, social media influencers are being blasted for making the movement about themselves.

headline: ministers show how world beating they are all over again | john crace
standfirst: From Hancock being forced to bin the test and trace app to Raab’s BLM gaffe, who can rival the cabinet for incompetence?
lead_paragraph: for months now the government has been prefacing all its coronavirus briefings as world-beating when the only thing in which we appeared to be global leaders was our mortality rates. but now i’m beginning to think boris johnson and his cabinet may have been on to something after all. because it’s beginning to look more and more as if we are genuine world beaters: if only in total incompetence.

headline: george floyd killing: journalist arrested while reporting on minneapolis protest; trump calls protesters 'thugs' - as it happened

For all the latest updates, click on this link.l>i>Minnesota governor has called on the national guard and Minneapolis has declared a local emergencyi>i>Twitter adds disclaimer to Trump tweet, saying it ‘glorifies violence’i>i>Read more:  George Floyd killing: fires erupt in Minneapolis as US rocked by third night of protestsi>i> Two officers involved previously reviewed for use of forcei>i> Coronavirus – latest global updatesr>i>i>Get a fresh perspective on America – sign up to our  First Thing newsletteri>l>

headline: merriam-webster to revise racism definition after woman’s campaign
standfirst: Kennedy Mitchum, who asked dictionary to update definition, said racism is ‘prejudice combined with social and institutional power’ l>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: in a blow to arguments that end with “well, m>thism> is the dictionary definition of racism”, the dictionary definition of racism is being revised.

headline: how the killing of george floyd exposed hong kong activists' uneasy relationship with donald trump
standfirst: The US president may be the pro-democracy movement’s biggest backer, but some protesters feel they are being used
lead_paragraph: hong kong’s pro-democracy movement has struggled to reconcile the support it has received from donald trump with his administration’s brutal crackdown on protests over the police killing of george floyd.

headline: 'that was crazy to me': black film-maker captures own pepper-spraying by us police
standfirst: Documentarian Christopher Frierson was displaying a press badge when he was sprayed – protesters quickly came to his aidl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: the wrenching agony caused by excessive use of force by riot police on  media people and protesters has been captured by an african american film-maker who was temporarily blinded after he was pepper-sprayed in the face.

headline: top un human rights expert urges us to listen to demands of protesters
standfirst: Agnès Callamard says killing of Rayshard Brooks ‘makes my stomach turn’ and pushes for radical changes to end police killingsl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: the killing of african americans like george floyd and rayshard brooks by police officers is a systemic problem in the us which requires profound changes that go way beyond prosecutions and police reforms, according to the un special rapporteur on extrajudicial, summary or arbitrary executions.

headline: it will be a team decision if we protest over george floyd, says jason holder
standfirst: l>i>West Indies captain says full squad will be on ‘same page’i>i>Tourists delighted to be in Manchester and playing againi>l>
lead_paragraph: it is just as well that jason holder is an experienced, intelligent captain – and diplomat – as he heads up an unusual expedition in unusual circumstances.

headline: cummings recruit sacked after suggesting police use 'live rounds' on blm protesters
standfirst: Exclusive: data specialist appointed after responding to call by Boris Johnson’s chief adviser for ‘weirdos and misfits’l>i> How civil servants’ concerns about racism led them to Cummings recruit’s tweeti>l>
lead_paragraph: a data specialist recruited to the civil service following dominic cummings’ call for “weirdos and misfits” to work for the uk government was sacked recently after posting on social media that police should use live rounds against black lives matter demonstrators, the guardian can reveal.

headline: rockets and blue lights review – swirling journey through black history
standfirst: trong>Available onlinetrong>r>Winsome Pinnock’s play, responding to JMW Turner’s Slave Ship painting, is a timely contribution to the Black Lives Matter campaignl>i> Hottest front-room seats: the best theatre and dance to watch onlinei>l>
lead_paragraph: when the bbc programmed rockets and blue lights as part of its  lockdown theatre festival, it had good cause to think it was on to a winner. here was a play, pulled after three previews because of the covid-19 pandemic, written by  winsome pinnock, the first black woman to have a play staged at the national theatre, directed by miranda cromwell and produced by the manchester royal exchange. it had form.

headline: tuesday briefing: covid's toll on lungs vicious – expert
standfirst: UK vaccine scientists begin human trials … family of Rayshard Brooks call for calm in BLM protests … and the cut-and-run trade of lockdown hairdressing
lead_paragraph: hello, warren murray here to make sure you keep up with the pack.

headline: bootsy collins: 'we're all funky, just not all of us know it'
standfirst: The P-Funk bassist was a street kid in the 60s, got his break with James Brown, then spent much of the 70s taking LSD. He talks about drugs, racism, police brutality – and the healing power of musicr>
lead_paragraph: at the age of 17, william “bootsy” collins packed up his homemade bass guitar and left home to tour the world with james brown. he was heading off in pursuit of the funk. or, as he calls it now – aged 68, in his high-pitched rasp down the phone from cincinnati, ohio – “the fonk”.

headline: as the george floyd protests continue, let's be clear where the violence is coming from | rebecca solnit
standfirst: Using damage to property as cover, US police have meted out shocking, indiscriminate brutality in the wake of the uprising
lead_paragraph: the word “violence” is going to be used a lot to describe the  events in us cities over the weekend and all this week. so it’s going to be important to be clear about who is violent and what violence is. property destruction and harming human beings are profoundly different actions, and with a few exceptions (seemingly interlopers in the protests) virtually all the violence visited on human beings during this round of civil unrest across the us has been inflicted by police.

headline: distrust of police is major driver of us gun violence, report warns
standfirst: Police brutality, over-enforcement of small infractions and high numbers of unsolved homicides have eroded trust in law enforcement
lead_paragraph: the lack of trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve is a major driver of gun violence in cities across the united states,  a new report by the giffords law center to prevent gun violence warns.

headline: why the officers fired for the george floyd killing could ultimately get their jobs back
standfirst: Officers in the US are frequently rehired after termination for misconduct – and it increases the likelihood of abuse and killings by police, experts say
lead_paragraph: the four minneapolis officers involved in  the killing of george floyd were swiftly fired after  footage of his death went viral.

headline: family of david dungay, who died in custody, express solidarity with family of george floyd
standfirst: Aboriginal man said ‘I can’t breathe’ 12 times before he died while being restrained by five guards in Sydney jail
lead_paragraph: the family of david dungay, an aboriginal man who said “i can’t breathe” 12 times before he died while being restrained by five prison guards, said they have been traumatised anew by footage of the recent deathof an unarmed black man in the us, george floyd.

headline: george floyd killing: fires erupt in minneapolis as us rocked by third night of protests
standfirst: l>i>Minnesota governor calls in national guard amid unresti>i>Demonstrations broke out in New York, Colorado and Californiai>l>
lead_paragraph: cities across the us were convulsed by protests on thursday night over the police killing of george floyd, a 46-year old black man, as demonstrators stormed the police headquarters of the officers involved in his death in minneapolis and donald trump threatened to use violence to suppress the unrest.

headline: police officers shoot and kill los angeles security guard: 'he ran because he was scared'
standfirst: Sheriff’s deputies chased and shot dead Andres Guardado, 18, a security guard at an auto repairs shopl>i> Juneteenth: live coveragei>l>
lead_paragraph: after sheriff’s deputies chased and shot dead a security guard at an auto repairs shop in los angeles on thursday evening, family members have identified the dead man  to local media as andres guardado, 18.

headline: allyship or stunt? marc quinn’s blm statue divides art world
standfirst: Artist’s sculpture to replace Edward Colston criticised as a ‘votive statue to appropriation’
lead_paragraph: marc quinn’s  statue of a black lives matter protester has divided opinion in the art world with critics calling it a “an opportunistic stunt”, while booker prize-winning author  bernardine evaristo said it showed “initiative” and “active allyship”.

headline: us books world rocked by racism rows
standfirst: Questions over the response of the Poetry Foundation and the National Book Critics Circle to BLM protests have sparked a wave of resignationsr>
lead_paragraph: the us literary establishment is in turmoil after a wave of resignations from the poetry foundation and the national book critics circle over their responses to black lives matter protests.

headline: anger mounts over selective us curfew rules: 'a license to decide who to arrest'
standfirst: Orders give police leeway to decide when to arrest someone for violating curfew, creating situations ripe for abuse, experts warnl>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: cities across the us have enacted curfews in an attempt to quell the unrest over the killing of george floyd in police custody. but the selective enforcement of the curfew orders only underscores the demonstrators’ message about law enforcement abuses, civil liberties experts warn.

headline: who was edward colston and why was his bristol statue toppled?
standfirst: Slave trader was a member of the Royal African Company which had a monopoly on the west African trade in the late 17th centuryl>i> BLM protesters topple statue of Bristol slave trader Edward Colston i>l>
lead_paragraph: the statue of slave trader edward colston that was toppled from its plinth and pushed into the docks by protesters has long caused anger and divided opinion in bristol.

headline: teen charged in killings of blm protesters considered himself a militia member
standfirst: Kyle Rittenhouse, 17, appears to have long been interested in law enforcement and claimed he was at protest to protect businesses
lead_paragraph: kyle rittenhouse, who is suspected of involvement in  fatally shooting two people and wounding another during the kenosha, wisconsin, protests on tuesday night, appears to have long been interested in law enforcement – and considered himself a militia member working to protect property, social media posts and reports indicate.

headline: detroit’s star activist adds blm rally to her 50 years of rebellion
standfirst: Leni Sinclair was at the heart of the city’s radical music and politics in the 1960s. Now 80, she reflects on today’s struggle for equality and social changer>
lead_paragraph: defying covid-19 and advancing years, leni sinclair left home recently to join a black lives matter demonstration in detroit. “it was exhilarating,” the 80-year-old rock photographer and radical activist of 1960s counterculture said last week. “but i did my marching 50 years ago.”

headline: american convulsion - inside the 5 june edition of the guardian weekly
standfirst: The killing of George Floyd has led to another extraordinary crisis in American life. Can it also help bring systemic change? For home delivery of our international news magazine,  click here
lead_paragraph: on tuesday, much of the world woke up to the extraordinary sight of peaceful protesters outside the white house being teargassed so that the president could pose with a bible outside the nearby st john’s church.

headline: amber guyger guilty of murdering black neighbor botham jean in his own home
standfirst: l>i>Ex-officer shot and killed Jean in his apartment last yeari>i>Chants of ‘black lives matter’ after guilty verdict read outi>l>
lead_paragraph: a former police officer who argued she had a right to use lethal force when she killed an innocent man after mistakenly entering his apartment has been convicted of murder.

headline: trump and republicans use calls to 'defund the police' to attack democrats
standfirst: The president and his allies are trying to turn national debate over racism and policing against the party and its 2020 nomineel>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: donald trump is “appalled” by calls to “ defund the police”. the senate majority leader, mitch mcconnell, called the suggestion “outlandish”. and the house minority leader, kevin mccarthy,  promised police officers “republicans will never turn our backs on you”, unveiling a new line of attack ahead of the november elections.

headline: man drives car into seattle protest crowd and shoots demonstrator
standfirst: l>i>Suspect dashed through crowd and turned himself over to policei>i>Injured man, 26, in stable condition after being shot in armi>i> George Floyd killing – latest US updatesi>l>
lead_paragraph: a man drove his car into a crowd of protesters in seattle on sunday, then shot and wounded a demonstrator who confronted him as he came to a stop, according to police and eyewitness video.

headline: new york police hunt car that drove into blm protesters in times square
standfirst: l>i>Video shows car moving through crowd with horn blaringi>i>No one appeared to be seriously injured in incidenti>l>
lead_paragraph: the new york police department says it is trying to find a car that drove through a group of black lives matter protesters blocking a street in times square on thursday night.

headline: 'it isn't a tick-box': young blm activists on black history month in uk schools
standfirst: Young people energised by a year of protest want changes to the way black history is taughtl>i> Ten black history events that should be taught to every pupili>l>
lead_paragraph: for  young people who took part in the summer’s protests, this year’s  black history month is arguably one of the most important since it was first celebrated in the uk in 1987.

headline: us police forcefully crack down on protesters as curfews fail to stop demonstrations – as it happened
standfirst: President threatens to deploy military as demonstrations continue nationwidel>i> Follow coverage of the protests on our new live blogi>l>
lead_paragraph: class="block-time published-time"> ime datetime="2020-06-02t10:29:23.117z">11.29am pan class="timezone">bstpan>ime>

headline: morning mail: hospital staff infected, blm ultimatum, second thai rock warning
standfirst: trong>Monday:trong> How Australia’s frontline healthcare workers are getting coronavirus. Plus, the former Manus detainee free today but ‘overwhelmed with guilt’
lead_paragraph: good morning, this is emilie gramenz bringing you the main stories and must-reads on monday 27 july.

headline: kick it out urges all players to take knee over george floyd and no fa sanctions
standfirst: l>i>Chair Sanjay Bhandari wants protests at Premier League gamesi>i>Liverpool squad take a knee at Anfield training i>l>
lead_paragraph: the chairman of kick it out has urged every premier league footballer to take a knee when the season resumes in protest against  href="https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2020/may/29/george-floyd-killing-protests-police-brutality" title="">the killing of george floyd by police in minneapolis, adding that the football association should not punish players who use their platforms to call for social change.

headline: 'i can't breathe': nypd fires officer who put eric garner in chokehold
standfirst: Daniel Pantaleo held Garner in chokehold before his death, and his words became rallying cry for Black Lives Matter movement

lead_paragraph: black lives matters protesters in bristol have pulled down a statue of the slave trader edward colston.

headline: k-pop fans join forces to drown out opposition to #blacklivesmatter
standfirst: Social media bombardment saw K-pop fans commandeer rightwing and pro-Donald Trump hashtags including #WhiteLivesMatterl>i> Live coverage of the US protestsi>l>
lead_paragraph: k-pop fans around the world have joined forces to drown out online opposition to the  black lives matter movement, flooding social media with videos and images of their favourite artists alongside the #whitelivesmatter hashtag and other racist content.

headline: britain's urban fabric comes under spotlight shone by blm protests
standfirst: Force of history demands re-evaluation of colonial statues and street names
lead_paragraph: cities have always been about apportioning and memorialising power; about writing force into space. britain’s colonial and imperial past is inscribed into the bricks and mortar of every city and town in the country. mostly this hidden text of power relations and wealth acquisition lies dormant in the half-forgotten significance of street names, in the knotty iconography of grand facades, in the barely read inscriptions on memorials and sculptures, in the nomenclature of grand public buildings. forming the backdrop of lived lives, these omnipresent clues are rarely fully decoded. the most monumental of sculptures has a habit of fading away to near invisibility if it is sufficiently familiar.

headline: watford's andre gray: 'it's not just about george floyd – we are still stereotyped and judged by police here'
standfirst: In a searing interview, the Watford striker – a keen student of black American history – explores the sad normality of the tragic scenes in Minneapolis and his own experiences of living in a racist world
lead_paragraph: it is a simple point but one andre gray wants to make, lest anyone in the united kingdom has failed to grasp it. the  marches and protests that have swept the major cities in recent days have not only been about george floyd, the unarmed black man who died at the hands of a white police officer in minneapolis on the monday before last – or, more precisely, his left knee, when it was applied with remorseless force to the side of floyd’s neck during an arrest.

headline: blm supporter speaks out after carrying counter-protester to safety
standfirst: Photo of Patrick Hutchinson coming to the man’s aid went viral after Saturday’s protests
lead_paragraph: the black lives matter demonstrator who carried a counter-protester to safety during saturday’s protests in london has spoken out about the moment he decided to intervene to help the man.

headline: the 10 best statues in britain – chosen by our critic
standfirst: There’s more to British statues than the ones of Colston and Rhodes highlighted by BLM. From Damien Hirst’s sword-fighter to a cat called Hodge, our critic picks his top 10
lead_paragraph: the ship,  which sank in 1912 with more than 1,500 souls drowned, has become a symbol of the precariousness of existence. it is commemorated by this marble monument in the city where the doomed ocean liner was built. a female mythological figure of fate looms over a drowning sailor held in a mermaid’s embrace. created by sculptor thomas brock and erected in 1920, it’s a passionate exception to the often tight-lipped statuary of imperial britain.

headline: online influencers under fire for blacking up in support of blm
standfirst: Instagram stars with millions of followers post photos of themselves painted half black
lead_paragraph: social media influencers have been criticised for attempting to show solidarity with the black lives matter movement by blacking up.

headline: pass over review – fiercely relevant and compelling

lead_paragraph: antoinette nwandu wrote pass over partly as a response to  trayvon martin’s shooting but it was also inspired by  waiting for godot and the biblical book of exodus. alongside this, the play aims to show “black americans wrestling with the dregs of the american dream”.

headline: black lives matter's alicia garza: ‘leadership today doesn't look like martin luther king’
standfirst: In seven years, BLM has gone from hashtag to global rallying cry. So why has the co-founder stepped away from the movement she helped create?l>i> Read an exclusive extract from Alicia Garza’s new book i>l>
lead_paragraph: alicia garza is not synonymous with  href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/black-lives-matter-movement" title="">black lives matter, the movement she helped create, and that’s very deliberate. the 39-year-old organiser is not interested in being the face of things; she’s interested in change. “we are often taught that, like a stork, some leader swoops from the sky to save us,” she tells me over zoom from her home in oakland, california. that sort of mythologising, she says, “obscures the average person’s role in creating change”.

headline: greek activists warn of surge in police brutality and rights violations

headline: 'we are not safe': india's muslims tell of wave of police brutality
standfirst: Police in Uttar Pradesh state have embarked on ‘reign of terror’ against Muslims in wake of new citizenship law
lead_paragraph: it was midnight at a police barracks in the indian state of uttar pradesh and in a freezing windowless room about 150 muslim men and boys sat huddled, bloodied and bruised. some of the shivering prisoners had raw gashes across their hands and faces, others had broken limbs splayed out at awkward angles. the beatings from police came frequently, according to multiple corresponding accounts; to those who asked for water or closed their eyes in drowsiness or simply did nothing at all. over and over, metal rods and bamboo canes hit soft human skin. some had been stripped of their clothes. the youngest among them was just 12 years old, said witnesses.

headline: american skin review: nate parker is noble victim in compromised comeback

lead_paragraph: if there exists a cursed cinema at the venice film festival, it is surely the sala casino, the smallest theatre on site, with its big steel door and its exposed white wall and a queuing system that leaves its guests broiling for an hour in the afternoon sun. it was here, two years ago, that they screened the latest james toback, just weeks before the guillotine came down. and it is here, this year, where they play the new film from nate parker. the sala casino is like the roach motel. the pictures check in but they may not check out.

headline: defacement: the tragic story of basquiat's most personal painting
standfirst: The death of artist Michael Stewart, allegedly the result of police brutality, inspired Basquiat to create one of his most impactful works
lead_paragraph: “it could have been me,” jean-michel basquiat would say at the mere mention of the untimely death of michael stewart. stewart, a 25-year-old artist, was allegedly drawing on the walls of the subway on 15 september 1983 when he was approached by transit cops who then placed him under arrest. witnesses say they saw the cops throw him to the ground after exiting the train station and beat him, while the cops involved reported that he fell after attempting to escape police custody. he would later die, after 13 days in the hospital, where bruising and brain damage would indicate he was strangled. the police officers involved were subsequently acquitted of any wrongdoing.

headline: the hate u give's amandla stenberg on bringing black lives matter to the box office
standfirst: Stenberg is the star of a new adaptation of the YA novel phenomenon. The actor, and the film’s director, discuss cinema’s new generation of resistance r>
lead_paragraph: any resemblance between  the hate u give and your average teen movie evaporates about 20 minutes in, when 16-year-old starr carter, played by  amandla stenberg, witnesses a police officer shoot dead her friend khalil at point-blank range. by this stage, starr’s father has already given her the talk, the time-honoured ritual where african-american parents instruct their children how to behave if stopped by the police: be polite, stay calm, put your hands where they can see them. when their car is pulled over, starr follows the drill. khalil reaches for a hairbrush. the police officer thinks it’s a gun. that’s all it takes.

lead_paragraph: the peace and quiet of a south memphis neighborhood gave way to chaos on monday, as more than two dozen police cars, most unmarked, blocked off the street before officers raided two homes.

headline: common struggle: black lives matter leader talks of painful parallels with indigenous australia
standfirst: Countries can acknowledge their histories without being captive to them, says Hawk Newsome, who is visiting Sydney
lead_paragraph: the death of black teenager travyon martin – shot six years ago by a neighbourhood watch volunteer who thought he looked suspicious in a hoodie – sparked three words on a facebook post, black lives matter. since then, there has been progress and frustration in the name of the cause.r/>

headline: 'they didn't give a damn': first footage of croatian police 'brutality'
standfirst: Migrants who allegedly suffer savage beatings by state officials call it ‘the game’. But as shocking evidence suggests, attempting to cross the Bosnia-Croatia border is far from mere sport
lead_paragraph: as screams ring out through the cold night air, sami, hidden behind bushes, begins to film what he can.

headline: ‘intoxicating freedom, gripping fear’: mumia abu-jamal on life as a black panther
standfirst: The best known of all incarcerated black radicals speaks out in a two-year email correspondence with trong>Ed Pilkingtontrong> on the ‘continuum’ of the Black Panthers to Black Lives Matter
lead_paragraph: the letter was dated 30 august 2016. written in black ink in spidery, meticulous handwriting, it proclaimed at the top of the page: “on a move!”, the mantra of the move group of black liberationists from philadelphia who clashed violently with the city’s police force 40 years ago, sending nine of them to prison for decades.r/>
