headline: the artist trying to change rio's violent police force from within
standfirst: Police brutality is rife in the Brazilian city, but a new project wants officers to see themselves in a different lightr>
lead_paragraph: in the city and wider state of rio de janeiro, stories of police brutality abound. in june, a security operation saw a  police helicopter open fire in the maré favela; seven people died in the raid, including a 14-year-old boy. from january to july this year, military and civil police killed 895 people. human rights watch concluded that, at this rate, the  state will have its bloodiest year in more than a decade.

headline: where does police brutality fit in america's first law enforcement museum?
standfirst: The Washington institution is likely to spark debate over whether it gets the tone right in an era of police shootings and allegations of racism
lead_paragraph: in narrative terms, it is like threading a needle. america’s first museum dedicated to law enforcement cannot avoid the racially charged subject of ferguson, missouri, where a white police officer  killed an unarmed black teenager in 2014.

headline: one to watch: oscar #worldpeace
standfirst: Ironic moniker aside, this Mike Skinner-mentored rapper doesn’t hold back when tackling police brutality and racial tension
lead_paragraph: you shouldn’t judge an artist by their stage name. british rapper oscar #worldpeace (surname unknown) may sound like the leader of an ill-fated twitter campaign, but it’s clear that the tottenham-born rapper is also a formidable talent.

headline: from the streets to the screen: how hollywood is tackling police brutality
standfirst: In films such as Monsters and Men and The Hate U Give, real-life tragedy is making its way to the cinema with anger and purpose
lead_paragraph: in terms of reaction time, cinema lags far behind tv, music and theater. for anyone  not named steven spielberg, it usually takes from one and a half to two years to nurture the seedling of an idea through scripting, pre-production, shooting, editing and distribution before the general public can finally get an eyeful. in 2016, the us presidential election had put everyone on ideological edge and rendered everything partisan. after two years of growth in size and power following the 2014 killings of tamir rice, eric garner and michael brown, the black lives matter activism collective had staked out a corner of the mainstream. and still, the flow of violence from police officers to unarmed black civilians continued without ebb.

headline: kamasi washington at sydney opera house: a defiant cry from a jazz star in his prime
standfirst: LA saxophonist evokes Black Lives Matter in a musical sermon on the mount emanating from a core of melodic through-lines
lead_paragraph: emerging onstage with his band among shards of muted light, kamasi washington steps up to the microphone. he is dressed in his signature dashiki overcoat and sparkling medallion. “we are about to go on a little journey together. are you ready to go?”

headline: justice in the factory: how black lives matter breathed new life into unions
standfirst: As Black Lives Matter and other social justice campaigns focus more on economic inequality, unions see an opportunityr>
lead_paragraph: after decades of decline unions have found a new champion in efforts to organize workers: the black lives matter movement.r/>

headline: black lives matter novel wins waterstones children's book of the year
standfirst: The Hate U Give, by US author Angie Thomas, has been praised as an extraordinary achievement
lead_paragraph: a young adult novel inspired by both the black lives matter movement and the rapper tupac shakur has won the waterstones children’s book prize.

headline: fake black lives matter facebook page run by australian union official – report
standfirst: Ian Mackay suspended from National Union of Workers over report he ran page, which he deniesl>i> Mark Zuckerberg testifies before Congress over Facebook data scandal – livei>l>
lead_paragraph: a high-ranking australian union official has been suspended amid reports he ran a fake black lives matter facebook page that solicited donations from the movement’s supporters.

headline: australian union officials who ran fake black lives matter facebook page fired
standfirst: National Union of Workers ‘deeply distressed and appalled’ about sham site, which had twice as many followers as official page
lead_paragraph: an australian union has sacked two employees linked to  a fake black lives matter facebook page.

headline: oprah supports the florida students. what about black lives matter? | khanya khondlo mtshali
standfirst: There’s something unsettling about Winfrey’s immediate support for the teens, in contrast with her comments on the #BlackLivesMatter movement
lead_paragraph: in a tweet posted on tuesday, the media mogul oprah winfrey  promised to pledge $500,000 towards the parkland students’ march for our lives rally, which will take place on 24 march in washington dc. the aftermath of the deadly mass shooting has seen students of marjory stoneman douglas high school in parkland, florida,  call for tougher gun control measures,  pleading with senators to vote against a bill protecting the right to carry assault rifles and  planning a nationwide walkout on 20 april.r/>

headline: 'we've ignited a new generation': patrisse khan-cullors on the resurgence of black activism
standfirst: The author of When They Call You a Terrorist sees hope in the Black Lives Matter movement she helped launch
lead_paragraph: it started with a facebook post.

headline: br’er cotton review – bold, hilarious drama in age of black lives matter
standfirst: trong>Theatre 503, Londonr>trong>A militant teenager grapples with politics and older relatives in Tearrance Arvelle Chisholm’s profound, beautifully staged play
lead_paragraph: what is it like for young black children to grow up in the us in the age of  black lives matter? so asks br’er cotton,  tearrance arvelle chisholm’s new play, set in a virginia community on the site of a former cotton mill.

headline: gop lawmaker condemned for inviting holocaust denier to state of the union
standfirst: Matt Gaetz says Charles Johnson, banned from Twitter for seeking help ‘taking out’ Black Lives Matter activist, is not white supremacist
lead_paragraph: a florida congressman is under fire for inviting a holocaust denier to the state of the union on tuesday.r/>

headline: erica garner, black lives matter activist, dies aged 27
standfirst: l>i>Daughter of Eric Garner was in hospital for a week after a heart attacki>i>Bernie Sanders and Bill de Blasio among those to pay tributei>l>
lead_paragraph: the black lives matter activist erica garner has died, after a week in hospital following a heart attack. she was 27. garner was the daughter of eric garner, a man who died in a police chokehold in new york in 2014.

headline: when they call you a terrorist review: black lives matter memoir convinces
standfirst: This powerful book by Black Lives Matter co-founder Patrice Khan-Cullors reminds us American racism is pervasive – even in liberal California
lead_paragraph: this is a powerful memoir by “a mother and a wife, a community organizer and queer, an artist and a dreamer”, who in 2013 invented the hashtag #blacklivesmatter and then became one of the co-founders of that organization.

headline: david lammy: ‘kids are getting killed. where is the prime minister? where is sadiq khan?’
standfirst: Following a shocking rise in violence in London in which four of his constituents died, the Tottenham MP is calling for politicians to admit the ‘war on drugs’ has failed – and that black lives matter
lead_paragraph: david lammy is one of those politicians whose public profile has never correlated with his position in his party, or converted into frontbench power, and this sort of maverick celebrity operator tends to attract suspicion. elected to represent tottenham 18 years ago, the 46-year-old has at various key moments –  the grenfell fire, the  london riots – distinguished himself in the public’s affection by seizing individual ownership of the agenda. to some, particularly in westminster, this highly personalised brand of political identity is opportunistic self-promotion, artfully disguised as heroism.

headline: hey alexa, is it true you’re a lefty feminist?
standfirst: Amazon’s virtual assistant is winding up the US far-right with her answers to questions on feminism and the Black Lives Matter movement
lead_paragraph: trong>name: trong>alexa.

headline: why the grammys continue to fail women and hip-hop
standfirst: The event may yoke itself to issues like #MeToo and Black Lives Matter, but when it comes to actual awards, women and hip-hop continue to be overlooked
lead_paragraph: expecting radical action from an awards ceremony is like expecting the weather forecast to rearrange the skies. these events reinforce cultural norms rather than setting them, even if institutions such as the oscars and golden globes are trying to reinvent themselves in the aftermath of  harvey weinstein,  donald trump and  black lives matter. but rarely has that culture of affirmation been more apparent than at this year’s grammys, which rode numerous political moments without contributing to or rewarding them.

headline: police shot a pregnant california teen – but with no video, the case dried up
standfirst: As smartphone videos sparked a national debate about police brutality, Elena Mondragon’s death went largely unnoticed
lead_paragraph: the undercover officers were dressed in plain clothes and armed with ar-15 rifles when they ambushed the car of teenagers. as the car’s driver attempted to speed away – he later said he thought they were being robbed – two of the policemen fired at the vehicle, missing the driver and striking elena mondragon, a 16-year-old girl in the passenger seat, killing her.

headline: erica garner suffering from 'major brain damage' after cardiac arrest
standfirst: Garner, a vocal member of the Black Lives Matter movement whose father was killed by a police officer three years ago, is in intensive care in New York
lead_paragraph: erica garner, who became a vocal member of the black lives matter movement after her father was killed by a police officer three years ago, was in intensive care in a new york hospital on thursday, after going into cardiac arrest over the weekend.

headline: having black lives matter in australia can help strengthen indigenous activism | jack latimore
standfirst: Malcolm Turnbull’s flat rejection of the Uluru statement hung absurdly and deplorably over our visitors’ time here
lead_paragraph: the visit of the founders of black lives matter to accept the sydney peace prize should be leveraged by first nations, indeed by all people of colour in australia plus our allies and advocates, as a mechanism to have our agendas infiltrate mainstream forums at an international level and work towards redressing the raft of issues that affect us.

headline: black activist jailed for his facebook posts speaks out about secret fbi surveillance
standfirst: trong>Exclusive: trong>Rakem Balogun spoke out against police brutality. Now he is believed to be the first prosecuted under a secretive US effort to track so-called ‘black identity extremists’r>
lead_paragraph: rakem balogun thought he was dreaming when armed agents in tactical gear stormed his apartment. startled awake by a large crash and officers screaming commands, he soon realized his nightmare was real, and he and his 15-year-old son were forced outside of their dallas home, wearing only underwear.

headline: policeman tells black man in coventry: 'you'd be first one i'd shoot'
standfirst: West Midlands officer also asks man if he is going to ‘go all Black Lives Matter’ in footage posted on Facebook
lead_paragraph: a west midlands police officer has been removed from frontline duties after he was filmed telling a black man: “you’d be the first one i’d shoot if i had a gun.”

headline: landmark case against british mining firm begins in sierra leone
standfirst: British high court convenes on foreign soil for first time as evidence is heard of Tonkolili Iron Ore Ltd’s alleged complicity in police brutality
lead_paragraph: a british court has heard testimony of the alleged  complicity of a british mining company in police brutality including rape, in an unusual hearing held in sierra leone.r/>r/>hearings in the civil case, brought by 142 claimants seeking damages from tonkolili iron ore ltd, began this week in freetown, in what is believed to be the first british high court case heard overseas.r/>r/>judge mark turner said in a previous hearing in london that he wanted to meet the claimants in person.r/>r/>british courts agreed to hear the lawsuit because the iron ore producer was previously a subsidiary of african minerals ltd (aml), which was headquartered in london before it went into administration in 2015.r/>r/>the court heard testimony from a woman who said she was picked up by police and company workers at her village near the mine while selling oranges in bumbuna, northern sierra leone, in 2010.r/>r/>“i was molested, beaten and dragged to a waiting vehicle, they tore my clothes and raped me,” the woman told the court. she was two months pregnant at the time and miscarried shortly afterwards, she said.r/>r/>the claimants argue that the company effectively oversaw policing of its mine and surrounding areas where protests turned deadly in two incidents in 2010 and 2012.r/>r/>villagers allegedly set up a roadblock to keep the company off their land in 2012, only to be faced with police who opened fire.r/>r/>witness yusif koroma said he saw an aml worker with the police “while they were firing bullets, and chasing villagers to arrest them”.r/>r/>the court is later due to hear of the fatal shooting by police of a 24-year-old female during a protest over working conditions and pay during the 2012 incident.r/>r/>astrid perry, a lawyer in the international claims team at leigh day, who is representing the villagers, said sierra leone’s attorney general, joseph fitzgerald kamara, backed the hearing being held in sierra leone.

headline: black lives matter in australia: wherever black people are, there is racism – and resistance
standfirst: The government must stand on the side of the original people of this land, and challenge the idea that their lives don’t matter
lead_paragraph: of the many remarkable moments on our australian trip so far, there’s one that stands out.

headline: they can’t kill us all: the story of black lives matter by wesley lowery – review
standfirst: The American reporter’s account of the birth of the BLM movement is well researched but doesn’t quite bring the protesters to life
lead_paragraph: “there are no stories in the riots, just the ghosts of other stories.” so says a voiceover in  m>handsworth songsm>, the black audio film collective’s dense and resonant response to the 1985 riots in birmingham. it’s a notion that infuriated salman rushdie, who wrote a strident essay for the m>guardianm> in which he claimed the film-makers, too wedded to avant-garde hermeticism, had spurned the opportunity to offer a loudspeaker to marginalised immigrants. he was on the side of a dominant style of journalism in which reporters race to burning neighbourhoods to track down and interview locals who can explain, preferably in outraged sentences, why people are angry, who is to blame for the mess, and what will happen if things don’t change.

headline: shots fired: is this black lives matter, the tv show?
standfirst: Despite many attempts, television has failed to represent the civil rights movement adequately. Does this 10-part drama succeed?
lead_paragraph: pan>related: pan> from gay rights to black lives matter: why network tv suddenly got serious

headline: 'black is beautiful' advert for toilet paper sparks outrage in brazil
standfirst: l>i>Advertising agency accused of appropriating black cultural movementi>i>‘In Brazil  #Blackisbeautiful is now toilet paper. Where do black lives matter?’i>l>
lead_paragraph: the manufacturers of a new brand of luxury black toilet paper in  brazil have been accused of racism for using the slogan “black is beautiful” as part of an advertising campaign starring a famous white actress.r/>

headline: black lives matter awarded 2017 sydney peace prize
standfirst: Former winners Naomi Klein and Pat Dodson hail recognition of US-founded movement that ‘resonates around the globe’  Podcast: ‘We’re trying to re-imagine humanity’
lead_paragraph: the human rights movement black lives matter has won this year’s sydney peace prize.

headline: this anti-abortion hijacking of black lives matter is cynical and offensive | elizabeth nelson
standfirst: Both Lives Matter has got away with a misleading ad. But using the language of human rights can’t hide its true agenda: subjugating Northern Ireland’s women
lead_paragraph: it’s a fairly large number, 100,000, but nice and round. easy to compute. most of us could even divide it by 10, at a push. apparently it is this convenient roundedness that led the advertising standards authority (asa) this week to dismiss complaints about recent claims on a billboard that  northern ireland’s abortion laws have saved “100,000” lives. in its  statement, the asa said: “we considered that 100,000 was a large, round number that readers would typically associate with estimates” – and was therefore unproblematic.

headline: the guardian view on catalonia’s referendum: the spanish state has lost | editorial
standfirst: Police brutality has ignited the political crisis. Can Madrid and the pro-independence movement find a way forward?
lead_paragraph: spain is in crisis, and its prime minister appears to be in denial. the run-up to sunday’s referendum on independence for catalonia made it clear that the country was in trouble. but neither those arranging it nor those rejecting it can fully have anticipated  href="https://www.theguardian.com/world/2017/oct/01/dozens-injured-as-riot-police-storm-catalan-ref-polling-stations" title="">the scenes at polling stations: police in riot gear beating peaceful protesters with batons, dragging voters out by the hair or throwing them down stairs, firing rubber bullets to disperse crowds – even striking at catalan firefighters and jostling with catalan police.

headline: occupy and black lives matter failed. we can either win wars or win elections | micah white
standfirst: The people’s sovereignty is dead and every protest is a hopeless struggle to revive the corpse. It is time to try a different method
lead_paragraph: the difficulties faced by recent social movements in achieving positive change, despite their tremendous speed and overwhelming size, is a sign that activism as a discipline must embark on a period of paradigmatic reevaluation. breaking with the enforced consensus that our movements are winning even when it looks like we’re losing — that occupy, black lives matter, standing rock, charlottesville and the countless protests happening worldwide every day are victories despite never achieving their avowed objectives — is not easy. challenging the activist orthodoxy as an activist is far more difficult than marching in the streets or sharing rebellious tweets. but the risk of staying silent is too great. activists must act up to save protest from irrelevance.

headline: sunday’s best tv: the handmaid's tale; shots fired
standfirst: The magnificent Margaret Atwood adaptation hits its midpoint, as the Black Lives Matter-themed drama continues to impress. Plus: OMG! My Barbie Body
lead_paragraph: “better never means better for everyone, it always means worse for some.” so learns offred as the margaret atwood adaptation continues. most obviously, it’s an idea that finds bleak expression in the denial of freedom visited upon women in theocratic gilead, but it’s subtly underscored by the backstory of how offred met her husband. elsewhere, fred reveals a penchant for “the old things”, and serena joy makes a surprising proposition. superb. m>jonathan wrightm>

headline: fbi terrorism unit says 'black identity extremists' pose a violent threat
standfirst: Leaked report, citing concerns of retaliation over ‘perceptions of police brutality against African Americans’, prompts fears of crackdown on activists
lead_paragraph: the us government has declared “black identity extremists” a violent threat, according to a leaked report from the fbi’s counter-terrorism division.

headline: detroit review – scenes from a riot revisited
standfirst: Kathryn Bigelow directs John Boyega in a stunningly shot story of disturbing police brutality and civil unrest in 1960s Detroit
lead_paragraph: having become the first woman to win the oscar for best director  with m>the hurt locker m>in 2010, kathryn bigelow became the  focus of controversy when 2012’s m>zero dark thirtym> was accused of somehow endorsing the use of torture in the hunt for osama bin laden (naomi wolf ludicrously  compared bigelow to leni riefenstahl). torture rears its ugly head again in m>detroitm>, but this time in a context that leaves no room for misinterpretation. revisiting a shocking “incident” that took place amid five days of rioting in the summer of 1967, m>detroitm> is a provocative period piece made all the more alarming by its stark contemporary relevance. more than 40 people died during the so-called “detroit rebellion”, most of them african americans, many shot by the police or national guardsmen. in attempting to unpack “the anatomy of an uprising”, bigelow focuses in on a harrowing tragedy that has become emblematic of the racial tensions still haunting the us.

headline: from africa to the us to haiti, climate change is a race issue | patrisse cullors and nyeusi nguvu
standfirst: Racism is endemic to global inequality. This means that those most affected – and killed – by climate change are black and poor peopler>l>i>Patrisse Cullors and Nyeusi Nguvu are members of the Black Lives Matter movementi>l>
lead_paragraph: just over a year ago, black lives matter uk  href="https://www.theguardian.com/uk-news/2016/sep/06/black-lives-matter-protesters-occupy-london-city-airport-runway" title="">successfully shut down london city airport. our aims were to  href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2016/sep/06/climate-change-racist-crisis-london-city-airport-black-lives-matter" title="">call attention to three things: britain’s  href="http://www.climatechangenews.com/2014/01/17/uk-has-made-largest-contribution-to-global-warming-says-study/" title="">historical responsibility for global temperature changes, while the uk remains among the least vulnerable countries to the direct effects of climate change; second, that black people and poor people globally suffer the most from environmental impacts; and third, that safe freedom of movement is a reality only for the privileged, wealthy and mostly white.

headline: for the sake of all marginalised groups, this anti-blackness must be addressed | funmilola fagbamila
standfirst: An original member of Black Lives Matter says the movement has played a key role in highlighting how race, gender, sexuality and class oppression intersect
lead_paragraph: inequality is so often misunderstood as an outgrowth of cultural deficiency. but contrary to popular belief (which pervades the right, left and centre of the political spectrum), we do not live under a  meritocracy. inequality is not the result of the superior or inferior work ethics of a society’s inhabitants.

headline: nypd officers accessed black lives matter activists' texts, documents show
standfirst: trong>Exclusive:trong> Documents obtained by the Guardian reveal details of how police posed as protesters amid unrest following the death of Eric Garner
lead_paragraph: undercover officers in the new york police department infiltrated small groups of black lives matter activists and gained access to their text messages, according to newly released nypd documents obtained by the guardian.

headline: orange is the new black season five review – so jolty it will give you whiplash
standfirst: It was meant to show a prison riot and tackle the Black Lives Matter movement. But after this bumpy, queasy ride it’s clear the writers lost their nerve
lead_paragraph: m>trong>warning: contains spoilerstrong>m>

headline: nfl boss roger goodell says all players should stand for the national anthem
standfirst: In a letter to the league’s 32 teams concerning players’ protests against police brutality, Goodell urged them to ‘move past this controversy’ and ‘honor our flag’
lead_paragraph: all nfl players should stand during the national anthem, the football league’s boss, roger goodell, said on tuesday, as the controversy over protests against police brutality by players and their dispute with donald trump rumbled on.r/>

headline: why fox doesn't want americans to see nfl players protesting about race | ameer hasan loggins
standfirst: The channel deliberately chose to hide black NFL players protesting police brutality over the weekend, and the reasons are all too clearr>
lead_paragraph: did you notice that during the playing of the star-spangled banner, philadelphia eagles player malcolm jenkins firmly raised his fist, as a symbolic gesture of black opposition to various forms of systemic oppression? no? did you see rodney mcleod and chris long alongside jenkins in solidarity with the cause in which he is standing for? no? you are not alone. viewers at home did not see any of this – not by accident, but by design.

headline: stevie wonder joins #takeaknee protest against trump's attack on nfl players
standfirst: Singers shows solidarity with sports stars after the president said players who have knelt on the field to protest police brutality were ‘sons of bitches’
lead_paragraph: stevie wonder has shown his solidarity with sports stars who were criticised by us president donald trump for kneeling on the field during the national anthem.

headline: abolitionists still have work to do in america | patrisse cullors
standfirst: While we have seen some semblance of emancipation, we still live with the vestiges of slavery every day in the United Statesr>l>i>Patrisse Cullors is a co-founder of Black Lives Matteri>l>
lead_paragraph: what does it look like to build a city, state or nation invested in communities thriving rather than their death and destruction? to ask this question is the first act of an abolitionist.

headline: 'demolish that lie': james forman jr takes on black lives matter backlash
standfirst: The son of a prominent civil rights leader argues in a new book, Locking Up Our Own, that the ‘black on black crime’ trope is based on a false premise – and lays much of the blame for America’s carceral crisis at the feet of the political class
lead_paragraph: in the conservative backlash to the black lives matter movement, deflection to “black on black” crime has become a meme. why, op-eds and pundits sputter, does the black community get so riled about police violence and yet remain silent about the gun and drug crime that savages so many of its own?

headline: wednesday briefing: a little room for eu movement
standfirst: Free movement might extend beyond Brexit … people urged to save the NHS by not using it … and Pepsi sugarcoats Black Lives Matter protests
lead_paragraph: good morning, and a happy wednesday to you. graham russell here, bringing you today’s news.

headline: taylor swift's groping trial marks her long-awaited political awakening | ben beaumont-thomas
standfirst: Attacked for her silence during the 2016 presidential election and over the Black Lives Matter movement, Taylor Swift has, by countersuing a man who groped her, finally made a universal feminist statementl>i>Ben Beaumont-Thomas is the Guardian’s music editori>l>
lead_paragraph: taylor swift has been victorious in her court case against david mueller, a denver dj who,  a jury decided, groped the pop singer by putting his hand up her skirt at a meet-and-greet. his girlfriend stood unaware alongside swift.

headline: sheriff who likened black lives matter to kkk says he will join trump administration
standfirst: David Clarke, who acted as surrogate for president during election campaign, says he will be link between federal government and local law enforcement
lead_paragraph: the controversial milwaukee county sheriff, david clarke, who has compared black lives matter to the ku klux klan, has said he is joining the trump administration as a point person between federal government and local and state law enforcement.

headline: 'we can't wait for hollywood to change' - the directors reframing black history
standfirst: From Raoul Peck’s I Am Not Your Negro to Ava DuVernay’s 13th, the factual film-makers tackling race in the era of Black Lives Matter
lead_paragraph: pan>related: pan> did #oscarssowhite work? looking beyond hollywood's diversity drought

headline: trump breaks from obama with crime crackdown and 'blue lives matter' protections
standfirst: President’s plan represents sharp about-turn from moderately progressive proposals by Obama amid unrest over fatal police shootings in past two years
lead_paragraph: by ordering a zealous crackdown on crime and new “blue lives matter” protections for police officers on thursday, donald trump made an ostentatious break with barack obama’s reformist agenda on criminal justice.

headline: mark bradford: the artist and ex-hairdresser forcing america to face ugly truths about itself
standfirst: He caused a sensation at the Venice Biennale by turning the US pavilion into a comment on slavery, Trump and police brutality. The outspoken painter talks about feeding off rejection, muscling into Monet territory – and what he’d like to do to middle-class lawns
lead_paragraph: mark bradford created one of the most talked about displays at the venice biennale earlier this year. the artist from south central la piled up stones and gravel outside the  us pavilion, to make it look like monticello,  the plantation in virginia owned by thomas jefferson, the third us president. bradford made visitors enter via a side door, as plantation slaves would have, and filled the inside with his abstract expressionist art, inspired by everything from the rise of trump to police violence and black lives matter. the result, he says, was his “ most urgent exhibition to date”.

headline: how james baldwin's the fire next time still lights the way towards equality
standfirst: A new edition of the classic treatise on civil rights, featuring photojournalist Steve Schapiro’s visual record of the struggle, provides a model for how to report in the Black Lives Matter era
lead_paragraph: there is never a bad time to encounter james baldwin, and as the wide success of the oscar-nominated documentary  i am not your negro has made clear, the appetite in trump’s america for his prescient brilliance on race and civil rights is fierce and growing.

headline: vince vaughn and mel gibson: the hollywood cops out to prove all lives matter
standfirst: Together at last! The duo is about to take on police brutality and solve race relationsr>r>
lead_paragraph: in the history of race relations and law enforcement in the united states, april 2017 will surely be regarded as the month the tide turned. first came  href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2017/apr/06/pepsi-race-luther-king-kendall-jenner-lindsay-lohan" title="">the woking of kendall jenner, a pepsi advert that began as a sort of soda spiritual, but ended up showing us that we had the answers to this little problem all along. now comes news of a would-be landmark documentary focusing on the relationship between african-american communities and the police. “you have to find out what’s the real struggle,” audience network boss chris long  href="http://deadline.com/2017/04/audience-network-vince-vaughn-documentary-police-race-relations-1202076419/" title="">declared this week when he announced the project, “and that’s part of getting the story to be authentic.” the other part is that it’s going to be made by vince vaughn.

headline: from gay rights to black lives matter: why network tv suddenly got serious
standfirst: Shows such as When We Rise and Shots Fired are introducing social issues into a schedule filled with escapism but can the Big Four ever take on premium cable?
lead_paragraph: on a reputable college campus, a young undergrad comes forward and names multiple star football players as her rapists. a scandal instantly erupts, complete with media dressing down the university administration, coaches confessing to cover-ups, and the survivor’s name dragged through the muck. it’s a regrettably familiar story, but for once, it’s not the latest above-the-fold headline from the daily news; it’s called controversy, and it may appear on fox’s programming schedule sometime soon.

headline: rights groups lead paris rally against police brutality
standfirst: French Human Rights League says protest, a month after officer charged with rape, is to express anger over police violence
lead_paragraph: rights groups and victims’ families are holding a rally in paris on sunday against police brutality after the recent baton-rape of a young man heightened tensions over alleged beatings and deaths in police custody.r/>

headline: the fire this time – the legacy of james baldwin
standfirst: His work fell foul of civil-rights-era binary racial and sexual politics but, as a new film shows, now Baldwin’s ideas are used to explain everything from Trump to Black Lives Matter
lead_paragraph: in the opening to his  1962 new yorker essay letter from a region in my mind, james baldwin remembers walking around his neighbourhood of harlem as a 14-year-old, wondering if his fate would trap him there. “what i saw around me that summer in harlem was what i had always seen,” he wrote. “nothing had changed.” more than 50 years on, baldwin’s words and philosophy have travelled thousands of miles from 110th street. his public image has been on a journey, from literary sensation with his  debut novel go tell it on the mountain in 1952 to his searing non-fiction work in the 60s that saw him revered as one of america’s most prominent public intellectuals. thirty years since he died of stomach cancer in 1987, an expat in the south of france, there is reinvigorated interest in baldwin and his ideas. february sees the release of  i am not your negro, a documentary by haitian director raoul peck that takes baldwin’s final, unfinished project – a book about the lives and murders of his friends malcolm x, martin luther king and medgar evers – as a starting point, before analysing baldwin’s sometimes strained and difficult relationship with the civil rights movement. in march, taschen will publish a special edition of the fire next time with images from life magazine photographer steve schapiro.

headline: adama traoré's death in police custody casts long shadow over french society
standfirst: Young man’s death in custody has become one of France’s most high-profile cases of alleged police brutality
lead_paragraph: one july afternoon last year in beaumont-sur-oise, a small town north of paris,  draggable="true" adama traoré was out with his older brother, bagui, planning how to celebrate his 24th birthday that evening when police drove by looking for bagui in connection with a case. but adama didn’t have his id on him and tried to run. hours later, he was dead in police custody.

headline: the good fight: a courtroom drama for the era of trump and fake news
standfirst: The Good Wife spinoff maintains the high standards and agenda-setting of its parent show – while adding police brutality, corporate evil and white privilege
lead_paragraph: the good wife’s creators, robert and michelle king, have never been afraid of silence. their heroine, alicia, mostly operated via crisply disdainful turns on her work-appropriate heels, the careful raising and putting down of a large glass of red wine or a single styptic blink when faced with another sudden revelation that was about to rain down disaster on her professional or personal life (most often both).

headline: when will france admit that police racism is systemic? | rokhaya diallo
standfirst: Through hashtag activism French society is waking up to police brutality towards minorities – but addressing the impunity the force enjoys is another question
lead_paragraph: “black lives matter” was the slogan chanted last july at a demonstration against police violence in paris. while the world’s eyes were on the us, where two black men,  alton sterling and philando castile, had been killed by white police officers, thousands gathered in the french capital to protest about  the death of adama traoré, a 24-year-old frenchman who suffocated after being arrested by gendarmes during an identity check.

headline: ‘art is my weapon’: meet the turkish artist taking on erdoğan
standfirst: Ekin Onat’s project at Venice Biennale sensationally exposes police brutality and political revolt in Turkey. As the country prepares for a historic referendum, Onat explains why she faces exile
lead_paragraph: it started, somewhat innocuously, with a tree. ekin onat waves a hand across gezi park in central istanbul, on a bright but quiet saturday morning, pinpointing the recent history of protest that galvanised all but two of turkey’s 81 provinces in the spring of 2013.

headline: janelle monáe: ‘i am the whole package’
standfirst: She’s a musician whose work has brought her massive acclaim. She’s also an outspoken activist in the Black Lives Matter movement, and now Janelle Monáe is in Moonlight, one of the most talked about films of the year
lead_paragraph: one of  janelle monáe’s earliest childhood memories is of being hugged by her grandmother, a former sharecropper from mississippi, and listening to her stories from the past: her years as a cotton picker; how their family came to be in kansas city; the importance of connection to others. it was there, in her grandma’s arms, that a slip of a six-year-old girl decided that one day she would become a storyteller, too. she wrote precocious plays and poems, sang and entered talent competitions that she often won, and gave her mother the winnings to help towards the electricity bill.

headline: radical brownies documentary: berets, badges and social justice
standfirst: See the what happens when girls embrace activism. The Radical Monarchs of California earn badges for Black Lives Matter and LGBTQ support. The movement is not without controversy but its commitment to equality is genuiner>
lead_paragraph: guardian documentaries’ latest film follows a youth group for 8- to 12-year-old girls of colour –  the radical monarchs. as a social justice-oriented alternative to the girl scouts, its members earn badges not for sewing or selling cookies,but for completing challenges on topics such as black lives matter, radical beauty, being an lgbtq ally and the environment.

headline: the hate u give by angie thomas review – racism and police brutality
standfirst: An outstanding debut stages the debates convulsing America in the story of a teenager who testifies after a shooting
lead_paragraph: “girls wear their hair coloured, curled, laid, and slayed. got me feeling basic as hell with my ponytail. guys in their freshest kicks and sagging pants grind so close to girls they just about need condoms ...” then gunshots shatter the music. fleeing from the party, 16-year-old starr is led to apparent safety by her friend khalil. shortly after, their car is pulled over by a police officer. what happens next crystallises the black lives matter movement and indeed, the whole debate about race in america. the unarmed khalil is murdered – shot at point blank range by the man starr refers to from this moment on as “officer one-fifteen”. starr is the only witness to the crime and her 16-year-old shoulders have to bear the ferocious outrage of her race and community.

headline: french police brutality in spotlight again after officer charged with rape
standfirst: One officer charged with the rape of a young man, and three other officers with assault over violent arrest in suburb of Paris
lead_paragraph: police in france are again facing allegations of brutality after an officer was charged with the rape of a young man during a violent arrest in a suburb of paris.r/>

headline: boss sounds: eight essential podcasts by women
standfirst: Whether they’re reporting on police brutality, chatting pop culture or investigating murders, women are making the must-hear podcasts of the moment. From 2 Dope Queens to Call Your Girlfriend, here’s a guide to the best
lead_paragraph: mary beard  href="https://www.lrb.co.uk/v36/n06/mary-beard/the-public-voice-of-women" title="">once pointed out that in antiquity, men openly admitted it: they didn’t like the sound of a woman’s voice. modern life reveals traces of that attitude in the destructive metaphors we use to describe how women sound. angry women are “shrill”; intelligent women are “sharp”. and, as any woman who uses her voice for work – in, for example, a podcast – will tell you, men are not shy about complaining. they have thousands of complaints, about your tone and your language. they will say you have “ href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2015/jul/24/vocal-fry-strong-female-voice" title="">vocal fry”, but what they mean is: i don’t like having to listen to you.

headline: pepsi pulls kendall jenner ad ridiculed for co-opting protest movements
standfirst: Company admits it ‘missed the mark’ after ad was mocked on social media and by civil rights activists including Martin Luther King Jr’s daughter l>i> Kendall Jenner’s Pepsi ad criticized for co-opting protest movements for profitr>i>l>
lead_paragraph: pepsi has withdrawn and apologized for a new ad campaign featuring kendall jenner, after the company faced a  backlash for a video that co-opted the imagery of protest movements to sell soda.

headline: mel gibson set to star in police brutality drama alongside vince vaughn
standfirst: The duo will play a cop in Dragged Across Concrete, about two police officers who are the subject of a video leak of their treatment of suspects
lead_paragraph: mel gibson will star alongside vince vaughn in a film about two police officers who are suspended when footage of their “strong-arm” tactics is leaked to the media.

headline: radical brownies: berets, badges and social justice – video
standfirst: The Radical Monarchs is an alternative to the Girl Scout movement for young girls carrying the torch of radical black youth activism in Oakland, California. Its members earn badges not for sewing or selling cookies, but for completing challenges on social justice including Black Lives Matter, ‘radical beauty’, being ‘an LGBTQ ally’ and the environment
lead_paragraph: none

headline: fbi posed as journalists to get evidence on bundys. now it could hurt their case
standfirst: Trial stemming from a 2014 standoff could be derailed by a ploy to pose as a ‘fake film company’ and an ethics scandal involving a BLM officer and Burning Man
lead_paragraph: fbi agents posed as journalists and tricked the bundy ranching family and their supporters into giving on-camera interviews that prosecutors may use in upcoming trials, according to defense attorneys and court records.
